\phantomsection\label{index::doc}


MariaDB Tools are a collection of advanced command-line tools
used by \href{http://www.mariadb.com/}{MariaDB}) support staff
to perform a variety of MariaDB database and system tasks
that are too difficult or complex to perform manually.

These tools are ideal alternatives to private or ``one-off'' scripts,
because they are professionally developed, formally tested,
and fully documented.
They are also fully self-contained,
so installation is quick and easy,
and no libraries are installed.

MariaDB Tools were derived from MariaDB scripts, Percona Toolkit,
Maatkit, PalaminoDB Tools and Aspersa,
some of the best-known toolkits for MariaDB server administration.
It is developed and supported by MariaDB.


\chapter{Getting MariaDB Tools}
\label{index:mariadb-tools-documentation}\label{index:getting-mariadb-tools}

\section{Installing MariaDB Tools}
\label{installation::doc}\label{installation:installing-mariadb-tools}\label{installation:install}
MariaDB provides packages for most popular 64-bit Linux distributions:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Debian 7 (``wheezy'')

\item {} 
Debian 8 (``jessie'')

\item {} 
Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (Trusty Tahr)

\item {} 
Ubuntu 16.04 LTS (Xenial Xerus)

\item {} 
Ubuntu 16.10 (Yakkety Yak)

\item {} 
Ubuntu 17.04 (Zesty Zapus)

\item {} 
Red Hat Enterprise Linux or CentOS 6 (Santiago)

\item {} 
Red Hat Enterprise Linux or CentOS 7 (Maipo)

\end{itemize}

\begin{notice}{note}{Note:}
MariaDB Tools should work on other DEB-based and RPM-based systems
(for example, Oracle Linux and Amazon Linux AMI),
but it is tested only on those listed above.
\end{notice}

It is recommended to install MariaDB software from official repositories:
\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
Configure repositories as described in
\href{https://mariadb.com/docs/deploy/installation/\#install-repository}{MariaDB Enterprise Documentation}.

\item {} 
Install MariaDB Tools using the corresponding package manager:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
For Debian or Ubuntu:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo apt-get install MariaDB-Tools
\end{Verbatim}

\item {} 
For RHEL or CentOS:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sudo yum install MariaDB-Tools
\end{Verbatim}

\end{itemize}

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{Alternative Install Methods}
\label{installation:alternative-install-methods}
You can also download the packages from the
\href{https://customers.mariadb.com}{MariaDB Customer Portal}
and install it using tools like \code{dpkg} and \code{rpm},
depending on your system.

If you want to download a specific tool, use the following address:
\href{http://tools.mariadb.com/get}{http://tools.mariadb.com/get}

For example, to download the \code{mariadb-summary} tool, run:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
wget tools.mariadb.com/get/mariadb-summary
\end{Verbatim}

\section{\textbf{mariadb-align-output}}
\label{mariadb-align-output:mariadb-align-output}\label{mariadb-align-output::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-align-output:name}
\textbf{mariadb-align-output} - Align output from other tools to columns.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-align-output:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-align-output:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{align}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{output} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{FILES}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-align-output} aligns output from other tools to columns.  If no FILES are specified,
STDIN is read.

If a tool prints the following output,

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
DATABASE TABLE   ROWS
foo      bar      100
long\PYGZus{}db\PYGZus{}name table  1
another  long\PYGZus{}name 500
\end{Verbatim}

then \textbf{mariadb-align-output} reprints the output as,

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
DATABASE     TABLE     ROWS
foo          bar        100
long\PYGZus{}db\PYGZus{}name table        1
another      long\PYGZus{}name  500
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-align-output:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-align-output} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-align-output:description}
\textbf{mariadb-align-output} reads lines and splits them into words.  It counts how many
words each line has, and if there is one number that predominates, it assumes
this is the number of words in each line.  Then it discards all lines that
don't have that many words, and looks at the 2nd line that does.  It assumes
this is the first non-header line.  Based on whether each word looks numeric
or not, it decides on column alignment.  Finally, it goes through and decides
how wide each column should be, and then prints them out.

This is useful for things like aligning the output of vmstat or iostat so it
is easier to read.


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-align-output:options}
This tool accepts additional command-line arguments.  Refer to the
``SYNOPSIS'' and usage information for details.
\index{mariadb-align-output command line option!--help}\index{--help!mariadb-align-output command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-align-output:cmdoption-mariadb-align-output--help}\pysigline{\bfcode{--help}\code{}}
Show help and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-align-output command line option!--version}\index{--version!mariadb-align-output command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}

Show version and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-align-output:environment}
This tool does not use any environment variables.


\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}
\label{mariadb-align-output:system-requirements}
You need Perl, and some core packages that ought to be installed in any
reasonably new version of Perl.

\section{\textbf{mariadb-archiver}}
\label{mariadb-archiver:mariadb-archiver}\label{mariadb-archiver::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-archiver:name}
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} - Archive rows from a MariaDB table into another table or a file.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-archiver:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-archiver:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-archiver [OPTIONS] --source DSN --where WHERE
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-archiver} nibbles records from a MariaDB table.  The --source and --dest
arguments use DSN syntax; if COPY is yes, --dest defaults to the key's value
from --source.


\subsubsection{Examples}
\label{mariadb-archiver:examples}
Archive all rows from oltp\_server to olap\_server and to a file:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-archiver --source \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}oltp\PYGZus{}server,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}tbl --dest \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}olap\PYGZus{}server \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
  --file \PYG{l+s+s1}{'/var/log/archive/\PYGZpc{}Y-\PYGZpc{}m-\PYGZpc{}d-\PYGZpc{}D.\PYGZpc{}t'}                           \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
  --where \PYG{l+s+s2}{"1=1"} --limit 1000 --commit-each
\end{Verbatim}

Purge (delete) orphan rows from child table:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-archiver --source \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}host,D\PYG{o}{=}db,t\PYG{o}{=}child --purge \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
  --where \PYG{l+s+s1}{'NOT EXISTS(SELECT * FROM parent WHERE col=child.col)'}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-archiver:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-archiver:description}
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} is the tool I use to archive tables as described in
\href{http://tinyurl.com/mysql-archiving}{http://tinyurl.com/mysql-archiving}.  The goal is a low-impact, forward-only
job to nibble old data out of the table without impacting OLTP queries much.
You can insert the data into another table, which need not be on the same
server.  You can also write it to a file in a format suitable for LOAD DATA
INFILE.  Or you can do neither, in which case it's just an incremental DELETE.

\textbf{mariadb-archiver} is extensible via a plugin mechanism.  You can inject your own
code to add advanced archiving logic that could be useful for archiving
dependent data, applying complex business rules, or building a data warehouse
during the archiving process.

You need to choose values carefully for some options.  The most important are
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--retries]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}retries}}}}, and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}txn-size}}}}.

The strategy is to find the first row(s), then scan some index forward-only to
find more rows efficiently.  Each subsequent query should not scan the entire
table; it should seek into the index, then scan until it finds more archivable
rows.  Specifying the index with the `i' part of the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} argument can
be crucial for this; use {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dry-run]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dry-run}}}} to examine the generated queries and be
sure to EXPLAIN them to see if they are efficient (most of the time you probably
want to scan the PRIMARY key, which is the default).  Even better, examine the
difference in the Handler status counters before and after running the query,
and make sure it is not scanning the whole table every query.

You can disable the seek-then-scan optimizations partially or wholly with
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-ascend]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-ascend}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--ascend-first]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}ascend-first}}}}.  Sometimes this may be more efficient
for multi-column keys.  Be aware that \textbf{mariadb-archiver} is built to start at the
beginning of the index it chooses and scan it forward-only.  This might result
in long table scans if you're trying to nibble from the end of the table by an
index other than the one it prefers.  See {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and read the
documentation on the \code{i} part if this applies to you.


\subsection{MariaDB Galera Cluster}
\label{mariadb-archiver:mariadb-galera-cluster}
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} works with MariaDB Galera Cluster 10.1 and newer,
but there are three limitations you should consider before archiving on
a cluster:

Error on commit
\begin{quote}

\textbf{mariadb-archiver} does not check for error when it commits transactions.
Commits on Galera can fail, but the tool does not yet check for or retry the
transaction when this happens.  If it happens, the tool will die.
\end{quote}

MyISAM tables
\begin{quote}

Archiving MyISAM tables works, but MyISAM support in Galera is still
experimental at the time of this release.  There are several known bugs with
Galera, MyISAM tables, and \code{AUTO\_INCREMENT} columns.  Therefore, you must ensure
that archiving will not directly or indirectly result in the use of default
\code{AUTO\_INCREMENT} values for a MyISAM table.  For example, this happens with
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} if {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--columns]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}columns}}}} is used and the \code{AUTO\_INCREMENT} column is not
included.  The tool does not check for this!
\end{quote}

Non-cluster options
\begin{quote}

Certain options may or may not work.  For example, if a cluster node
is not also a slave, then {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--check-slave-lag]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}check-slave-lag}}}} does not work.  And since Galera
tables are usually InnoDB, but InnoDB doesn't support \code{INSERT DELAYED}, then
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--delayed-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}delayed-insert}}}} does not work.  Other options may also not work, but
the tool does not check them, therefore you should test archiving on a test
cluster before archiving on your real cluster.
\end{quote}


\subsection{OUTPUT}
\label{mariadb-archiver:output}
If you specify {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--progress]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}progress}}}}, the output is a header row, plus status output
at intervals.  Each row in the status output lists the current date and time,
how many seconds \textbf{mariadb-archiver} has been running, and how many rows it has
archived.

If you specify {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--statistics]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}statistics}}}}, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} outputs timing and other
information to help you identify which part of your archiving process takes the
most time.


\subsection{ERROR-HANDLING}
\label{mariadb-archiver:error-handling}
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} tries to catch signals and exit gracefully; for example, if you
send it SIGTERM (Ctrl-C on UNIX-ish systems), it will catch the signal, print a
message about the signal, and exit fairly normally.  It will not execute
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--analyze]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}analyze}}}} or {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--optimize]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}optimize}}}}, because these may take a long time to finish.
It will run all other code normally, including calling after\_finish() on any
plugins (see ``EXTENDING'').

In other words, a signal, if caught, will break out of the main archiving
loop and skip optimize/analyze.


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-archiver:options}
Specify at least one of {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}}, or {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--purge]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}purge}}}}.

{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--ignore]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}ignore}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--replace]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}replace}}}} are mutually exclusive.

{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}txn-size}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}commit-each}}}} are mutually exclusive.

{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--low-priority-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}low-priority-insert}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--delayed-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}delayed-insert}}}} are mutually exclusive.

{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--share-lock]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}share-lock}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--for-update]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}for-update}}}} are mutually exclusive.

{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--analyze]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}analyze}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--optimize]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}optimize}}}} are mutually exclusive.

{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-ascend]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-ascend}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-delete}}}} are mutually exclusive.

DSN values in {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} default to values from {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} if COPY is yes.
\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--analyze}\index{--analyze!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--analyze}\pysigline{\bfcode{--analyze}\code{}}
type: string

Run ANALYZE TABLE afterwards on {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and/or {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.

Runs ANALYZE TABLE after finishing.  The argument is an arbitrary string.  If it
contains the letter `s', the source will be analyzed.  If it contains `d', the
destination will be analyzed.  You can specify either or both.  For example, the
following will analyze both:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--analyze\PYG{o}{=}ds
\end{Verbatim}

See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/analyze-table/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/analyze-table/} for details on ANALYZE
TABLE.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--ascend-first}\index{--ascend-first!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--ascend-first}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ascend-first}\code{}}
Ascend only first column of index.

If you do want to use the ascending index optimization (see {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-ascend]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-ascend}}}}),
but do not want to incur the overhead of ascending a large multi-column index,
you can use this option to tell \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to ascend only the leftmost column
of the index.  This can provide a significant performance boost over not
ascending the index at all, while avoiding the cost of ascending the whole
index.

See ``EXTENDING'' for a discussion of how this interacts with plugins.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--ask-pass}\index{--ask-pass!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--ask-pass}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ask-pass}\code{}}
Prompt for a password when connecting to MariaDB.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--buffer}\index{--buffer!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--buffer}\pysigline{\bfcode{--buffer}\code{}}
Buffer output to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} and flush at commit.

Disables autoflushing to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} and flushes {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} to disk only when a
transaction commits.  This typically means the file is block-flushed by the
operating system, so there may be some implicit flushes to disk between
commits as well.  The default is to flush {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} to disk after every row.

The danger is that a crash might cause lost data.

The performance increase I have seen from using {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--buffer]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}buffer}}}} is around 5 to 15
percent.  Your mileage may vary.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--bulk-delete}\index{--bulk-delete!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-delete}\pysigline{\bfcode{--bulk-delete}\code{}}
Delete each chunk with a single statement (implies {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}commit-each}}}}).

Delete each chunk of rows in bulk with a single \code{DELETE} statement.  The
statement deletes every row between the first and last row of the chunk,
inclusive.  It implies {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}commit-each}}}}, since it would be a bad idea to
\code{INSERT} rows one at a time and commit them before the bulk \code{DELETE}.

The normal method is to delete every row by its primary key.  Bulk deletes might
be a lot faster.  \textbf{They also might not be faster} if you have a complex
\code{WHERE} clause.

This option completely defers all \code{DELETE} processing until the chunk of rows
is finished.  If you have a plugin on the source, its \code{before\_delete} method
will not be called.  Instead, its \code{before\_bulk\_delete} method is called later.

\textbf{WARNING}: if you have a plugin on the source that sometimes doesn't return
true from \code{is\_archivable()}, you should use this option only if you understand
what it does.  If the plugin instructs \textbf{mariadb-archiver} not to archive a row,
it will still be deleted by the bulk delete!

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--{[}no{]}bulk-delete-limit}\index{--{[}no{]}bulk-delete-limit!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}bulk-delete-limit}}
default: yes

Add {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-delete}}}} statement.

This is an advanced option and you should not disable it unless you know what
you are doing and why!  By default, {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-delete}}}} appends a {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}}
clause to the bulk delete SQL statement.  In certain cases, this clause can be
omitted by specifying \code{-{-}no-bulk-delete-limit}.  {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} must still be
specified.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--bulk-insert}\index{--bulk-insert!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-insert}\pysigline{\bfcode{--bulk-insert}\code{}}
Insert each chunk with LOAD DATA INFILE (implies {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-delete}}}} {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}commit-each}}}}).

Insert each chunk of rows with \code{LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE}.  This may be much
faster than inserting a row at a time with \code{INSERT} statements.  It is
implemented by creating a temporary file for each chunk of rows, and writing the
rows to this file instead of inserting them.  When the chunk is finished, it
uploads the rows.

To protect the safety of your data, this option forces bulk deletes to be used.
It would be unsafe to delete each row as it is found, before inserting the rows
into the destination first.  Forcing bulk deletes guarantees that the deletion
waits until the insertion is successful.

The {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--low-priority-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}low-priority-insert}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--replace]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}replace}}}}, and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--ignore]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}ignore}}}} options work
with this option, but {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--delayed-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}delayed-insert}}}} does not.

If \code{LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE} throws an error in the lines of \code{The used
command is not allowed with this MariaDB version}, refer to the documentation
for the \code{L} DSN option.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--channel}\index{--channel!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--channel}\pysigline{\bfcode{--channel}\code{}}
type: string

Channel name used when connected to a server using replication channels.
Suppose you have two masters, master\_a at port 12345, master\_b at port 1236 and
a slave connected to both masters using channels chan\_master\_a and chan\_master\_b.
If you want to run \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to syncronize the slave against master\_a, \textbf{mariadb-archiver}
won't be able to determine what's the correct master since SHOW SLAVE STATUS
will return 2 rows. In this case, you can use --channel=chan\_master\_a to specify
the channel name to use in the SHOW SLAVE STATUS command.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--charset}\index{--charset!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--charset}\pysigline{\bfcode{--charset}\code{}}
short form: -A; type: string

Default character set.  If the value is utf8, sets Perl's binmode on
STDOUT to utf8, passes the mysql\_enable\_utf8 option to DBD::mysql, and runs SET
NAMES UTF8 after connecting to MariaDB.  Any other value sets binmode on STDOUT
without the utf8 layer, and runs SET NAMES after connecting to MariaDB.

Note that only charsets as known by MariaDB are recognized; So for example,
``UTF8'' will work, but ``UTF-8'' will not.

See also \emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}check-charset}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--{[}no{]}check-charset}\index{--{[}no{]}check-charset!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}check-charset}}
default: yes

Ensure connection and table character sets are the same.  Disabling this check
may cause text to be erroneously converted from one character set to another
(usually from utf8 to latin1) which may cause data loss or mojibake.  Disabling
this check may be useful or necessary when character set conversions are
intended.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--{[}no{]}check-columns}\index{--{[}no{]}check-columns!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}check-columns}}
default: yes

Ensure {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} have same columns.

Enabled by default; causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to check that the source and destination
tables have the same columns.  It does not check column order, data type, etc.
It just checks that all columns in the source exist in the destination and
vice versa.  If there are any differences, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} will exit with an
error.

To disable this check, specify --no-check-columns.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--check-interval}\index{--check-interval!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--check-interval}\pysigline{\bfcode{--check-interval}\code{}}
type: time; default: 1s
\begin{description}
\item[{If {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--check-slave-lag]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}check-slave-lag}}}} is given, this defines how long the tool pauses each}] \leavevmode
time it discovers that a slave is lagging.
This check is performed every 100 rows.

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--check-slave-lag}\index{--check-slave-lag!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--check-slave-lag}\pysigline{\bfcode{--check-slave-lag}\code{}}
type: string; repeatable: yes

Pause archiving until the specified DSN's slave lag is less than {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--max-lag]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}max-lag}}}}.
This option can be specified multiple times for checking more than one slave.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--columns}\index{--columns!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--columns}\pysigline{\bfcode{--columns}\code{}}
short form: -c; type: array

Comma-separated list of columns to archive.

Specify a comma-separated list of columns to fetch, write to the file, and
insert into the destination table.  If specified, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} ignores other
columns unless it needs to add them to the \code{SELECT} statement for ascending an
index or deleting rows.  It fetches and uses these extra columns internally, but
does not write them to the file or to the destination table.  It \emph{does} pass
them to plugins.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--primary-key-only]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}primary-key-only}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--commit-each}\index{--commit-each!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each}\pysigline{\bfcode{--commit-each}\code{}}
Commit each set of fetched and archived rows (disables {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}txn-size}}}}).

Commits transactions and flushes {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} after each set of rows has been
archived, before fetching the next set of rows, and before sleeping if
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sleep]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sleep}}}} is specified.  Disables {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}txn-size}}}}; use {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} to
control the transaction size with {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}commit-each}}}}.

This option is useful as a shortcut to make {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}txn-size}}}} the
same value, but more importantly it avoids transactions being held open while
searching for more rows.  For example, imagine you are archiving old rows from
the beginning of a very large table, with {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} 1000 and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}txn-size}}}}
1000.  After some period of finding and archiving 1000 rows at a time,
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} finds the last 999 rows and archives them, then executes the next
SELECT to find more rows.  This scans the rest of the table, but never finds any
more rows.  It has held open a transaction for a very long time, only to
determine it is finished anyway.  You can use {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}commit-each}}}} to avoid this.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--config}\index{--config!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--config}\pysigline{\bfcode{--config}\code{}}
type: Array

Read this comma-separated list of config files; if specified, this must be the
first option on the command line.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--database}\index{--database!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--database}\pysigline{\bfcode{--database}\code{}}
short form: -D; type: string

Connect to this database.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--delayed-insert}\index{--delayed-insert!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--delayed-insert}\pysigline{\bfcode{--delayed-insert}\code{}}
Add the DELAYED modifier to INSERT statements.

Adds the DELAYED modifier to INSERT or REPLACE statements.  See
\href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/insert/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/insert/} for details.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--dest}\index{--dest!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest}\pysigline{\bfcode{--dest}\code{}}
type: DSN

DSN specifying the table to archive to.

This item specifies a table into which \textbf{mariadb-archiver} will insert rows
archived from {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}.  It uses the same key=val argument format as
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}.  Most missing values default to the same values as
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}, so you don't have to repeat options that are the same in
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.  Use the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--help]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}help}}}} option to see which values
are copied from {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}.

\textbf{WARNING}: Using a default options file (F) DSN option that defines a
socket for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to connect to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} using
that socket unless another socket for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} is specified.  This
means that \textbf{mariadb-archiver} may incorrectly connect to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} when it
connects to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.  For example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--source \PYG{n+nv}{F}\PYG{o}{=}host1.cnf,D\PYG{o}{=}db,t\PYG{o}{=}tbl --dest \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}host2
\end{Verbatim}

When \textbf{mariadb-archiver} connects to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}, host2, it will connect via the
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}, host1, socket defined in host1.cnf.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--dry-run}\index{--dry-run!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dry-run}\pysigline{\bfcode{--dry-run}\code{}}
Print queries and exit without doing anything.

Causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to exit after printing the filename and SQL statements
it will use.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--file}\index{--file!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file}\pysigline{\bfcode{--file}\code{}}
type: string

File to archive to, with DATE\_FORMAT()-like formatting.

Filename to write archived rows to.  A subset of MariaDB's DATE\_FORMAT()
formatting codes are allowed in the filename, as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZpc{}d    Day of the month, numeric \PYG{o}{(}01..31\PYG{o}{)}
\PYGZpc{}H    Hour \PYG{o}{(}00..23\PYG{o}{)}
\PYGZpc{}i    Minutes, numeric \PYG{o}{(}00..59\PYG{o}{)}
\PYGZpc{}m    Month, numeric \PYG{o}{(}01..12\PYG{o}{)}
\PYGZpc{}s    Seconds \PYG{o}{(}00..59\PYG{o}{)}
\PYGZpc{}Y    Year, numeric, four digits
\end{Verbatim}

You can use the following extra format codes too:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYGZpc{}D    Database name
\PYGZpc{}t    Table name
\end{Verbatim}

Example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--file \PYG{l+s+s1}{'/var/log/archive/\PYGZpc{}Y-\PYGZpc{}m-\PYGZpc{}d-\PYGZpc{}D.\PYGZpc{}t'}
\end{Verbatim}

The file's contents are in the same format used by SELECT INTO OUTFILE, as
documented in the MariaDB manual: rows terminated by newlines, columns
terminated by tabs, NULL characters are represented by N, and special
characters are escaped by .  This lets you reload a file with LOAD DATA
INFILE's default settings.

If you want a column header at the top of the file, see {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--header]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}header}}}}.  The file
is auto-flushed by default; see {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--buffer]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}buffer}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--for-update}\index{--for-update!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--for-update}\pysigline{\bfcode{--for-update}\code{}}
Adds the FOR UPDATE modifier to SELECT statements.

For details, see \href{http://dev.mysql.com/doc/en/innodb-locking-reads.html}{http://dev.mysql.com/doc/en/innodb-locking-reads.html}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--header}\index{--header!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--header}\pysigline{\bfcode{--header}\code{}}
Print column header at top of {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}}.

Writes column names as the first line in the file given by {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}}.  If the
file exists, does not write headers; this keeps the file loadable with LOAD
DATA INFILE in case you append more output to it.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--help}\index{--help!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--help}\pysigline{\bfcode{--help}\code{}}
Show help and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--high-priority-select}\index{--high-priority-select!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--high-priority-select}\pysigline{\bfcode{--high-priority-select}\code{}}
Adds the HIGH\_PRIORITY modifier to SELECT statements.

See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/select/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/select/} for details.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--host}\index{--host!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--host}\pysigline{\bfcode{--host}\code{}}
short form: -h; type: string

Connect to host.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--ignore}\index{--ignore!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--ignore}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore}\code{}}
Use IGNORE for INSERT statements.

Causes INSERTs into {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} to be INSERT IGNORE.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--limit}\index{--limit!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--limit}\pysigline{\bfcode{--limit}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

Number of rows to fetch and archive per statement.

Limits the number of rows returned by the SELECT statements that retrieve rows
to archive.  Default is one row.  It may be more efficient to increase the
limit, but be careful if you are archiving sparsely, skipping over many rows;
this can potentially cause more contention with other queries, depending on the
storage engine, transaction isolation level, and options such as
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--for-update]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}for-update}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--local}\index{--local!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--local}\pysigline{\bfcode{--local}\code{}}
Do not write OPTIMIZE or ANALYZE queries to binlog.

Adds the NO\_WRITE\_TO\_BINLOG modifier to ANALYZE and OPTIMIZE queries.  See
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--analyze]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}analyze}}}} for details.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--low-priority-delete}\index{--low-priority-delete!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--low-priority-delete}\pysigline{\bfcode{--low-priority-delete}\code{}}
Adds the LOW\_PRIORITY modifier to DELETE statements.

See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/delete/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/delete/} for details.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--low-priority-insert}\index{--low-priority-insert!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--low-priority-insert}\pysigline{\bfcode{--low-priority-insert}\code{}}
Adds the LOW\_PRIORITY modifier to INSERT or REPLACE statements.

See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/insert/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/insert/} for details.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--max-flow-ctl}\index{--max-flow-ctl!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--max-flow-ctl}\pysigline{\bfcode{--max-flow-ctl}\code{}}
type: float

Somewhat similar to --max-lag but for Galera clusters.
Check average time cluster spent pausing for Flow Control and make tool pause if
it goes over the percentage indicated in the option.
Default is no Flow Control checking.
This option is available for Galera versions 5.6 or higher.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--max-lag}\index{--max-lag!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--max-lag}\pysigline{\bfcode{--max-lag}\code{}}
type: time; default: 1s

Pause archiving if the slave given by {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--check-slave-lag]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}check-slave-lag}}}} lags.

This option causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to look at the slave every time it's about
to fetch another row.  If the slave's lag is greater than the option's value,
or if the slave isn't running (so its lag is NULL), pt-table-checksum sleeps
for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--check-interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}check-interval}}}} seconds and then looks at the lag again.  It repeats
until the slave is caught up, then proceeds to fetch and archive the row.

This option may eliminate the need for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sleep]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sleep}}}} or {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sleep-coef]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sleep-coef}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--no-ascend}\index{--no-ascend!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-ascend}\pysigline{\bfcode{--no-ascend}\code{}}
Do not use ascending index optimization.

The default ascending-index optimization causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to optimize
repeated \code{SELECT} queries so they seek into the index where the previous query
ended, then scan along it, rather than scanning from the beginning of the table
every time.  This is enabled by default because it is generally a good strategy
for repeated accesses.

Large, multiple-column indexes may cause the WHERE clause to be complex enough
that this could actually be less efficient.  Consider for example a four-column
PRIMARY KEY on (a, b, c, d).  The WHERE clause to start where the last query
ended is as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
WHERE \PYG{o}{(}a \textgreater{} ?\PYG{o}{)}
   OR \PYG{o}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a} \PYG{o}{=} ? AND b \textgreater{} ?\PYG{o}{)}
   OR \PYG{o}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a} \PYG{o}{=} ? AND \PYG{n+nv}{b} \PYG{o}{=} ? AND c \textgreater{} ?\PYG{o}{)}
   OR \PYG{o}{(}\PYG{n+nv}{a} \PYG{o}{=} ? AND \PYG{n+nv}{b} \PYG{o}{=} ? AND \PYG{n+nv}{c} \PYG{o}{=} ? AND d \textgreater{}\PYG{o}{=} ?\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

Populating the placeholders with values uses memory and CPU, adds network
traffic and parsing overhead, and may make the query harder for MariaDB to
optimize.  A four-column key isn't a big deal, but a ten-column key in which
every column allows \code{NULL} might be.

Ascending the index might not be necessary if you know you are simply removing
rows from the beginning of the table in chunks, but not leaving any holes, so
starting at the beginning of the table is actually the most efficient thing to
do.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--ascend-first]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}ascend-first}}}}.  See ``EXTENDING'' for a discussion of how this
interacts with plugins.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--no-delete}\index{--no-delete!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-delete}\pysigline{\bfcode{--no-delete}\code{}}
Do not delete archived rows.

Causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} not to delete rows after processing them.  This disallows
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-ascend]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-ascend}}}}, because enabling them both would cause an infinite loop.

If there is a plugin on the source DSN, its \code{before\_delete} method is called
anyway, even though \textbf{mariadb-archiver} will not execute the delete.  See
``EXTENDING'' for more on plugins.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--optimize}\index{--optimize!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--optimize}\pysigline{\bfcode{--optimize}\code{}}
type: string

Run OPTIMIZE TABLE afterwards on {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and/or {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.

Runs OPTIMIZE TABLE after finishing.  See {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--analyze]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}analyze}}}} for the option syntax
and \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/optimize-table/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/optimize-table/} for details on OPTIMIZE
TABLE.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--output-format}\index{--output-format!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--output-format}\pysigline{\bfcode{--output-format}\code{}}
type: string

Used with {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} to specify the output format.
\begin{description}
\item[{Valid formats are:}] \leavevmode
dump: MariaDB dump format using tabs as field separator (default)
csv : Dump rows using `,' as separator and optionally enclosing fields by `'''. This format is equivalent to FIELDS TERMINATED BY `,' OPTIONALLY ENCLOSED BY `'''.

\end{description}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--password}\index{--password!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--password}\pysigline{\bfcode{--password}\code{}}
short form: -p; type: string

Password to use when connecting.
If password contains commas they must be escaped with a backslash: ``exam,ple''

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--pid}\index{--pid!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--pid}\pysigline{\bfcode{--pid}\code{}}
type: string

Create the given PID file.  The tool won't start if the PID file already
exists and the PID it contains is different than the current PID.  However,
if the PID file exists and the PID it contains is no longer running, the
tool will overwrite the PID file with the current PID.  The PID file is
removed automatically when the tool exits.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--plugin}\index{--plugin!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--plugin}\pysigline{\bfcode{--plugin}\code{}}
type: string

Perl module name to use as a generic plugin.

Specify the Perl module name of a general-purpose plugin.  It is currently used
only for statistics (see {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--statistics]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}statistics}}}}) and must have \code{new()} and a
\code{statistics()} method.

The \code{new( src =} \$src, dst =\textgreater{} \$dst, opts =\textgreater{} \$o )\textgreater{} method gets the source
and destination DSNs, and their database connections, just like the
connection-specific plugins do.  It also gets an OptionParser object (\code{\$o}) for
accessing command-line options (example: {\color{red}\bfseries{}{}`{}`}\$o-{\color{red}\bfseries{}{}`{}`}get(`purge');\textgreater{}).

The \code{statistics(\textbackslash{}\%stats, \$time)} method gets a hashref of the statistics
collected by the archiving job, and the time the whole job started.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--port}\index{--port!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--port}\pysigline{\bfcode{--port}\code{}}
short form: -P; type: int

Port number to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--primary-key-only}\index{--primary-key-only!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--primary-key-only}\pysigline{\bfcode{--primary-key-only}\code{}}
Primary key columns only.

A shortcut for specifying {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--columns]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}columns}}}} with the primary key columns.  This is
an efficiency if you just want to purge rows; it avoids fetching the entire row,
when only the primary key columns are needed for \code{DELETE} statements.  See also
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--purge]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}purge}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--progress}\index{--progress!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--progress}\pysigline{\bfcode{--progress}\code{}}
type: int

Print progress information every X rows.

Prints current time, elapsed time, and rows archived every X rows.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--purge}\index{--purge!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--purge}\pysigline{\bfcode{--purge}\code{}}
Purge instead of archiving; allows omitting {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.

Allows archiving without a {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} or {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} argument, which is
effectively a purge since the rows are just deleted.

If you just want to purge rows, consider specifying the table's primary key
columns with {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--primary-key-only]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}primary-key-only}}}}.  This will prevent fetching all columns
from the server for no reason.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--quick-delete}\index{--quick-delete!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--quick-delete}\pysigline{\bfcode{--quick-delete}\code{}}
Adds the QUICK modifier to DELETE statements.

See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/delete/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/delete/} for details.  As stated in the
documentation, in some cases it may be faster to use DELETE QUICK followed by
OPTIMIZE TABLE.  You can use {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--optimize]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}optimize}}}} for this.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--quiet}\index{--quiet!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--quiet}\pysigline{\bfcode{--quiet}\code{}}
short form: -q

Do not print any output, such as for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--statistics]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}statistics}}}}.

Suppresses normal output, including the output of {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--statistics]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}statistics}}}}, but doesn't
suppress the output from {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--why-quit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}why-quit}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--replace}\index{--replace!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--replace}\pysigline{\bfcode{--replace}\code{}}
Causes INSERTs into {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} to be written as REPLACE.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--retries}\index{--retries!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--retries}\pysigline{\bfcode{--retries}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

Number of retries per timeout or deadlock.

Specifies the number of times \textbf{mariadb-archiver} should retry when there is an
InnoDB lock wait timeout or deadlock.  When retries are exhausted,
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} will exit with an error.

Consider carefully what you want to happen when you are archiving between a
mixture of transactional and non-transactional storage engines.  The INSERT to
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} and DELETE from {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} are on separate connections, so they
do not actually participate in the same transaction even if they're on the same
server.  However, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} implements simple distributed transactions in
code, so commits and rollbacks should happen as desired across the two
connections.

At this time I have not written any code to handle errors with transactional
storage engines other than InnoDB.  Request that feature if you need it.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--run-time}\index{--run-time!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--run-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--run-time}\code{}}
type: time

Time to run before exiting.

Optional suffix s=seconds, m=minutes, h=hours, d=days; if no suffix, s is used.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--{[}no{]}safe-auto-increment}\index{--{[}no{]}safe-auto-increment!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}safe-auto-increment}}
default: yes

Do not archive row with max AUTO\_INCREMENT.

Adds an extra WHERE clause to prevent \textbf{mariadb-archiver} from removing the newest
row when ascending a single-column AUTO\_INCREMENT key.  This guards against
re-using AUTO\_INCREMENT values if the server restarts, and is enabled by
default.

The extra WHERE clause contains the maximum value of the auto-increment column
as of the beginning of the archive or purge job.  If new rows are inserted while
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} is running, it will not see them.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--sentinel}\index{--sentinel!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sentinel}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sentinel}\code{}}
type: string; default: /tmp/mariadb-archiver-sentinel

Exit if this file exists.

The presence of the file specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sentinel]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sentinel}}}} will cause \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to
stop archiving and exit.  The default is /tmp/mariadb-archiver-sentinel.  You
might find this handy to stop cron jobs gracefully if necessary.  See also
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--stop]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}stop}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--slave-user}\index{--slave-user!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--slave-user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--slave-user}\code{}}
type: string

Sets the user to be used to connect to the slaves.
This parameter allows you to have a different user with less privileges on the
slaves but that user must exist on all slaves.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--slave-password}\index{--slave-password!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--slave-password}\pysigline{\bfcode{--slave-password}\code{}}
type: string

Sets the password to be used to connect to the slaves.
It can be used with --slave-user and the password for the user must be the same
on all slaves.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--set-vars}\index{--set-vars!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--set-vars}\pysigline{\bfcode{--set-vars}\code{}}
type: Array

Set the MariaDB variables in this comma-separated list of \code{variable=value} pairs.

By default, the tool sets:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{wait\PYGZus{}timeout}\PYG{o}{=}10000
\end{Verbatim}

Variables specified on the command line override these defaults.  For
example, specifying \code{-{-}set-vars wait\_timeout=500} overrides the default
value of \code{10000}.

The tool prints a warning and continues if a variable cannot be set.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--share-lock}\index{--share-lock!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--share-lock}\pysigline{\bfcode{--share-lock}\code{}}
Adds the LOCK IN SHARE MODE modifier to SELECT statements.

See \href{http://dev.mysql.com/doc/en/innodb-locking-reads.html}{http://dev.mysql.com/doc/en/innodb-locking-reads.html}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--skip-foreign-key-checks}\index{--skip-foreign-key-checks!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--skip-foreign-key-checks}\pysigline{\bfcode{--skip-foreign-key-checks}\code{}}
Disables foreign key checks with SET FOREIGN\_KEY\_CHECKS=0.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--sleep}\index{--sleep!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sleep}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sleep}\code{}}
type: int

Sleep time between fetches.

Specifies how long to sleep between SELECT statements.  Default is not to
sleep at all.  Transactions are NOT committed, and the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}} file is NOT
flushed, before sleeping.  See {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}txn-size}}}} to control that.

If {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--commit-each]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}commit-each}}}} is specified, committing and flushing happens before
sleeping.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--sleep-coef}\index{--sleep-coef!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sleep-coef}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sleep-coef}\code{}}
type: float

Calculate {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sleep]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sleep}}}} as a multiple of the last SELECT time.

If this option is specified, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} will sleep for the query time of the
last SELECT multiplied by the specified coefficient.

This is a slightly more sophisticated way to throttle the SELECTs: sleep a
varying amount of time between each SELECT, depending on how long the SELECTs
are taking.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--socket}\index{--socket!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--socket}\pysigline{\bfcode{--socket}\code{}}
short form: -S; type: string

Socket file to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--source}\index{--source!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source}\pysigline{\bfcode{--source}\code{}}
type: DSN

DSN specifying the table to archive from (required).  This argument is a DSN.
See DSN OPTIONS for the syntax.  Most options control how \textbf{mariadb-archiver}
connects to MariaDB, but there are some extended DSN options in this tool's
syntax.  The D, t, and i options select a table to archive:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--source \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}my\PYGZus{}server,D\PYG{o}{=}my\PYGZus{}database,t\PYG{o}{=}my\PYGZus{}tbl
\end{Verbatim}

The a option specifies the database to set as the connection's default with USE.
If the b option is true, it disables binary logging with SQL\_LOG\_BIN.  The m
option specifies pluggable actions, which an external Perl module can provide.
The only required part is the table; other parts may be read from various
places in the environment (such as options files).

The `i' part deserves special mention.  This tells \textbf{mariadb-archiver} which index
it should scan to archive.  This appears in a FORCE INDEX or USE INDEX hint in
the SELECT statements used to fetch archivable rows.  If you don't specify
anything, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} will auto-discover a good index, preferring a \code{PRIMARY
KEY} if one exists.  In my experience this usually works well, so most of the
time you can probably just omit the `i' part.

The index is used to optimize repeated accesses to the table; \textbf{mariadb-archiver}
remembers the last row it retrieves from each SELECT statement, and uses it to
construct a WHERE clause, using the columns in the specified index, that should
allow MariaDB to start the next SELECT where the last one ended, rather than
potentially scanning from the beginning of the table with each successive
SELECT.  If you are using external plugins, please see ``EXTENDING'' for a
discussion of how they interact with ascending indexes.

The `a' and `b' options allow you to control how statements flow through the
binary log.  If you specify the `b' option, binary logging will be disabled on
the specified connection.  If you specify the `a' option, the connection will
\code{USE} the specified database, which you can use to prevent slaves from
executing the binary log events with \code{-{-}replicate-ignore-db} options.  These
two options can be used as different methods to achieve the same goal: archive
data off the master, but leave it on the slave.  For example, you can run a
purge job on the master and prevent it from happening on the slave using your
method of choice.

\textbf{WARNING}: Using a default options file (F) DSN option that defines a
socket for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to connect to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} using
that socket unless another socket for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} is specified.  This
means that \textbf{mariadb-archiver} may incorrectly connect to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} when it
is meant to connect to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.  For example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--source \PYG{n+nv}{F}\PYG{o}{=}host1.cnf,D\PYG{o}{=}db,t\PYG{o}{=}tbl --dest \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}host2
\end{Verbatim}

When \textbf{mariadb-archiver} connects to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}, host2, it will connect via the
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}, host1, socket defined in host1.cnf.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--statistics}\index{--statistics!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--statistics}\pysigline{\bfcode{--statistics}\code{}}
Collect and print timing statistics.

Causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to collect timing statistics about what it does.  These
statistics are available to the plugin specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--plugin]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}plugin}}}}

Unless you specify {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--quiet]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}quiet}}}}, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} prints the statistics when it
exits.  The statistics look like this:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Started at 2008-07-18T07:18:53, ended at 2008-07-18T07:18:53
Source: \PYG{n+nv}{D}\PYG{o}{=}db,t\PYG{o}{=}table
SELECT 4
INSERT 4
DELETE 4
Action         Count       Time        Pct
commit            10     0.1079      88.27
\PYG{k}{select             }5     0.0047       3.87
deleting           4     0.0028       2.29
inserting          4     0.0028       2.28
other              0     0.0040       3.29
\end{Verbatim}

The first two (or three) lines show times and the source and destination tables.
The next three lines show how many rows were fetched, inserted, and deleted.

The remaining lines show counts and timing.  The columns are the action, the
total number of times that action was timed, the total time it took, and the
percent of the program's total runtime.  The rows are sorted in order of
descending total time.  The last row is the rest of the time not explicitly
attributed to anything.  Actions will vary depending on command-line options.

If {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--why-quit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}why-quit}}}} is given, its behavior is changed slightly.  This option
causes it to print the reason for exiting even when it's just because there are
no more rows.

This option requires the standard Time::HiRes module, which is part of core Perl
on reasonably new Perl releases.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--stop}\index{--stop!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--stop}\pysigline{\bfcode{--stop}\code{}}
Stop running instances by creating the sentinel file.

Causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to create the sentinel file specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--sentinel]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sentinel}}}} and
exit.  This should have the effect of stopping all running instances which are
watching the same sentinel file.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--txn-size}\index{--txn-size!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--txn-size}\pysigline{\bfcode{--txn-size}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

Number of rows per transaction.

Specifies the size, in number of rows, of each transaction. Zero disables
transactions altogether.  After \textbf{mariadb-archiver} processes this many rows, it
commits both the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} if given, and flushes the
file given by {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}}.

This parameter is critical to performance.  If you are archiving from a live
server, which for example is doing heavy OLTP work, you need to choose a good
balance between transaction size and commit overhead.  Larger transactions
create the possibility of more lock contention and deadlocks, but smaller
transactions cause more frequent commit overhead, which can be significant.  To
give an idea, on a small test set I worked with while writing \textbf{mariadb-archiver}, a
value of 500 caused archiving to take about 2 seconds per 1000 rows on an
otherwise quiet MariaDB instance on my desktop machine, archiving to disk and to
another table.  Disabling transactions with a value of zero, which turns on
autocommit, dropped performance to 38 seconds per thousand rows.

If you are not archiving from or to a transactional storage engine, you may
want to disable transactions so \textbf{mariadb-archiver} doesn't try to commit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--user}\index{--user!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--user}\code{}}
short form: -u; type: string

User for login if not current user.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--version}\index{--version!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--version}\pysigline{\bfcode{--version}\code{}}
Show version and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--where}\index{--where!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--where}\pysigline{\bfcode{--where}\code{}}
type: string

WHERE clause to limit which rows to archive (required).

Specifies a WHERE clause to limit which rows are archived.  Do not include the
word WHERE.  You may need to quote the argument to prevent your shell from
interpreting it.  For example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--where \PYG{l+s+s1}{'ts \textless{} current\PYGZus{}date - interval 90 day'}
\end{Verbatim}

For safety, {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--where]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}where}}}} is required.  If you do not require a WHERE clause, use
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--where]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}where}}}} 1=1.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-archiver command line option!--why-quit}\index{--why-quit!mariadb-archiver command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--why-quit}\pysigline{\bfcode{--why-quit}\code{}}
Print reason for exiting unless rows exhausted.

Causes \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to print a message if it exits for any reason other than
running out of rows to archive.  This can be useful if you have a cron job with
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} specified, for example, and you want to be sure \textbf{mariadb-archiver} is
finishing before running out of time.

If {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--statistics]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}statistics}}}} is given, the behavior is changed slightly.  It will print
the reason for exiting even when it's just because there are no more rows.

This output prints even if {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--quiet]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}quiet}}}} is given.  That's so you can put
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} in a \code{cron} job and get an email if there's an abnormal exit.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{DSN OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-archiver:dsn-options}
These DSN options are used to create a DSN.  Each option is given like
\code{option=value}.  The options are case-sensitive, so P and p are not the
same option.  There cannot be whitespace before or after the \code{=} and
if the value contains whitespace it must be quoted.  DSN options are
comma-separated.  See the mariadb-tools manpage for full details.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
a

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

copy: no

Database to USE when executing queries.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
A

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: charset; copy: yes

Default character set.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
b

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

copy: no

If true, disable binlog with SQL\_LOG\_BIN.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
D

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: database; copy: yes

Database that contains the table.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
F

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: mysql\_read\_default\_file; copy: yes

Only read default options from the given file
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
h

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: host; copy: yes

Connect to host.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
i

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

copy: yes

Index to use.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
L

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

copy: yes

Explicitly enable LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE.

For some reason, some vendors compile libmysql without the
--enable-local-infile option, which disables the statement.  This can
lead to weird situations, like the server allowing LOCAL INFILE, but
the client throwing exceptions if it's used.

However, as long as the server allows LOAD DATA, clients can easily
re-enable it; See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/load-data-infile/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/load-data-infile/}
and \href{http://search.cpan.org/~capttofu/DBD-mysql/lib/DBD/mysql.pm}{http://search.cpan.org/\textasciitilde{}capttofu/DBD-mysql/lib/DBD/mysql.pm}.
This option does exactly that.

Although we've not found a case where turning this option leads to errors or
differing behavior, to be on the safe side, this option is not
on by default.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
m

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

copy: no

Plugin module name.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
p

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: password; copy: yes

Password to use when connecting.
If password contains commas they must be escaped with a backslash: ``exam,ple''
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
P

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: port; copy: yes

Port number to use for connection.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
S

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: mysql\_socket; copy: yes

Socket file to use for connection.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
t

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

copy: yes

Table to archive from/to.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
u

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: user; copy: yes

User for login if not current user.
\end{quote}


\subsection{EXTENDING}
\label{mariadb-archiver:extending}
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} is extensible by plugging in external Perl modules to handle some
logic and/or actions.  You can specify a module for both the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and
the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}, with the `m' part of the specification.  For example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--source \PYG{n+nv}{D}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}test1,m\PYG{o}{=}My::Module1 --dest \PYG{n+nv}{m}\PYG{o}{=}My::Module2,t\PYG{o}{=}test2
\end{Verbatim}

This will cause \textbf{mariadb-archiver} to load the My::Module1 and My::Module2 packages,
create instances of them, and then make calls to them during the archiving
process.

You can also specify a plugin with {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--plugin]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}plugin}}}}.

The module must provide this interface:

new(dbh =\textgreater{} \$dbh, db =\textgreater{} \$db\_name, tbl =\textgreater{} \$tbl\_name)
\begin{quote}

The plugin's constructor is passed a reference to the database handle, the
database name, and table name.  The plugin is created just after \textbf{mariadb-archiver}
opens the connection, and before it examines the table given in the arguments.
This gives the plugin a chance to create and populate temporary tables, or do
other setup work.
\end{quote}

before\_begin(cols =\textgreater{} @cols, allcols =\textgreater{} @allcols)
\begin{quote}

This method is called just before \textbf{mariadb-archiver} begins iterating through rows
and archiving them, but after it does all other setup work (examining table
structures, designing SQL queries, and so on).  This is the only time
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} tells the plugin column names for the rows it will pass the
plugin while archiving.

The \code{cols} argument is the column names the user requested to be archived,
either by default or by the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--columns]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}columns}}}} option.  The \code{allcols} argument is
the list of column names for every row \textbf{mariadb-archiver} will fetch from the source
table.  It may fetch more columns than the user requested, because it needs some
columns for its own use.  When subsequent plugin functions receive a row, it is
the full row containing all the extra columns, if any, added to the end.
\end{quote}

is\_archivable(row =\textgreater{} @row)
\begin{quote}

This method is called for each row to determine whether it is archivable.  This
applies only to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}.  The argument is the row itself, as an arrayref.
If the method returns true, the row will be archived; otherwise it will be
skipped.

Skipping a row adds complications for non-unique indexes.  Normally
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} uses a WHERE clause designed to target the last processed row as
the place to start the scan for the next SELECT statement.  If you have skipped
the row by returning false from is\_archivable(), \textbf{mariadb-archiver} could get into
