an infinite loop because the row still exists.  Therefore, when you specify a
plugin for the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} argument, \textbf{mariadb-archiver} will change its WHERE clause
slightly.  Instead of starting at ``greater than or equal to'' the last processed
row, it will start ``strictly greater than.''  This will work fine on unique
indexes such as primary keys, but it may skip rows (leave holes) on non-unique
indexes or when ascending only the first column of an index.

\textbf{mariadb-archiver} will change the clause in the same way if you specify
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-delete}}}}, because again an infinite loop is possible.

If you specify the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-delete}}}} option and return false from this method,
\textbf{mariadb-archiver} may not do what you want.  The row won't be archived, but it will
be deleted, since bulk deletes operate on ranges of rows and don't know which
rows the plugin selected to keep.

If you specify the {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-insert}}}} option, this method's return value will
influence whether the row is written to the temporary file for the bulk insert,
so bulk inserts will work as expected.  However, bulk inserts require bulk
deletes.
\end{quote}

before\_delete(row =\textgreater{} @row)
\begin{quote}

This method is called for each row just before it is deleted.  This applies only
to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}.  This is a good place for you to handle dependencies, such as
deleting things that are foreign-keyed to the row you are about to delete.  You
could also use this to recursively archive all dependent tables.

This plugin method is called even if {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-delete}}}} is given, but not if
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-delete}}}} is given.
\end{quote}

before\_bulk\_delete(first\_row =\textgreater{} @row, last\_row =\textgreater{} @row)
\begin{quote}

This method is called just before a bulk delete is executed.  It is similar to
the \code{before\_delete} method, except its arguments are the first and last row of
the range to be deleted.  It is called even if {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--no-delete]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}no-delete}}}} is given.
\end{quote}

before\_insert(row =\textgreater{} @row)
\begin{quote}

This method is called for each row just before it is inserted.  This applies
only to {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.  You could use this to insert the row into multiple tables,
perhaps with an ON DUPLICATE KEY UPDATE clause to build summary tables in a data
warehouse.

This method is not called if {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-insert}}}} is given.
\end{quote}

before\_bulk\_insert(first\_row =\textgreater{} @row, last\_row =\textgreater{} @row, filename =\textgreater{} bulk\_insert\_filename)
\begin{quote}

This method is called just before a bulk insert is executed.  It is similar to
the \code{before\_insert} method, except its arguments are the first and last row of
the range to be deleted.
\end{quote}

custom\_sth(row =\textgreater{} @row, sql =\textgreater{} \$sql)
\begin{quote}

This method is called just before inserting the row, but after
``before\_insert()''.  It allows the plugin to specify different \code{INSERT}
statement if desired.  The return value (if any) should be a DBI statement
handle.  The \code{sql} parameter is the SQL text used to prepare the default
\code{INSERT} statement.  This method is not called if you specify
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-insert}}}}.

If no value is returned, the default \code{INSERT} statement handle is used.

This method applies only to the plugin specified for {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}, so if your
plugin isn't doing what you expect, check that you've specified it for the
destination and not the source.
\end{quote}

custom\_sth\_bulk(first\_row =\textgreater{} @row, last\_row =\textgreater{} @row, sql =\textgreater{} \$sql, filename =\textgreater{} \$bulk\_insert\_filename)
\begin{quote}

If you've specified {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--bulk-insert]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}bulk-insert}}}}, this method is called just before the
bulk insert, but after ``before\_bulk\_insert()'', and the arguments are
different.

This method's return value etc is similar to the ``custom\_sth()'' method.
\end{quote}

after\_finish()
\begin{quote}

This method is called after \textbf{mariadb-archiver} exits the archiving loop, commits all
database handles, closes {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--file]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}file}}}}, and prints the final statistics, but
before \textbf{mariadb-archiver} runs ANALYZE or OPTIMIZE (see {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--analyze]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}analyze}}}} and
{\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--optimize]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}optimize}}}}).
\end{quote}

If you specify a plugin for both {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}, \textbf{mariadb-archiver}
constructs, calls before\_begin(), and calls after\_finish() on the two plugins in
the order {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.

\textbf{mariadb-archiver} assumes it controls transactions, and that the plugin will NOT
commit or roll back the database handle.  The database handle passed to the
plugin's constructor is the same handle \textbf{mariadb-archiver} uses itself.  Remember
that {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--source]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}source}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-archiver:cmdoption-mariadb-archiver--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} are separate handles.

A sample module might look like this:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
package My::Module;

sub new \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
   my \PYG{o}{(} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}class}, \PYGZpc{}args \PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{=} @\PYGZus{};
   \PYG{k}{return }bless\PYG{o}{(}\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}\PYGZpc{}}args, \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}class}\PYG{o}{)};
\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}

sub before\PYGZus{}begin \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
   my \PYG{o}{(} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}self}, \PYGZpc{}args \PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{=} @\PYGZus{};
   \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Save column names for later}
   \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}self}-\textgreater{}\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}cols\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}args}\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}cols\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}};
\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}

sub is\PYGZus{}archivable \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
   my \PYG{o}{(} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}self}, \PYGZpc{}args \PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{=} @\PYGZus{};
   \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Do some advanced logic with \PYGZdl{}args\PYGZob{}row\PYGZcb{}}
   \PYG{k}{return }1;
\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}

sub before\PYGZus{}delete \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Take no action}
sub before\PYGZus{}insert \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Take no action}
sub custom\PYGZus{}sth    \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Take no action}
sub after\PYGZus{}finish  \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Take no action}

1;
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-archiver:environment}
The environment variable \code{PTDEBUG} enables verbose debugging output to STDERR.
To enable debugging and capture all output to a file, run the tool like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{PTDEBUG}\PYG{o}{=}1 mariadb-archiver ... \textgreater{} FILE 2\textgreater{}\&1
\end{Verbatim}

Be careful: debugging output is voluminous and can generate several megabytes
of output.


\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}
\label{mariadb-archiver:system-requirements}
You need Perl, DBI, DBD::mysql, and some core packages that ought to be
installed in any reasonably new version of Perl.

\section{\textbf{mariadb-database-summary}}
\label{mariadb-database-summary::doc}\label{mariadb-database-summary:mariadb-database-summary}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:name}
\textbf{mariadb-database-summary} - Summarize MariaDB information nicely.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{database}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{summary} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-database-summary} conveniently summarizes the status and configuration of a
MariaDB database server so that you can learn about it at a glance.  It is not
a tuning tool or diagnosis tool.  It produces a report that is easy to diff
and can be pasted into emails without losing the formatting.  It should work
well on any modern UNIX systems.


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-database-summary} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:description}
\textbf{mariadb-database-summary} works by connecting to a MariaDB database server and querying
it for status and configuration information.  It saves these bits of data
into files in a temporary directory, and then formats them neatly with awk
and other scripting languages.

To use, simply execute it.  Optionally add a double dash and then the same
command-line options you would use to connect to MariaDB, such as the following:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-database-summary --user\PYG{o}{=}root
\end{Verbatim}

The tool interacts minimally with the server upon which it runs.  It assumes
that you'll run it on the same server you're inspecting, and therefore it
assumes that it will be able to find the my.cnf configuration file, for example.
However, it should degrade gracefully if this is not the case.  Note, however,
that its output does not indicate which information comes from the MariaDB
database and which comes from the host operating system, so it is possible for
confusing output to be generated if you run the tool on one server and connect
to a MariaDB database server running on another server.


\subsection{OUTPUT}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:output}
Many of the outputs from this tool are deliberately rounded to show their
magnitude but not the exact detail.  This is called fuzzy-rounding. The idea
is that it does not matter whether a server is running 918 queries per second
or 921 queries per second; such a small variation is insignificant, and only
makes the output hard to compare to other servers.  Fuzzy-rounding rounds in
larger increments as the input grows.  It begins by rounding to the nearest 5,
then the nearest 10, nearest 25, and then repeats by a factor of 10 larger
(50, 100, 250), and so on, as the input grows.

This section shows selected counters from two snapshots of SHOW GLOBAL STATUS,
gathered approximately 10 seconds apart and fuzzy-rounded. It includes only
items that are incrementing counters; it does not include absolute numbers such
as the Threads\_running status variable, which represents a current value, rather
than an accumulated number over time.

The first column is the variable name, and the second column is the counter from
the first snapshot divided by 86400 (the number of seconds in a day), so you can
see the magnitude of the counter's change per day. 86400 fuzzy-rounds to 90000,
so the Uptime counter should always be about 90000.

The third column is the value from the first snapshot, divided by Uptime and
then fuzzy-rounded, so it represents approximately how quickly the counter is
growing per-second over the uptime of the server.

The third column is the incremental difference from the first and second
snapshot, divided by the difference in uptime and then fuzzy-rounded. Therefore,
it shows how quickly the counter is growing per second at the time the report
was generated.

databases. It is generated by running \code{mariadb-dump -{-}no-data}, not by querying
the INFORMATION\_SCHEMA, which can freeze a busy server.

The first sub-report in the section is the count of objects by type in each
database: tables, views, and so on. The second one shows how many tables use
various storage engines in each database. The third sub-report shows the number
of each type of indexes in each database.

The last section shows the number of columns of various data types in each
database. For compact display, the column headers are formatted vertically, so
you need to read downwards from the top. In this example, the first column is
\code{char} and the second column is \code{timestamp}. This example is truncated so it
does not wrap on a terminal.

All of the numbers in this portion of the output are exact, not fuzzy-rounded.

This section shows a pretty-printed version of the my.cnf file, with comments
removed and with whitespace added to align things for easy reading. The tool
tries to detect the my.cnf file by looking at the output of ps, and if it does
not find the location of the file there, it tries common locations until it
finds a file. Note that this file might not actually correspond with the server
from which the report was generated. This can happen when the tool isn't run on
the same server it's reporting on, or when detecting the location of the
configuration file fails.


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:options}
All options after -- are passed to \code{mariadb}.
\index{mariadb-database-summary command line option!--all-databases}\index{--all-databases!mariadb-database-summary command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-database-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-database-summary--all-databases}\pysigline{\bfcode{--all-databases}\code{}}
mariadb-dump and summarize all databases.  See {\hyperref[mariadb-database-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-database-summary--databases]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}databases}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-database-summary command line option!--ask-pass}\index{--ask-pass!mariadb-database-summary command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-database-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-database-summary--ask-pass}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ask-pass}\code{}}
Prompt for a password when connecting to MariaDB.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-database-summary command line option!--config}\index{--config!mariadb-database-summary command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-database-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-database-summary--config}\pysigline{\bfcode{--config}\code{}}
type: string

Read this comma-separated list of config files.  If specified, this must be the
first option on the command line.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-database-summary command line option!--databases}\index{--databases!mariadb-database-summary command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-database-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-database-summary--databases}\pysigline{\bfcode{--databases}\code{}}
type: string

mariadb-dump and summarize this comma-separated list of databases.  Specify
{\hyperref[mariadb-database-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-database-summary--all-databases]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}all-databases}}}} instead if you want to dump and summary all databases.

\end{fulllineitems}

Only read mariadb options from the given file.  You must give an absolute
pathname.

\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:environment}
This tool does not use any environment variables.


\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}
\label{mariadb-database-summary:system-requirements}
This tool requires Bash v3 or newer, Perl 5.8 or newer, and binutils.
These are generally already provided by most distributions.
On BSD systems, it may require a mounted procfs.

\section{\textbf{mariadb-index-checker}}
\label{mariadb-index-checker:mariadb-index-checker}\label{mariadb-index-checker::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-index-checker:name}
\textbf{mariadb-index-checker} - Find duplicate indexes and foreign keys on MariaDB tables.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-index-checker:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-index-checker:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{index}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{checker} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{DSN}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-index-checker} examines MariaDB tables for duplicate or redundant
indexes and foreign keys.  Connection options are read from MariaDB option files.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-index-checker --host host1
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-index-checker:risks}
MariaDB Tools is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-index-checker:description}
This program examines the output of SHOW CREATE TABLE on MariaDB tables, and if
it finds indexes that cover the same columns as another index in the same
order, or cover an exact leftmost prefix of another index, it prints out
the suspicious indexes.  By default, indexes must be of the same type, so a
BTREE index is not a duplicate of a FULLTEXT index, even if they have the same
columns.  You can override this.

It also looks for duplicate foreign keys.  A duplicate foreign key covers the
same columns as another in the same table, and references the same parent
table.

The output ends with a short summary that includes an estimate of the total
size, in bytes, that the duplicate indexes are using. This is calculated by
multiplying the index length by the number of rows in their respective tables.


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-index-checker:options}
This tool accepts additional command-line arguments.  Refer to the
``SYNOPSIS'' and usage information for details.
\index{mariadb-index-checker command line option!--all-structs}\index{--all-structs!mariadb-index-checker command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-index-checker:cmdoption-mariadb-index-checker--all-structs}\pysigline{\bfcode{--all-structs}\code{}}
Compare indexes with different structs (BTREE, HASH, etc).

By default this is disabled, because a BTREE index that covers the same columns
as a FULLTEXT index is not really a duplicate, for example.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-index-checker command line option!--ask-pass}\index{--ask-pass!mariadb-index-checker command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-index-checker:cmdoption-mariadb-index-checker--ask-pass}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ask-pass}\code{}}
Prompt for a password when connecting to MariaDB.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-index-checker command line option!--charset}\index{--charset!mariadb-index-checker command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-index-checker:cmdoption-mariadb-index-checker--charset}\pysigline{\bfcode{--charset}\code{}}
short form: -A; type: string

Default character set.  If the value is utf8, sets Perl's binmode on
STDOUT to utf8, passes the mysql\_enable\_utf8 option to DBD::mysql, and runs SET
NAMES UTF8 after connecting to MariaDB.  Any other value sets binmode on STDOUT
without the utf8 layer, and runs SET NAMES after connecting to MariaDB.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-index-checker command line option!--{[}no{]}clustered}\index{--{[}no{]}clustered!mariadb-index-checker command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-index-checker:cmdoption-mariadb-index-checker--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}clustered}}
default: yes

PK columns appended to secondary key is duplicate.

Detects when a suffix of a secondary key is a leftmost prefix of the primary
key, and treats it as a duplicate key.  Only detects this condition on storage
engines whose primary keys are clustered (currently InnoDB and solidDB).

Clustered storage engines append the primary key columns to the leaf nodes of
all secondary keys anyway, so you might consider it redundant to have them
appear in the internal nodes as well.  Of course, you may also want them in the
internal nodes, because just having them at the leaf nodes won't help for some
queries.  It does help for covering index queries, however.

Here's an example of a key that is considered redundant with this option:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
PRIMARY KEY  \PYG{o}{(}\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}a\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}\PYG{o}{)}
KEY \PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}b\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`} \PYG{o}{(}\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}b\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`},\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}a\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

The use of such indexes is rather subtle.  For example, suppose you have the
following query:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT ... WHERE \PYG{n+nv}{b}\PYG{o}{=}1 ORDER BY a;
\end{Verbatim}

This query will do a filesort if we remove the index on \code{b,a}.  But if we
shorten the index on \code{b,a} to just \code{b} and also remove the ORDER BY, the query
should return the same results.

The tool suggests shortening duplicate clustered keys by dropping the key
and re-adding it without the primary key prefix.  The shortened clustered
key may still duplicate another key, but the tool cannot currently detect
when this happens without being ran a second time to re-check the newly
shortened clustered keys.  Therefore, if you shorten any duplicate clustered
keys, you should run the tool again.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-index-checker command line option!--config}\index{--config!mariadb-index-checker command line option}

\section{\textbf{mariadb-iostat}}
\label{mariadb-iostat::doc}\label{mariadb-iostat:mariadb-iostat}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-iostat:name}
\textbf{mariadb-iostat} - An interactive I/O monitoring tool for GNU/Linux.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-iostat:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-iostat:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{iostat} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{FILES}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-iostat} prints disk I/O statistics for GNU/Linux.  It is somewhat similar
to iostat, but it is interactive and more detailed.  It can analyze samples
gathered from another machine.


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-iostat:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-iostat} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-iostat:description}
The \textbf{mariadb-iostat} tool is similar to iostat, but has some advantages. It prints
read and write statistics separately, and has more columns. It is menu-driven
and interactive, with several different ways to aggregate the data. It
integrates well with the mariadb-stat tool. It also does the ``right thing'' by
default, such as hiding disks that are idle.  These properties make it very
convenient for quickly drilling down into I/O performance and inspecting disk
behavior.

This program works in two modes. The default is to collect samples of
\emph{/proc/diskstats} and print out the formatted statistics at intervals. The other
mode is to process a file that contains saved samples of \emph{/proc/diskstats}; there
is a shell script later in this documentation that shows how to collect such a
file.

In both cases, the tool is interactively controlled by keystrokes, so you can
redisplay and slice the data flexibly and easily.  It loops forever, until you
exit with the `q' key.  If you press the `?' key, you will bring up the
interactive help menu that shows which keys control the program.

When the program is gathering samples of \emph{/proc/diskstats} and refreshing its
display, it prints information about the newest sample each time it refreshes.
When it is operating on a file of saved samples, it redraws the entire file's
contents every time you change an option.

The program doesn't print information about every block device on the system. It
hides devices that it has never observed to have any activity.  You can enable
and disable this by pressing the `i' key.


\subsection{OUTPUT}
\label{mariadb-iostat:output}
In the rest of this documentation, we will try to clarify the distinction
between block devices (/dev/sda1, for example), which the kernel presents to the
application via a filesystem, versus the (usually) physical device underneath
the block device, which could be a disk, a RAID controller, and so on.  We will
sometimes refer to logical I/O operations, which occur at the block device,
versus physical I/Os which are performed on the underlying device.  When we
refer to the queue, we are speaking of the queue associated with the block
device, which holds requests until they're issued to the physical device.

The program's output looks like the following sample, which is too wide for this
manual page, so we have formatted it as several samples with line breaks:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}ts device rd\PYGZus{}s rd\PYGZus{}avkb rd\PYGZus{}mb\PYGZus{}s rd\PYGZus{}mrg rd\PYGZus{}cnc   rd\PYGZus{}rt}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}6\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} sda     0.9     4.2     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    17.9
\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}6\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} sdb     0.4     4.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    26.1
\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}6\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} dm-0    0.0     4.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    13.5
\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}6\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} dm-1    0.8     4.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    16.0

    ...    wr\PYGZus{}s wr\PYGZus{}avkb wr\PYGZus{}mb\PYGZus{}s wr\PYGZus{}mrg wr\PYGZus{}cnc   wr\PYGZus{}rt
    ...    99.7     6.2     0.6    35\PYGZpc{}    3.7    23.7
    ...    14.5    15.8     0.2    75\PYGZpc{}    0.5     9.2
    ...     1.0     4.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0     2.3
    ...   117.7     4.0     0.5     0\PYGZpc{}    4.1    35.1

    ...              busy in\PYGZus{}prg    io\PYGZus{}s  qtime stime
    ...                6\PYGZpc{}      0   100.6   23.3   0.4
    ...                4\PYGZpc{}      0    14.9    8.6   0.6
    ...                0\PYGZpc{}      0     1.1    1.5   1.2
    ...                5\PYGZpc{}      0   118.5   34.5   0.4
\end{Verbatim}

The columns are as follows:

\#ts
\begin{quote}

This column's contents vary depending on the tool's aggregation mode.  In the
default mode, when each line contains information about a single disk but
possibly aggregates across several samples from that disk, this column shows the
number of samples that were included into the line of output, in \{curly braces\}.
In the example shown, each line of output aggregates \{10\} samples of
\emph{/proc/diskstats}.

In the ``all'' group-by mode, this column shows timestamp offsets, relative to the
time the tool began aggregating or the timestamp of the previous lines printed,
depending on the mode.  The output can be confusing to explain, but it's rather
intuitive when you see the lines appearing on your screen periodically.

Similarly, in ``sample'' group-by mode, the number indicates the total time span
that is grouped into each sample.

If you specify {\hyperref[mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--show-timestamps]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}show-timestamps}}}}, this field instead shows the timestamp at
which the sample was taken; if multiple timestamps are present in a single line
of output, then the first timestamp is used.
\end{quote}

device
\begin{quote}

The device name.  If there is more than one device, then instead the number
of devices aggregated into the line is shown, in \{curly braces\}.
\end{quote}

rd\_s
\begin{quote}

The average number of reads per second.  This is the number of I/O requests that
were sent to the underlying device.  This usually is a smaller number than the
number of logical IO requests made by applications.  More requests might have
been queued to the block device, but some of them usually are merged before
being sent to the disk.

This field is computed from the contents of \emph{/proc/diskstats} as follows.  See
``KERNEL DOCUMENTATION'' below for the meaning of the field numbers:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
delta\PYG{o}{[}field1\PYG{o}{]} / delta\PYG{o}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{time}\PYG{o}{]}
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

rd\_avkb
\begin{quote}

The average size of the reads, in kilobytes.  This field is computed as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
2 * delta\PYG{o}{[}field3\PYG{o}{]} / delta\PYG{o}{[}field1\PYG{o}{]}
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

rd\_mb\_s
\begin{quote}

The average number of megabytes read per second.  Computed as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
2 * delta\PYG{o}{[}field3\PYG{o}{]} / delta\PYG{o}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{time}\PYG{o}{]}
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

rd\_mrg
\begin{quote}

The percentage of read requests that were merged together in the queue scheduler
before being sent to the physical device.  The field is computed as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
100 * delta\PYG{o}{[}field2\PYG{o}{]} / \PYG{o}{(}delta\PYG{o}{[}field2\PYG{o}{]} + delta\PYG{o}{[}field1\PYG{o}{]}\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

rd\_cnc
\begin{quote}

The average concurrency of the read operations, as computed by Little's Law.
This is the end-to-end concurrency on the block device, not the underlying
disk's concurrency. It includes time spent in the queue.  The field is computed
as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
delta\PYG{o}{[}field4\PYG{o}{]} / delta\PYG{o}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{time}\PYG{o}{]} / 1000 / devices-in-group
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

rd\_rt
\begin{quote}

The average response time of the read operations, in milliseconds.  This is the
end-to-end response time, including time spent in the queue.  It is the response
time that the application making I/O requests sees, not the response time of the
physical disk underlying the block device.  It is computed as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
delta\PYG{o}{[}field4\PYG{o}{]} / \PYG{o}{(}delta\PYG{o}{[}field1\PYG{o}{]} + delta\PYG{o}{[}field2\PYG{o}{]}\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

wr\_s, wr\_avkb, wr\_mb\_s, wr\_mrg, wr\_cnc, wr\_rt
\begin{quote}

These columns show write activity, and they match the corresponding columns for
read activity.
\end{quote}

busy
\begin{quote}

The fraction of wall-clock time that the device had at least one request in
progress; this is what iostat calls \%util, and indeed it is utilization,
depending on how you define utilization, but that is sometimes ambiguous in
common parlance.  It may also be called the residence time; the time during
which at least one request was resident in the system.  It is computed as
follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
100 * delta\PYG{o}{[}field10\PYG{o}{]} / \PYG{o}{(}1000 * delta\PYG{o}{[}\PYG{n+nb}{time}\PYG{o}{]}\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

This field cannot exceed 100\% unless there is a rounding error, but it is a
common mistake to think that a device that's busy all the time is saturated.  A
device such as a RAID volume should support concurrency higher than 1, and
solid-state drives can support very high concurrency.  Concurrency can grow
without bound, and is a more reliable indicator of how loaded the device really
is.
\end{quote}

in\_prg
\begin{quote}

The number of requests that were in progress.  Unlike the read and write
concurrencies, which are averages that are generated from reliable numbers, this
number is an instantaneous sample, and you can see that it might represent a
spike of requests, rather than the true long-term average.  If this number is
large, it essentially means that the device is heavily loaded.  It is computed
as follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
field9
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

ios\_s
\begin{quote}

The average throughput of the physical device, in I/O operations per second
(IOPS).  This column shows the total IOPS the underlying device is handling.  It
is the sum of rd\_s and wr\_s.
\end{quote}

qtime
\begin{quote}

The average queue time; that is, time a request spends in the device scheduler
queue before being sent to the physical device.  This is an average over reads
and writes.

It is computed in a slightly complex way: the average response time seen by the
application, minus the average service time (see the description of the next
column).  This is derived from the queueing theory formula for response time, R
= W + S: response time = queue time + service time.  This is solved for W, of
course, to give W = R - S.  The computation follows:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
delta\PYG{o}{[}field11\PYG{o}{]} / \PYG{o}{(}delta\PYG{o}{[}field1, 2, 5, 6\PYG{o}{]} + delta\PYG{o}{[}field9\PYG{o}{]}\PYG{o}{)}
   - delta\PYG{o}{[}field10\PYG{o}{]} / delta\PYG{o}{[}field1, 2, 5, 6\PYG{o}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

See the description for \code{stime} for more details and cautions.
\end{quote}

stime
\begin{quote}

The average service time; that is, the time elapsed while the physical device
processes the request, after the request finishes waiting in the queue.  This is
an average over reads and writes.  It is computed from the queueing theory
utilization formula, U = SX, solved for S.  This means that utilization divided
by throughput gives service time:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
delta\PYG{o}{[}field10\PYG{o}{]} / \PYG{o}{(}delta\PYG{o}{[}field1, 2, 5, 6\PYG{o}{]}\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

Note, however, that there can be some kernel bugs that cause field 9 in
\emph{/proc/diskstats} to become negative, and this can cause field 10 to be wrong,
thus making the service time computation not wholly trustworthy.

Note that in the above formula we use utilization very specifically. It is a
duration, not a percentage.

You can compare the stime and qtime columns to see whether the response time for
reads and writes is spent in the queue or on the physical device.  However, you
cannot see the difference between reads and writes.  Changing the block device
scheduler algorithm might improve queue time greatly.  The default algorithm,
cfq, is very bad for servers, and should only be used on laptops and
workstations that perform tasks such as working with spreadsheets and surfing
the Internet.
\end{quote}

If you are used to using iostat, you might wonder where you can find the same
information in \textbf{mariadb-iostat}.  Here are two samples of output from both tools on
the same machine at the same time, for \emph{/dev/sda}, wrapped to fit:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
     \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}ts dev rd\PYGZus{}s rd\PYGZus{}avkb rd\PYGZus{}mb\PYGZus{}s rd\PYGZus{}mrg rd\PYGZus{}cnc   rd\PYGZus{}rt}
08:50:10 sda  0.0     0.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0     0.0
08:50:20 sda  0.4     4.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    15.5
08:50:30 sda  2.1     4.4     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    21.1
08:50:40 sda  2.4     4.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    15.4
08:50:50 sda  0.1     4.0     0.0     0\PYGZpc{}    0.0    33.0

             wr\PYGZus{}s wr\PYGZus{}avkb wr\PYGZus{}mb\PYGZus{}s wr\PYGZus{}mrg wr\PYGZus{}cnc   wr\PYGZus{}rt
              7.7    25.5     0.2    84\PYGZpc{}    0.0     0.3
             49.6     6.8     0.3    41\PYGZpc{}    2.4    28.8
            210.1     5.6     1.1    28\PYGZpc{}    7.4    25.2
            297.1     5.4     1.6    26\PYGZpc{}   11.4    28.3
             11.9    11.7     0.1    66\PYGZpc{}    0.2     4.9

                     busy  in\PYGZus{}prg   io\PYGZus{}s  qtime   stime
                       1\PYGZpc{}       0    7.7    0.1     0.2
                       6\PYGZpc{}       0   50.0   28.1     0.7
                      12\PYGZpc{}       0  212.2   24.8     0.4
                      16\PYGZpc{}       0  299.5   27.8     0.4
                       1\PYGZpc{}       0   12.0    4.7     0.3

         Dev rrqm/s  wrqm/s   r/s    w/s  rMB/s  wMB/s
08:50:10 sda   0.00   41.40  0.00   7.70   0.00   0.19
08:50:20 sda   0.00   34.70  0.40  49.60   0.00   0.33
08:50:30 sda   0.00   83.30  2.10 210.10   0.01   1.15
08:50:40 sda   0.00  105.10  2.40 297.90   0.01   1.58

                avgrq-sz avgqu-sz  await  svctm  \PYGZpc{}util
                   51.01     0.02   2.04   1.25   0.96
                   13.55     2.44  48.76   1.16   5.79

                   10.81    11.40  37.96   0.53  15.97
                   24.07     0.17  15.60   0.87   0.97
\end{Verbatim}

The correspondence between the columns is not one-to-one.  In particular:

rrqm/s, wrqm/s
\begin{quote}

These columns in iostat are replaced by rd\_mrg and wr\_mrg in \textbf{mariadb-iostat}.
\end{quote}

avgrq-sz
\begin{quote}

This column is in sectors in iostat, and is a combination of reads and writes.
The \textbf{mariadb-iostat} output breaks these out separately and shows them in kB.  You
can derive it via a weighted average of rd\_avkb and wr\_avkb in \textbf{mariadb-iostat}, and
then multiply by 2 to get sectors (each sector is 512 bytes).
\end{quote}

avgqu-sz
\begin{quote}

This column really represents concurrency at the block device scheduler.  The
\textbf{mariadb-iostat} output shows concurrency for reads and writes separately: rd\_cnc
and wr\_cnc.
\end{quote}

await
\begin{quote}

This column is the average response time from the beginning to the end of a
request to the block device, including queue time and service time, and is not
shown in \textbf{mariadb-iostat}.  Instead, \textbf{mariadb-iostat} shows individual response times at
the disk level for reads and writes (rd\_rt and wr\_rt), as well as queue time
versus service time for reads and writes in aggregate.
\end{quote}

svctm
\begin{quote}

This column is the average service time at the disk, and is shown as stime in
\textbf{mariadb-iostat}.
\end{quote}

\%util
\begin{quote}

This column is called busy in \textbf{mariadb-iostat}.  Utilization is usually defined as
the portion of time during which there was at least one active request, not as a
percentage, which is why we chose to avoid this confusing term.
\end{quote}


\subsection{COLLECTING DATA}
\label{mariadb-iostat:collecting-data}
It is straightforward to gather a sample of data for this tool.  Files should
have this format, with a timestamp line preceding each sample of statistics:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
TS \textless{}timestamp\textgreater{}
\textless{}contents of /proc/diskstats\textgreater{}
TS \textless{}timestamp\textgreater{}
\textless{}contents of /proc/diskstats\textgreater{}
... et cetera
\end{Verbatim}

You can simply use \textbf{mariadb-iostat} with {\hyperref[mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--save-samples]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}save-samples}}}} to collect this data
for you.  If you wish to capture samples as part of some other tool, and use
\textbf{mariadb-iostat} to analyze them, you can include a snippet of shell script such as
the following:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{INTERVAL}\PYG{o}{=}1
\PYG{k}{while }\PYG{n+nb}{true}; \PYG{k}{do}
\PYG{k}{   }\PYG{n+nv}{sleep}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{k}{\PYGZdl{}(}date +\PYGZpc{}s.\PYGZpc{}N \textbar{} awk \PYG{l+s+s2}{"\PYGZob{}print \PYGZdl{}INTERVAL - (\PYGZbs{}\PYGZdl{}1 \PYGZpc{} \PYGZdl{}INTERVAL)\PYGZcb{}"}\PYG{k}{)}
   sleep \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}sleep}
   date +\PYG{l+s+s2}{"TS \PYGZpc{}s.\PYGZpc{}N \PYGZpc{}F \PYGZpc{}T"} \textgreater{}\textgreater{} diskstats-samples.txt
   cat /proc/diskstats \textgreater{}\textgreater{} diskstats-samples.txt
\PYG{k}{done}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{KERNEL DOCUMENTATION}
\label{mariadb-iostat:kernel-documentation}
This documentation supplements \href{http://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/iostats.txt}{the official
documentation} on the
contents of \emph{/proc/diskstats}.  That documentation can sometimes be difficult
to understand for those who are not familiar with Linux kernel internals.  The
contents of \emph{/proc/diskstats} are generated by the \code{diskstats\_show()} function
in the kernel source file \emph{block/genhd.c}.

Here is a sample of \emph{/proc/diskstats} on a recent kernel.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
8 1 sda1 426 243 3386 2056 3 0 18 87 0 2135 2142
\end{Verbatim}

The fields in this sample are as follows.  The first three fields are the major
and minor device numbers (8, 1), and the device name (sda1). They are followed
by 11 fields of statistics:
\begin{enumerate}
\item {} 
The number of reads completed.  This is the number of physical reads done by the
underlying disk, not the number of reads that applications made from the block
device.  This means that 426 actual reads have completed successfully to the
disk on which \emph{/dev/sda1} resides.  Reads are not counted until they complete.

\item {} 
The number of reads merged because they were adjacent.  In the sample, 243 reads
were merged. This means that \emph{/dev/sda1} actually received 869 logical reads,
but sent only 426 physical reads to the underlying physical device.

\item {} 
The number of sectors read successfully.  The 426 physical reads to the disk
read 3386 sectors.  Sectors are 512 bytes, so a total of about 1.65MB have been
read from \emph{/dev/sda1}.

\item {} 
The number of milliseconds spent reading.  This counts only reads that have
completed, not reads that are in progress.  It counts the time spent from when
requests are placed on the queue until they complete, not the time that the
underlying disk spends servicing the requests. That is, it measures the total
response time seen by applications, not disk response times.

\item {} 
Ditto for field 1, but for writes.

\item {} 
Ditto for field 2, but for writes.

\item {} 
Ditto for field 3, but for writes.

\item {} 
Ditto for field 4, but for writes.

\item {} 
The number of I/Os currently in progress, that is, they've been scheduled by the
queue scheduler and issued to the disk (submitted to the underlying disk's
queue), but not yet completed.  There are bugs in some kernels that cause this
number, and thus fields 10 and 11, to be wrong sometimes.

\item {} 
The total number of milliseconds spent doing I/Os.  This is \textbf{not} the total
response time seen by the applications; it is the total amount of time during
which at least one I/O was in progress.  If one I/O is issued at time 100,
another comes in at 101, and both of them complete at 102, then this field
increments by 2, not 3.

\item {} 
This field counts the total response time of all I/Os.  In contrast to field 10,
it counts double when two I/Os overlap.  In our previous example, this field
would increment by 3, not 2.

\end{enumerate}


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-iostat:options}
This tool accepts additional command-line arguments.  Refer to the
``SYNOPSIS'' and usage information for details.
\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--columns-regex}\index{--columns-regex!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--columns-regex}\pysigline{\bfcode{--columns-regex}\code{}}
type: string; default: .

Print columns that match this Perl regex.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--config}\index{--config!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--config}\pysigline{\bfcode{--config}\code{}}
type: Array

Read this comma-separated list of config files; if specified, this must be the
first option on the command line.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--devices-regex}\index{--devices-regex!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--devices-regex}\pysigline{\bfcode{--devices-regex}\code{}}
type: string

Print devices that match this Perl regex.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--group-by}\index{--group-by!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--group-by}\pysigline{\bfcode{--group-by}\code{}}
type: string; default: all

Group-by mode: disk, sample, or all.  In \textbf{disk} mode, each line of output
shows one disk device, with the statistics computed since the tool started.  In
\textbf{sample} mode, each line of output shows one sample of statistics, with all
disks averaged together.  In \textbf{all} mode, each line of output shows one sample
and one disk device.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--headers}\index{--headers!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--headers}\pysigline{\bfcode{--headers}\code{}}
type: Hash; default: group,scroll

If \code{group} is present, each sample will be separated by a blank line, unless
the sample is only one line.  If \code{scroll} is present, the tool will print the
headers as often as needed to prevent them from scrolling out of view. Note that
you can press the space bar, or the enter key, to reprint headers at will.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--help}\index{--help!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--help}\pysigline{\bfcode{--help}\code{}}
Show help and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--interval}\index{--interval!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--interval}\pysigline{\bfcode{--interval}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

When in interactive mode, wait N seconds before printing to the screen.
Also, how often the tool should sample \emph{/proc/diskstats}.

The tool attempts to gather statistics exactly on even intervals of clock time.
That is, if you specify a 5-second interval, it will try to capture samples at
12:00:00, 12:00:05, and so on; it will not gather at 12:00:01, 12:00:06 and so
forth.

This can lead to slightly odd delays in some circumstances, because the tool
waits one full cycle before printing out the first set of lines. (Unlike iostat
and vmstat, \textbf{mariadb-iostat} does not start with a line representing the averages
since the computer was booted.)  Therefore, the rule has an exception to avoid
very long delays.  Suppose you specify a 10-second interval, but you start the
tool at 12:00:00.01.  The tool might wait until 12:00:20 to print its first
lines of output, and in the intervening 19.99 seconds, it would appear to do
nothing.

To alleviate this, the tool waits until the next even interval of time to
gather, unless more than 20\% of that interval remains.  This means the tool will
never wait more than 120\% of the sampling interval to produce output, e.g if you
start the tool at 12:00:53 with a 10-second sampling interval, then the first
sample will be only 7 seconds long, not 10 seconds.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--iterations}\index{--iterations!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--iterations}\pysigline{\bfcode{--iterations}\code{}}
type: int

When in interactive mode, stop after N samples.  Run forever by default.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--sample-time}\index{--sample-time!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--sample-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sample-time}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

In --group-by sample mode, include N seconds of samples per group.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--save-samples}\index{--save-samples!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--save-samples}\pysigline{\bfcode{--save-samples}\code{}}
type: string

File to save diskstats samples in; these can be used for later analysis.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--show-inactive}\index{--show-inactive!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--show-inactive}\pysigline{\bfcode{--show-inactive}\code{}}
Show inactive devices.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--show-timestamps}\index{--show-timestamps!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--show-timestamps}\pysigline{\bfcode{--show-timestamps}\code{}}
Show a `HH:MM:SS' timestamp in the \code{\#ts} column.  If multiple timestamps are
aggregated into one line, the first timestamp is shown.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-iostat command line option!--version}\index{--version!mariadb-iostat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-iostat:cmdoption-mariadb-iostat--version}\pysigline{\bfcode{--version}\code{}}
Show version and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-iostat:environment}
The environment variable \code{PTDEBUG} enables verbose debugging output to STDERR.
To enable debugging and capture all output to a file, run the tool like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{PTDEBUG}\PYG{o}{=}1 mariadb-iostat ... \textgreater{} FILE 2\textgreater{}\&1
\end{Verbatim}

Be careful: debugging output is voluminous and can generate several megabytes
of output.


\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}
\label{mariadb-iostat:system-requirements}
This tool requires Perl v5.8.0 or newer and the \emph{/proc} filesystem, unless
reading from files.

\section{\textbf{mariadb-kill}}
\label{mariadb-kill::doc}\label{mariadb-kill:mariadb-kill}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-kill:name}
\textbf{mariadb-kill} - Kill MariaDB queries that match certain criteria.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-kill:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-kill:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{kill} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{DSN}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-kill} kills MariaDB connections.  \textbf{mariadb-kill} connects to MariaDB and gets queries
from SHOW PROCESSLIST if no FILE is given.  Else, it reads queries from one
or more FILE which contains the output of SHOW PROCESSLIST.  If FILE is -,
\textbf{mariadb-kill} reads from STDIN.

Kill queries running longer than 60s:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-kill --busy-time 60 --kill
\end{Verbatim}

Print, do not kill, queries running longer than 60s:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-kill --busy-time 60 --print
\end{Verbatim}

Check for sleeping processes and kill them all every 10s:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-kill --match-command Sleep --kill --victims all --interval 10
\end{Verbatim}

Print all login processes:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-kill --match-state login --print --victims all
\end{Verbatim}

See which queries in the processlist right now would match:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb -e \PYG{l+s+s2}{"SHOW PROCESSLIST"} \textgreater{} proclist.txt
mariadb-kill --test-matching proclist.txt --busy-time 60 --print
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-kill:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-kill} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-kill:description}
\textbf{mariadb-kill} captures queries from SHOW PROCESSLIST, filters them, and then either
kills or prints them.  This is also known as a ``slow query sniper'' in some
circles.  The idea is to watch for queries that might be consuming too many
resources, and kill them.

For brevity, we talk about killing queries, but they may just be printed
(or some other future action) depending on what options are given.

Normally \textbf{mariadb-kill} connects to MariaDB to get queries from SHOW PROCESSLIST.
Alternatively, it can read SHOW PROCESSLIST output from files.  In this case,
\textbf{mariadb-kill} does not connect to MariaDB and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} has no effect.  You should
use {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}} instead when reading files.  The ability to read a file
with {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--test-matching]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}test-matching}}}} allows you to capture SHOW PROCESSLIST and test it
later with \textbf{mariadb-kill} to make sure that your matches kill the proper queries.
There are a lot of special rules to follow, such as ``don't kill replication
threads,'' so be careful not to kill something important!

Two important options to know are {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}}.
First, whereas most match/filter options match their corresponding value from
SHOW PROCESSLIST (e.g. {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-command}}}} matches a query's Command value),
the Time value is matched by {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}}.  See also {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}}.

Second, {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}} controls which matching queries from each class are
killed.  By default, the matching query with the highest Time value is killed
(the oldest query).  See the next section, ``GROUP, MATCH AND KILL'',
for more details.

Usually you need to specify at least one \code{-{-}match} option, else no
queries will match.  Or, you can specify {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-all]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-all}}}} to match all queries
that aren't ignored by an \code{-{-}ignore} option.


\subsection{GROUP, MATCH AND KILL}
\label{mariadb-kill:group-match-and-kill}
Queries pass through several steps to determine which exactly will be killed
(or printed--whatever action is specified).  Understanding these steps will
help you match precisely the queries you want.

The first step is grouping queries into classes.  The {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} option
controls grouping.  By default, this option has no value so all queries are
grouped into one default class.  All types of matching and filtering
(the next step) are applied per-class.  Therefore, you may need to group
queries in order to match/filter some classes but not others.

The second step is matching.  Matching implies filtering since if a query
doesn't match some criteria, it is removed from its class.
Matching happens for each class.  First, queries are filtered from their
class by the various \code{Query Matches} options like {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-user]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-user}}}}.
Then, entire classes are filtered by the various \code{Class Matches} options
like {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--query-count]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}query-count}}}}.

The third step is victim selection, that is, which matching queries in each
class to kill.  This is controlled by the {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}} option.  Although
many queries in a class may match, you may only want to kill the oldest
query, or all queries, etc.

The forth and final step is to take some action on all matching queries
from all classes.  The \code{Actions} options specify which actions will be
taken.  At this step, there are no more classes, just a single list of
queries to kill, print, etc.

\textbf{mariadb-kill} will kill all the queries matching ANY of the specified criteria (logical OR).
For example, using:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--busy-time 114 --match-command \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Query\textbar{}Execute'}
\end{Verbatim}

will kill all queries having busy-time \textgreater{} 114 \code{OR} where the command is \code{Query} or \code{Execute}

If you want to kill only the queries where \code{busy-time {}`{}` 114\textgreater{} {}`{}`AND} the command is Query or
Execute, you need to use ``--kill-busy-commands:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--busy-time 114 --kill-busy-commands \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Query\textbar{}Execute'}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{OUTPUT}
\label{mariadb-kill:output}
If only {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} is given, then there is no output.  If only
{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}} is given, then a timestamped KILL statement if printed
for every query that would have been killed, like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 2009-07-15T15:04:01 KILL 8 (Query 42 sec) SELECT * FROM huge\PYGZus{}table}
\end{Verbatim}

The line shows a timestamp, the query's Id (8), its Time (42 sec) and its
Info (usually the query SQL).

If both {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}} are given, then matching queries are
killed and a line for each like the one above is printed.

Any command executed by {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--execute-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}execute-command}}}} is responsible for its own
output and logging.  After being executed, \textbf{mariadb-kill} has no control or interaction
with the command.


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-kill:options}
Specify at least one of {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill-query]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill-query}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--execute-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}execute-command}}}} or {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--stop]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}stop}}}}.

{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--any-busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}any-busy-time}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--each-busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}each-busy-time}}}} are mutually exclusive.

{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill-query]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill-query}}}} are mutually exclusive.

{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--daemonize]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}daemonize}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--test-matching]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}test-matching}}}} are mutually exclusive.

This tool accepts additional command-line arguments.  Refer to the
``SYNOPSIS'' and usage information for details.

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--filter}\index{--filter!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--filter}\pysigline{\bfcode{--filter}\code{}}
type: string

Discard events for which this Perl code doesn't return true.

This option is a string of Perl code or a file containing Perl code that gets
compiled into a subroutine with one argument: \$event.  This is a hashref.
If the given value is a readable file, then \textbf{mariadb-kill} reads the entire
file and uses its contents as the code.  The file should not contain
a shebang (\#!/usr/bin/perl) line.

If the code returns true, the chain of callbacks continues; otherwise it ends.
The code is the last statement in the subroutine other than \code{return \$event}.
The subroutine template is:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sub \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{shift}; filter \PYG{o}{\&\&} \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event}; \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

Filters given on the command line are wrapped inside parentheses like like
\code{( filter )}.  For complex, multi-line filters, you must put the code inside
a file so it will not be wrapped inside parentheses.  Either way, the filter
must produce syntactically valid code given the template.  For example, an
if-else branch given on the command line would not be valid:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--filter \PYG{l+s+s1}{'if () \PYGZob{} \PYGZcb{} else \PYGZob{} \PYGZcb{}'}  \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} WRONG}
\end{Verbatim}

Since it's given on the command line, the if-else branch would be wrapped inside
parentheses which is not syntactically valid.  So to accomplish something more
complex like this would require putting the code in a file, for example
filter.txt:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
my \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}; \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{o}{(}...\PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}\PYG{o}{=}1; \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}\PYG{o}{=}0; \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}
\end{Verbatim}

Then specify \code{-{-}filter filter.txt} to read the code from filter.txt.

If the filter code won't compile, \textbf{mariadb-kill} will die with an error.
If the filter code does compile, an error may still occur at runtime if the
code tries to do something wrong (like pattern match an undefined value).
\textbf{mariadb-kill} does not provide any safeguards so code carefully!

It is permissible for the code to have side effects (to alter \code{\$event}).

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--group-by}\index{--group-by!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--group-by}\pysigline{\bfcode{--group-by}\code{}}
type: string

Apply matches to each class of queries grouped by this SHOW PROCESSLIST column.
In addition to the basic columns of SHOW PROCESSLIST (user, host, command,
state, etc.), queries can be matched by \code{fingerprint} which abstracts the
SQL query in the \code{Info} column.

By default, queries are not grouped, so matches and actions apply to all
queries.  Grouping allows matches and actions to apply to classes of
similar queries, if any queries in the class match.

For example, detecting cache stampedes (see \code{all-but-oldest} under
{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}} for an explanation of that term) requires that queries are
grouped by the \code{arg} attribute.  This creates classes of identical queries
(stripped of comments).  So queries \code{"SELECT c FROM t WHERE id=1"} and
\code{"SELECT c FROM t WHERE id=1"} are grouped into the same class, but
query c\textless{}''SELECT c FROM t WHERE id=3''\textgreater{} is not identical to the first two
queries so it is grouped into another class. Then when {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}}
\code{all-but-oldest} is specified, all but the oldest query in each class is
killed for each class of queries that matches the match criteria.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--help}\index{--help!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--host}\index{--host!mariadb-kill command line option}

Connect to host.

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--interval}\index{--interval!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--interval}\pysigline{\bfcode{--interval}\code{}}
type: time

How often to check for queries to kill.  If {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}} is not given,
then the default interval is 30 seconds.  Else the default is half as often
as {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}}.  If both {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}} are given,
then the explicit {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}} value is used.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--log}\index{--log!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--log}\pysigline{\bfcode{--log}\code{}}
type: string

Print all output to this file when daemonized.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--log-dsn}\index{--log-dsn!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--log-dsn}\pysigline{\bfcode{--log-dsn}\code{}}
type: DSN

Store each query killed in this DSN.

The argument specifies a table to store all killed queries.  The DSN
passed in must have the databse (D) and table (t) options. The
table must have at least the following columns.  You can add more columns for
your own special purposes, but they won't be used by \textbf{mariadb-kill}.  The
following CREATE TABLE definition is also used for {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--create-log-table]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}create-log-table}}}}.
MAGIC\_create\_log\_table:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{CREATE} \PYG{k}{TABLE} \PYG{n}{kill\PYGZus{}log} \PYG{p}{(}
   \PYG{n}{kill\PYGZus{}id}     \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{10}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{n}{unsigned} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{n}{AUTO\PYGZus{}INCREMENT}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{server\PYGZus{}id}   \PYG{n+nb}{bigint}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'0'}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{k}{timestamp}   \PYG{n}{DATETIME}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{reason}      \PYG{n+nb}{TEXT}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{kill\PYGZus{}error}  \PYG{n+nb}{TEXT}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{Id}          \PYG{n+nb}{bigint}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{4}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'0'}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{k}{User}        \PYG{n+nb}{varchar}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{16}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{l+s+s1}{''}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{k}{Host}        \PYG{n+nb}{varchar}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{64}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{l+s+s1}{''}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{db}          \PYG{n+nb}{varchar}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{64}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{k}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{Command}     \PYG{n+nb}{varchar}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{16}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{l+s+s1}{''}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{Time}        \PYG{n+nb}{int}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{7}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'0'}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{k}{State}       \PYG{n+nb}{varchar}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{64}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{k}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{Info}        \PYG{n}{longtext}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{Time\PYGZus{}ms}     \PYG{n+nb}{bigint}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{21}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'0'}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{o}{\PYGZsh{}} \PYG{n}{NOTE}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{TODO}\PYG{p}{:} \PYG{n}{currently} \PYG{k}{not} \PYG{n}{used}
   \PYG{k}{PRIMARY} \PYG{k}{KEY} \PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{kill\PYGZus{}id}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{DEFAULT} \PYG{n}{CHARSET}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n}{utf8}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}
