\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--pid}\index{--pid!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--pid}\pysigline{\bfcode{--pid}\code{}}
type: string

Create the given PID file.  The tool won't start if the PID file already
exists and the PID it contains is different than the current PID.  However,
if the PID file exists and the PID it contains is no longer running, the
tool will overwrite the PID file with the current PID.  The PID file is
removed automatically when the tool exits.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--port}\index{--port!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--port}\pysigline{\bfcode{--port}\code{}}
short form: -P; type: int

Port number to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--query-id}\index{--query-id!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--query-id}\pysigline{\bfcode{--query-id}\code{}}
Prints an ID of the query that was just killed. This is
equivalent to the ``ID'' output of pt-query-digest. This allows
cross-referencing the output of both tools.

Example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Query ID 0xE9800998ECF8427E
\end{Verbatim}

Note that this is a digest (or hash) of the query's ``fingerprint'',
so queries of the same form but with different values will have the same ID.
See pt-query-digest for more information.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--rds}\index{--rds!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--rds}\pysigline{\bfcode{--rds}\code{}}
Denotes the instance in question is on Amazon RDS. By default \textbf{mariadb-kill} runs
the MariaDB command ``kill'' for {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} and ``kill query'' {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill-query]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill-query}}}}.
On RDS these two commands are not available and are replaced by function calls.
This option modifies {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} to use ``CALL mysql.rds\_kill(thread-id)'' instead
and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill-query]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill-query}}}} to use ``CALL mysql.rds\_kill\_query(thread-id)''

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--run-time}\index{--run-time!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--run-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--run-time}\code{}}
type: time

How long to run before exiting.  By default \textbf{mariadb-kill} runs forever, or until
its process is killed or stopped by the creation of a {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--sentinel]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sentinel}}}} file.
If this option is specified, \textbf{mariadb-kill} runs for the specified amount of time
and sleeps {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}} seconds between each check of the PROCESSLIST.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--sentinel}\index{--sentinel!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--sentinel}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sentinel}\code{}}
type: string; default: /tmp/mariadb-kill-sentinel

Exit if this file exists.

The presence of the file specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--sentinel]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sentinel}}}} will cause all
running instances of \textbf{mariadb-kill} to exit.  You might find this handy to stop cron
jobs gracefully if necessary.  See also {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--stop]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}stop}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--slave-user}\index{--slave-user!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--slave-user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--slave-user}\code{}}
type: string

Sets the user to be used to connect to the slaves.
This parameter allows you to have a different user with less privileges on the
slaves but that user must exist on all slaves.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--slave-password}\index{--slave-password!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--slave-password}\pysigline{\bfcode{--slave-password}\code{}}
type: string

Sets the password to be used to connect to the slaves.
It can be used with --slave-user and the password for the user must be the same
on all slaves.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--set-vars}\index{--set-vars!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--set-vars}\pysigline{\bfcode{--set-vars}\code{}}
type: Array

Set the MariaDB variables in this comma-separated list of \code{variable=value} pairs.

By default, the tool sets:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{wait\PYGZus{}timeout}\PYG{o}{=}10000
\end{Verbatim}

Variables specified on the command line override these defaults.  For
example, specifying \code{-{-}set-vars wait\_timeout=500} overrides the defaultvalue of \code{10000}.

The tool prints a warning and continues if a variable cannot be set.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--socket}\index{--socket!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--socket}\pysigline{\bfcode{--socket}\code{}}
short form: -S; type: string

Socket file to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--stop}\index{--stop!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--stop}\pysigline{\bfcode{--stop}\code{}}
Stop running instances by creating the {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--sentinel]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sentinel}}}} file.

Causes \textbf{mariadb-kill} to create the sentinel file specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--sentinel]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sentinel}}}} and
exit.  This should have the effect of stopping all running instances which are
watching the same sentinel file.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--{[}no{]}strip-comments}\index{--{[}no{]}strip-comments!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}strip-comments}}
default: yes

Remove SQL comments from queries in the Info column of the PROCESSLIST.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--user}\index{--user!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--user}\code{}}
short form: -u; type: string

User for login if not current user.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--version}\index{--version!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--version}\pysigline{\bfcode{--version}\code{}}
Show version and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--victims}\index{--victims!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims}\pysigline{\bfcode{--victims}\code{}}
type: string; default: oldest

Which of the matching queries in each class will be killed.  After classes
have been matched/filtered, this option specifies which of the matching
queries in each class will be killed (or printed, etc.).  The following
values are possible:

oldest
\begin{quote}

Only kill the single oldest query.  This is to prevent killing queries that
aren't really long-running, they're just long-waiting.  This sorts matching
queries by Time and kills the one with the highest Time value.
\end{quote}

all
\begin{quote}

Kill all queries in the class.
\end{quote}

all-but-oldest
\begin{quote}

Kill all but the oldest query.  This is the inverse of the \code{oldest} value.

This value can be used to prevent ``cache stampedes'', the condition where
several identical queries are executed and create a backlog while the first
query attempts to finish.  Since all queries are identical, all but the first
query are killed so that it can complete and populate the cache.
\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--wait-after-kill}\index{--wait-after-kill!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--wait-after-kill}\pysigline{\bfcode{--wait-after-kill}\code{}}
type: time

Wait after killing a query, before looking for more to kill.  The purpose of
this is to give blocked queries a chance to execute, so we don't kill a query
that's blocking a bunch of others, and then kill the others immediately
afterwards.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--wait-before-kill}\index{--wait-before-kill!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--wait-before-kill}\pysigline{\bfcode{--wait-before-kill}\code{}}
type: time

Wait before killing a query.  The purpose of this is to give
{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--execute-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}execute-command}}}} a chance to see the matching query and gather other
MariaDB or system information before it's killed.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{QUERY MATCHES}
\label{mariadb-kill:query-matches}
These options filter queries from their classes.  If a query does not
match, it is removed from its class.  The \code{-{-}ignore} options take precedence.
The matches for command, db, host, etc. correspond to the columns returned
by SHOW PROCESSLIST: Command, db, Host, etc.  All pattern matches are
case-sensitive by default, but they can be made case-insensitive by specifying
a regex pattern like \code{(?i-xsm:select)}.

See also ``GROUP, MATCH AND KILL''.
\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--busy-time}\index{--busy-time!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--busy-time}\code{}}
type: time; group: Query Matches

Match queries that have been running for longer than this time.  The queries
must be in Command=Query status.  This matches a query's Time value as
reported by SHOW PROCESSLIST.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--idle-time}\index{--idle-time!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--idle-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--idle-time}\code{}}
type: time; group: Query Matches

Match queries that have been idle/sleeping for longer than this time.
The queries must be in Command=Sleep status.  This matches a query's Time
value as reported by SHOW PROCESSLIST.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--ignore-command}\index{--ignore-command!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--ignore-command}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore-command}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Ignore queries whose Command matches this Perl regex.

See {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-command}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--ignore-db}\index{--ignore-db!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--ignore-db}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore-db}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Ignore queries whose db (database) matches this Perl regex.

See {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-db]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-db}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--ignore-host}\index{--ignore-host!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--ignore-host}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore-host}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Ignore queries whose Host matches this Perl regex.

See {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-host]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-host}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--ignore-info}\index{--ignore-info!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--ignore-info}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore-info}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Ignore queries whose Info (query) matches this Perl regex.

See {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-info]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-info}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--{[}no{]}ignore-self}\index{--{[}no{]}ignore-self!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}ignore-self}}
default: yes; group: Query Matches

Don't kill \textbf{mariadb-kill}`s own connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--ignore-state}\index{--ignore-state!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--ignore-state}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore-state}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches; default: Locked

Ignore queries whose State matches this Perl regex.  The default is to keep
threads from being killed if they are locked waiting for another thread.

See {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-state]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-state}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--ignore-user}\index{--ignore-user!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--ignore-user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore-user}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Ignore queries whose user matches this Perl regex.

See {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-user]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match-user}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--match-all}\index{--match-all!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-all}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match-all}\code{}}
group: Query Matches

Match all queries that are not ignored.  If no ignore options are specified,
then every query matches (except replication threads, unless
{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--replication-threads]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}replication-threads}}}} is also specified).  This option allows you to
specify negative matches, i.e. ``match every query \emph{except}...'' where the
exceptions are defined by specifying various \code{-{-}ignore} options.

This option is \emph{not} the same as {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}} \code{all}.  This option matches
all queries within a class, whereas {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}} \code{all} specifies that all
matching queries in a class (however they matched) will be killed.  Normally,
however, the two are used together because if, for example, you specify
{\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--victims]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}victims}}}} \code{oldest}, then although all queries may match, only the oldest
will be killed.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--match-command}\index{--match-command!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-command}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match-command}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Match only queries whose Command matches this Perl regex.

Common Command values are:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Query
Sleep
Binlog Dump
Connect
Delayed insert
Execute
Fetch
Init DB
Kill
Prepare
Processlist
Quit
Reset stmt
Table Dump
\end{Verbatim}

See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/thread-command-values/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/thread-command-values/} for a full
list and description of Command values.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--match-db}\index{--match-db!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-db}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match-db}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Match only queries whose db (database) matches this Perl regex.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--match-host}\index{--match-host!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-host}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match-host}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Match only queries whose Host matches this Perl regex.

The Host value often time includes the port like ``host:port''.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--match-info}\index{--match-info!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-info}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match-info}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Match only queries whose Info (query) matches this Perl regex.

The Info column of the processlist shows the query that is being executed
or NULL if no query is being executed.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--match-state}\index{--match-state!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-state}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match-state}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Match only queries whose State matches this Perl regex.

Common State values are:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Locked
login
copy to tmp table
Copying to tmp table
Copying to tmp table on disk
Creating tmp table
executing
Reading from net
Sending data
Sorting \PYG{k}{for }order
Sorting result
Table lock
Updating
\end{Verbatim}

See \href{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/general-thread-states/}{https://mariadb.com/kb/en/library/general-thread-states/} for
a full list and description of State values.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--match-user}\index{--match-user!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--match-user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match-user}\code{}}
type: string; group: Query Matches

Match only queries whose User matches this Perl regex.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--replication-threads}\index{--replication-threads!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--replication-threads}\pysigline{\bfcode{--replication-threads}\code{}}
group: Query Matches

Allow matching and killing replication threads.

By default, matches do not apply to replication threads; i.e. replication
threads are completely ignored.  Specifying this option allows matches to
match (and potentially kill) replication threads on masters and slaves.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--test-matching}\index{--test-matching!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--test-matching}\pysigline{\bfcode{--test-matching}\code{}}
type: array; group: Query Matches

Files with processlist snapshots to test matching options against.  Since
the matching options can be complex, you can save snapshots of processlist
in files, then test matching options against queries in those files.

This option disables {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}},
and \emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}ignore-self}}.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{CLASS MATCHES}
\label{mariadb-kill:class-matches}
These matches apply to entire query classes.  Classes are created by specifying
the {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} option, else all queries are members of a single, default
class.

See also ``GROUP, MATCH AND KILL''.
\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--any-busy-time}\index{--any-busy-time!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--any-busy-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--any-busy-time}\code{}}
type: time; group: Class Matches

Match query class if any query has been running for longer than this time.
``Longer than'' means that if you specify \code{10}, for example, the class will
only match if there's at least one query that has been running for greater
than 10 seconds.

See {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--each-busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}each-busy-time}}}} for more details.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--each-busy-time}\index{--each-busy-time!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--each-busy-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--each-busy-time}\code{}}
type: time; group: Class Matches

Match query class if each query has been running for longer than this time.
``Longer than'' means that if you specify \code{10}, for example, the class will
only match if each and every query has been running for greater than 10
seconds.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--any-busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}any-busy-time}}}} (to match a class if ANY query has been running
longer than the specified time) and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--query-count}\index{--query-count!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--query-count}\pysigline{\bfcode{--query-count}\code{}}
type: int; group: Class Matches

Match query class if it has at least this many queries.  When queries are
grouped into classes by specifying {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}}, this option causes matches
to apply only to classes with at least this many queries.  If {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}}
is not specified then this option causes matches to apply only if there
are at least this many queries in the entire SHOW PROCESSLIST.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--verbose}\index{--verbose!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--verbose}\pysigline{\bfcode{--verbose}\code{}}
short form: -v

Print information to STDOUT about what is being done.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{ACTIONS}
\label{mariadb-kill:actions}
These actions are taken for every matching query from all classes.
The actions are taken in this order: {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--execute-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}execute-command}}}},
\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill"/"-{-}kill-query}}.  This order allows {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--execute-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}execute-command}}}}
to see the output of {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}} and the query before
\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill"/"-{-}kill-query}}.  This may be helpful because \textbf{mariadb-kill} does
not pass any information to {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--execute-command]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}execute-command}}}}.

See also ``GROUP, MATCH AND KILL''.
\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--execute-command}\index{--execute-command!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--execute-command}\pysigline{\bfcode{--execute-command}\code{}}
type: string; group: Actions

Execute this command when a query matches.

After the command is executed, \textbf{mariadb-kill} has no control over it, so the command
is responsible for its own info gathering, logging, interval, etc.  The
command is executed each time a query matches, so be careful that the command
behaves well when multiple instances are ran.  No information from \textbf{mariadb-kill} is
passed to the command.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--wait-before-kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}wait-before-kill}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--kill}\index{--kill!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill}\pysigline{\bfcode{--kill}\code{}}
group: Actions

Kill the connection for matching queries.

This option makes \textbf{mariadb-kill} kill the connections (a.k.a. processes, threads) that
have matching queries.  Use {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill-query]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill-query}}}} if you only want to kill
individual queries and not their connections.

Unless {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}} is also given, no other information is printed that shows
that \textbf{mariadb-kill} matched and killed a query.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--wait-before-kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}wait-before-kill}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--wait-after-kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}wait-after-kill}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--kill-busy-commands}\index{--kill-busy-commands!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill-busy-commands}\pysigline{\bfcode{--kill-busy-commands}\code{}}
type: string; default: Query

group: Actions

Comma sepatated list of commands that will be watched/killed if they ran for
more than {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}} seconds. Default: \code{Query}

By default, {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}} kills only \code{Query} commands but in some cases, it
is needed to make {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--busy-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}busy-time}}}} to watch and kill other commands. For example,
a prepared statement execution command is \code{Execute} instead of \code{Query}. In this
case, specifying \code{-{-}kill-busy-commands=Query,Execute} will also kill the prepared
stamente execution.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--kill-query}\index{--kill-query!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill-query}\pysigline{\bfcode{--kill-query}\code{}}
group: Actions

Kill matching queries.

This option makes \textbf{mariadb-kill} kill matching queries.  This requires MariaDB 5.0 or
newer.  Unlike {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} which kills the connection for matching queries,
this option only kills the query, not its connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-kill command line option!--print}\index{--print!mariadb-kill command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print}\pysigline{\bfcode{--print}\code{}}
group: Actions

Print a KILL statement for matching queries; does not actually kill queries.

If you just want to see which queries match and would be killed without
actually killing them, specify {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}}.  To both kill and print
matching queries, specify both {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--kill]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}kill}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-kill:cmdoption-mariadb-kill--print]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}print}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{DSN OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-kill:dsn-options}
These DSN options are used to create a DSN.  Each option is given like
\code{option=value}.  The options are case-sensitive, so P and p are not the
same option.  There cannot be whitespace before or after the \code{=} and
if the value contains whitespace it must be quoted.  DSN options are
comma-separated.  See the percona-toolkit manpage for full details.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
A

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: charset; copy: yes

Default character set.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
D

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: database; copy: yes

Default database.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
F

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: mysql\_read\_default\_file; copy: yes

Only read default options from the given file
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
h

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: host; copy: yes

Connect to host.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
p

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: password; copy: yes

Password to use when connecting.
If password contains commas they must be escaped with a backslash: ``exam,ple''
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
P

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: port; copy: yes

Port number to use for connection.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
S

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: mariadb\_socket; copy: yes

Socket file to use for connection.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
u

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: user; copy: yes

User for login if not current user.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
t

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Table to log actions in, if passed through --log-dsn.
\end{quote}


\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-kill:environment}
The environment variable \code{PTDEBUG} enables verbose debugging output to STDERR.
To enable debugging and capture all output to a file, run the tool like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{PTDEBUG}\PYG{o}{=}1 mariadb-kill ... \textgreater{} FILE 2\textgreater{}\&1
\end{Verbatim}

Be careful: debugging output is voluminous and can generate several megabytes
of output.


\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}

You need Perl, DBI, DBD::mysql, and some core packages that ought to be
installed in any reasonably new version of Perl.

\section{\textbf{mariadb-parted}}
\label{mariadb-parted:mariadb-parted}\label{mariadb-parted::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-parted:name}
\textbf{mariadb-parted} - MySQL partition management script


\subsection{EXAMPLES}
\label{mariadb-parted:examples}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Create weekly partitions for the next quarter to test.part\PYGZus{}table}
mariadb-parted --add --interval w +1q \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Create daily partitions for the next 2 weeks}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} starting exactly at the beginning of every day}
mariadb-parted --add --interval d +2w.startof \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Email ops@example.com about partitions added}
mariadb-parted --add --email-activity --email-to ops@example.com \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           --interval d +4w \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Drop partitions older than 8 weeks}
mariadb-parted --drop -8w \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Drop partitions older than Dec 20th, 2010, but only 5 of them.}
mariadb-parted --drop --limit 5 \PYG{l+s+s1}{'2010-12-20 00:00:00'} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Drop and archive partitions older than 2 quarters ago.}
mariadb-parted --drop --archive --archive-path /backups -2q \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}locahost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Same as above, but archived to a separate database.}
mariadb-parted --drop --archive --archive-database \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}remotehost,D\PYG{o}{=}test\PYGZus{}archives,t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table -2q \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}locahost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Logging to syslog}
mariadb-parted --logfile syslog:LOCAL0 --add --interval d 1y \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-parted:synopsis}
\textbf{mariadb-parted} {[}options{]} ACTION TIMESPEC DSN

This tool assists in the creation of partitions in regular intervals.
It creates partitions in regular intervals up to some maximum future date.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--help,          -h   This help. See C\textless{}perldoc mariadb-parted\textgreater{} \PYG{k}{for }full docs.
--dryrun,        -n   Report on actions without taking them.
--logfile,       -L   Direct output to given logfile. Default: none.

--email-activity      Send a brief email report of actions taken.
                      The email is sent to --email-to.
--use-hours          Use hours instead of days when checking partitions.
--partcol-integer     Assume no partitioning \PYG{n+nb}{time }or date \PYG{k}{function }in use
--email-to,      -E   Where to send activity and failure emails.
                      Default: none.

--prefix,        -P   Partition prefix. Defaults to \PYG{l+s+s1}{'p'}.

--archive             Archive partitions before dropping them.
--archive-path        Directory to place mysqldumps.
                      Default: current directory.
--archive-database    Database to archive partitions to.
                      Default: none

--limit,         -m   Limit the number of actions to be performed.
                      Default: 0 \PYG{o}{(}unlimited\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{ACTION}
\label{mariadb-parted:action}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--add   Add partitions.
--drop  Remove partitions.
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{TIMESPEC}
\label{mariadb-parted:timespec}
A timespec is a ``natural'' string to specify how far in advance to create
partitions. A sampling of possible timespecs:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
1w \PYG{o}{(}create partitions one week in advance\PYG{o}{)}
1m \PYG{o}{(}one month\PYG{o}{)}
2q \PYG{o}{(}two quarters\PYG{o}{)}
5h \PYG{o}{(}five hours\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

See the full documentation for a complete description of timespecs.


\subsection{DSN}
\label{mariadb-parted:dsn}
DSNs, such as those passed as option values, or arguments to a program
are of the format: \code{(\{key\}=\{value\}(,\{key\}=\{value\})*}. That is, a \code{key=value} pair, followed
by a comma, followed by any number of additional \code{key=value} pairs separated by
commas.


\subsubsection{Examples}
\label{mariadb-parted:id1}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}testdb1,u\PYG{o}{=}pdb,p\PYG{o}{=}frogs
\PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,S\PYG{o}{=}/tmp/mysql.sock,u\PYG{o}{=}root,F\PYG{o}{=}/root/my.cnf
\end{Verbatim}

Where `h' is a hostname, `S' is a socket path, `u' is a user, `F' is a path
to a defaults file, and `p' is a password. These are non-exhaustive examples.


\subsection{TIMESPEC}
\label{mariadb-parted:id2}
A timespec is one of:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
A modifier to current \PYG{n+nb}{local }\PYG{n+nb}{time},
A unix timestamp \PYG{o}{(}assumed in UTC\PYG{o}{)},
The string \PYG{l+s+s1}{'now'} to refer to current \PYG{n+nb}{local }\PYG{n+nb}{time},
An absolute \PYG{n+nb}{time }in \PYG{l+s+s1}{'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS'} format,
An absolute \PYG{n+nb}{time }in \PYG{l+s+s1}{'YYYY-MD-DD HH:MM:SS TIMEZONE'} format.
\end{Verbatim}

For the purposes of this module, TIMEZONE refers to zone names
created and maintained by the zoneinfo database.
See \href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz\_database}{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz\_database} for more information.
Commonly used zone names are: Etc/UTC, US/Pacific and US/Eastern.

Since the last four aren't very complicated, this section describes
what the modifiers are.

A modifer is, an optional plus or minus sign followed by a number,
and then one of:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{y} \PYG{o}{=} year, \PYG{n+nv}{q} \PYG{o}{=} quarter , \PYG{n+nv}{m} \PYG{o}{=} month, \PYG{n+nv}{w} \PYG{o}{=} week, \PYG{n+nv}{d} \PYG{o}{=} day, \PYG{n+nv}{h} \PYG{o}{=} hour
\end{Verbatim}

Followed optionally by a space or a period and `startof'.
Which is described in the next section.

Some examples (the time is assumed to be 00:00:00):

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
-1y         \PYG{o}{(}2010-11-01 -\textgreater{} 2009-11-01\PYG{o}{)}
 5d         \PYG{o}{(}2010-12-10 -\textgreater{} 2010-12-15\PYG{o}{)}
-1w         \PYG{o}{(}2010-12-13 -\textgreater{} 2010-12-07\PYG{o}{)}
-1q startof \PYG{o}{(}2010-05-01 -\textgreater{} 2010-01-01\PYG{o}{)}
 1q.startof \PYG{o}{(}2010-05-01 -\textgreater{} 2010-07-01\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{startof}
\label{mariadb-parted:startof}
The `startof' modifier for timespecs is a little confusing,
but, is the only sane way to achieve latching like behavior.
It adjusts the reference time so that it starts at the beginning
of the requested type of interval. So, if you specify \code{-1h startof},
and the current time is: \code{2010-12-03 04:33:56}, first the calculation
throws away \code{33:56} to get: \code{2010-12-03 04:00:00}, and then subtracts
one hour to yield: \code{2010-12-03 03:00:00}.

Diagram of the `startof' operator for timespec \code{-1q startof},
given the date \code{2010-05-01 00:00}.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
        R P   C
        v v   v
 ---.---.---.---.---.--- Dec 2010
 \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}
 Jul Oct Jan Apr Jul Oct
2009    2010

. \PYG{o}{=} quarter separator
\PYG{n+nv}{C} \PYG{o}{=} current quarter
\PYG{n+nv}{P} \PYG{o}{=} previous quarter
\PYG{n+nv}{R} \PYG{o}{=} Resultant \PYG{n+nb}{time} \PYG{o}{(}2010-01-01 00:00:00\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-parted:options}\begin{optionlist}{3cm}
\item [-{-}help, -h]  
This help.
\item [-{-}dryrun, -n]  
Report on actions that would be taken. Works best with the \code{Pdb\_DEBUG} environment variable set to true.

See also: ENVIRONMENT
\item [-{-}logfile, -L]  
Path to a file for logging, or, \code{syslog:\textless{}facility\textgreater{}}
Where \code{\textless{}facility\textgreater{}} is a pre-defined logging facility for this machine.

See also: syslog(3), syslogd(8), syslog.conf(5)
\item [-{-}email-to, -E]  
Where to send emails.

This tool can send emails on failure, and whenever it adds, drops, or archive partitions.
Ordinarily, it will only send emails on failure.
\end{optionlist}
\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--email-activity}\index{--email-activity!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--email-activity}\pysigline{\bfcode{--email-activity}\code{}}
If this flag is present, then this will make the tool also email
whenver it adds, drops, or archives a partition.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--use-hours}\index{--use-hours!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--use-hours}\pysigline{\bfcode{--use-hours}\code{}}
If this flag is present, then partitions will be checked on the hour and not on the day.
Useful when you need to partition by hour.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--partcol-integer}\index{--partcol-integer!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--partcol-integer}\pysigline{\bfcode{--partcol-integer}\code{}}
If this flag is present, then the tool will assume there is no partitioning function
defined, e.g. if you are storing your date into an integer column

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{optionlist}{3cm}
\item [-{-}prefix, -P]  
Prefix for partition names. Partitions are always named like: \textless{}prefix\textgreater{}N.
Where N is a number. Default is `p', which was observed to be the most common prefix.
\item [-{-}interval, -i]  
type: string one of: d w m y

Specifies the size of the each partition for the --add action.
`d' is day, `w' is week, `m' is month, and `y' is year.
\end{optionlist}
\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--limit}\index{--limit!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--limit}\pysigline{\bfcode{--limit}\code{}}
Specifies a limit to the number of partitions to add, drop, or archive.
By default this is unlimited (0), so, for testing one usually wishes to set
this to 1.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--archive}\index{--archive!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--archive}\pysigline{\bfcode{--archive}\code{}}
type: boolean

mysqldump partitions to files \textbf{in the current directory} named like \textless{}host\textgreater{}.\textless{}schema\textgreater{}.\textless{}table\textgreater{}.\textless{}partition\_name\textgreater{}.sql

There is not currently a way to archive without dropping a partition.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--archive-path}\index{--archive-path!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--archive-path}\pysigline{\bfcode{--archive-path}\code{}}
What directory to place the SQL dumps of partition data in.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--archive-database}\index{--archive-database!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--archive-database}\pysigline{\bfcode{--archive-database}\code{}}
What database to place the archived partitions in.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{ACTIONS}
\label{mariadb-parted:actions}\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--add}\index{--add!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--add}\pysigline{\bfcode{--add}\code{}}
Adds partitions till there are at least TIMESPEC --interval sized future buckets.

The adding of partitions is not done blindly. This will only add new partitions
if there are fewer than TIMESPEC future partitions. For example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Given: --interval d, today is: 2011-01-15, TIMESPEC is: +1w,
       last partition \PYG{o}{(}p5\PYG{o}{)} is \PYG{k}{for }2011-01-16;

Result:
  Parted will add 6 partitions to make the last partition 2011-01-22 \PYG{o}{(}p11\PYG{o}{)}.

Before:
 \textbar{}---+\textbar{}
p0  p5

After:
 \textbar{}---+-----\textbar{}
p0  p5    p11
\end{Verbatim}

You can think of \code{-{-}add} as specifying a required minimum safety zone.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted command line option!--drop}\index{--drop!mariadb-parted command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted:cmdoption-mariadb-parted--drop}\pysigline{\bfcode{--drop}\code{}}
Drops partitions strictly older than TIMESPEC.
The partitions are not renumbered to start with p0 again.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Given: today is: 2011-01-15, TIMESPEC is: -1w,
       first partition \PYG{o}{(}p0\PYG{o}{)} is \PYG{k}{for }2011-01-06

Result: 2 partitions will be dropped.

Before: \textbar{}-----+--\textbar{}
        0     6  9
After : \textbar{}---+--\textbar{}
        2   6  9
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-parted:environment}

\section{\textbf{mariadb-parted-fat}}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat::doc}\label{mariadb-parted-fat:mariadb-parted-fat}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:name}
mariadb-parted - MySQL partition management script


\subsection{EXAMPLES}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:examples}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Create weekly partitions for the next quarter to test.part\PYGZus{}table}
mariadb-parted --add --interval w +1q \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Create daily partitions for the next 2 weeks}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} starting exactly at the beginning of every day}
mariadb-parted --add --interval d +2w.startof \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Email ops@example.com about partitions added}
mariadb-parted --add --email-activity --email-to ops@example.com \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           --interval d +4w \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Drop partitions older than 8 weeks}
mariadb-parted --drop -8w \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Drop partitions older than Dec 20th, 2010, but only 5 of them.}
mariadb-parted --drop --limit 5 \PYG{l+s+s1}{'2010-12-20 00:00:00'} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Drop and archive partitions older than 2 quarters ago.}
mariadb-parted --drop --archive --archive-path /backups -2q \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}locahost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Same as above, but archived to a separate database.}
mariadb-parted --drop --archive --archive-database \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}remotehost,D\PYG{o}{=}test\PYGZus{}archives,t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table -2q \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}locahost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table

\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Logging to syslog}
mariadb-parted --logfile syslog:LOCAL0 --add --interval d 1y \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
           \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,D\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{n+nb}{test},t\PYG{o}{=}part\PYGZus{}table
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:synopsis}
mariadb-parted {[}options{]} ACTION TIMESPEC DSN

This tool assists in the creation of partitions in regular intervals.
It creates partitions in regular intervals up to some maximum future date.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--help,          -h   This help. See C\textless{}perldoc mariadb-parted\textgreater{} \PYG{k}{for }full docs.
--dryrun,        -n   Report on actions without taking them.
--logfile,       -L   Direct output to given logfile. Default: none.

--email-activity      Send a brief email report of actions taken.
                      The email is sent to --email-to.
--use-hours          Use hours instead of days when checking partitions.
--partcol-integer     Assume no partitioning \PYG{n+nb}{time }or date \PYG{k}{function }in use
--email-to,      -E   Where to send activity and failure emails.
                      Default: none.

--prefix,        -P   Partition prefix. Defaults to \PYG{l+s+s1}{'p'}.

--archive             Archive partitions before dropping them.
--archive-path        Directory to place mysqldumps.
                      Default: current directory.
--archive-database    Database to archive partitions to.
                      Default: none

--limit,         -m   Limit the number of actions to be performed.
                      Default: 0 \PYG{o}{(}unlimited\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{ACTION}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:action}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--add   Add partitions.
--drop  Remove partitions.
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{TIMESPEC}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:timespec}
A timespec is a ``natural'' string to specify how far in advance to create
partitions. A sampling of possible timespecs:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
1w \PYG{o}{(}create partitions one week in advance\PYG{o}{)}
1m \PYG{o}{(}one month\PYG{o}{)}
2q \PYG{o}{(}two quarters\PYG{o}{)}
5h \PYG{o}{(}five hours\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

See the full documentation for a complete description of timespecs.


\subsection{DSN}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:dsn}
DSNs, such as those passed as option values, or arguments to a program
are of the format: \code{(\{key\}=\{value\}(,\{key\}=\{value\})*}. That is, a \code{key=value} pair, followed
by a comma, followed by any number of additional \code{key=value} pairs separated by
commas.


\subsubsection{Examples}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:id1}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}testdb1,u\PYG{o}{=}pdb,p\PYG{o}{=}frogs
\PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}localhost,S\PYG{o}{=}/tmp/mysql.sock,u\PYG{o}{=}root,F\PYG{o}{=}/root/my.cnf
\end{Verbatim}

Where `h' is a hostname, `S' is a socket path, `u' is a user, `F' is a path
to a defaults file, and `p' is a password. These are non-exhaustive examples.


\subsection{TIMESPEC}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:id2}
A timespec is one of:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
A modifier to current \PYG{n+nb}{local }\PYG{n+nb}{time},
A unix timestamp \PYG{o}{(}assumed in UTC\PYG{o}{)},
The string \PYG{l+s+s1}{'now'} to refer to current \PYG{n+nb}{local }\PYG{n+nb}{time},
An absolute \PYG{n+nb}{time }in \PYG{l+s+s1}{'YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM:SS'} format,
An absolute \PYG{n+nb}{time }in \PYG{l+s+s1}{'YYYY-MD-DD HH:MM:SS TIMEZONE'} format.
\end{Verbatim}

For the purposes of this module, TIMEZONE refers to zone names
created and maintained by the zoneinfo database.
See \href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz\_database}{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tz\_database} for more information.
Commonly used zone names are: Etc/UTC, US/Pacific and US/Eastern.

Since the last four aren't very complicated, this section describes
what the modifiers are.

A modifer is, an optional plus or minus sign followed by a number,
and then one of:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{y} \PYG{o}{=} year, \PYG{n+nv}{q} \PYG{o}{=} quarter , \PYG{n+nv}{m} \PYG{o}{=} month, \PYG{n+nv}{w} \PYG{o}{=} week, \PYG{n+nv}{d} \PYG{o}{=} day, \PYG{n+nv}{h} \PYG{o}{=} hour
\end{Verbatim}

Followed optionally by a space or a period and `startof'.
Which is described in the next section.

Some examples (the time is assumed to be 00:00:00):

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
-1y         \PYG{o}{(}2010-11-01 -\textgreater{} 2009-11-01\PYG{o}{)}
 5d         \PYG{o}{(}2010-12-10 -\textgreater{} 2010-12-15\PYG{o}{)}
-1w         \PYG{o}{(}2010-12-13 -\textgreater{} 2010-12-07\PYG{o}{)}
-1q startof \PYG{o}{(}2010-05-01 -\textgreater{} 2010-01-01\PYG{o}{)}
 1q.startof \PYG{o}{(}2010-05-01 -\textgreater{} 2010-07-01\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{startof}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:startof}
The `startof' modifier for timespecs is a little confusing,
but, is the only sane way to achieve latching like behavior.
It adjusts the reference time so that it starts at the beginning
of the requested type of interval. So, if you specify \code{-1h startof},
and the current time is: \code{2010-12-03 04:33:56}, first the calculation
throws away \code{33:56} to get: \code{2010-12-03 04:00:00}, and then subtracts
one hour to yield: \code{2010-12-03 03:00:00}.

Diagram of the `startof' operator for timespec \code{-1q startof},
given the date \code{2010-05-01 00:00}.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
        R P   C
        v v   v
 ---.---.---.---.---.--- Dec 2010
 \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}   \PYGZca{}
 Jul Oct Jan Apr Jul Oct
2009    2010

. \PYG{o}{=} quarter separator
\PYG{n+nv}{C} \PYG{o}{=} current quarter
\PYG{n+nv}{P} \PYG{o}{=} previous quarter
\PYG{n+nv}{R} \PYG{o}{=} Resultant \PYG{n+nb}{time} \PYG{o}{(}2010-01-01 00:00:00\PYG{o}{)}
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:options}\begin{optionlist}{3cm}
\item [-{-}help, -h]  
This help.
\item [-{-}dryrun, -n]  
Report on actions that would be taken. Works best with the \code{Pdb\_DEBUG} environment variable set to true.

See also: ENVIRONMENT
\item [-{-}logfile, -L]  
Path to a file for logging, or, \code{syslog:\textless{}facility\textgreater{}}
Where \code{\textless{}facility\textgreater{}} is a pre-defined logging facility for this machine.

See also: syslog(3), syslogd(8), syslog.conf(5)
\item [-{-}email-to, -E]  
Where to send emails.

This tool can send emails on failure, and whenever it adds, drops, or archive partitions.
Ordinarily, it will only send emails on failure.
\end{optionlist}
\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--email-activity}\index{--email-activity!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--email-activity}\pysigline{\bfcode{--email-activity}\code{}}
If this flag is present, then this will make the tool also email
whenver it adds, drops, or archives a partition.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--use-hours}\index{--use-hours!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--use-hours}\pysigline{\bfcode{--use-hours}\code{}}
If this flag is present, then partitions will be checked on the hour and not on the day.
Useful when you need to partition by hour.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--partcol-integer}\index{--partcol-integer!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--partcol-integer}\pysigline{\bfcode{--partcol-integer}\code{}}
If this flag is present, then the tool will assume there is no partitioning function
defined, e.g. if you are storing your date into an integer column

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{optionlist}{3cm}
\item [-{-}prefix, -P]  
Prefix for partition names. Partitions are always named like: \textless{}prefix\textgreater{}N.
Where N is a number. Default is `p', which was observed to be the most common prefix.
\item [-{-}interval, -i]  
type: string one of: d w m y

Specifies the size of the each partition for the --add action.
`d' is day, `w' is week, `m' is month, and `y' is year.
\end{optionlist}
\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--limit}\index{--limit!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--limit}\pysigline{\bfcode{--limit}\code{}}
Specifies a limit to the number of partitions to add, drop, or archive.
By default this is unlimited (0), so, for testing one usually wishes to set
this to 1.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--archive}\index{--archive!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--archive}\pysigline{\bfcode{--archive}\code{}}
type: boolean

mysqldump partitions to files \textbf{in the current directory} named like \textless{}host\textgreater{}.\textless{}schema\textgreater{}.\textless{}table\textgreater{}.\textless{}partition\_name\textgreater{}.sql

There is not currently a way to archive without dropping a partition.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--archive-path}\index{--archive-path!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--archive-path}\pysigline{\bfcode{--archive-path}\code{}}
What directory to place the SQL dumps of partition data in.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--archive-database}\index{--archive-database!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--archive-database}\pysigline{\bfcode{--archive-database}\code{}}
What database to place the archived partitions in.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{ACTIONS}
\label{mariadb-parted-fat:actions}\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--add}\index{--add!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--add}\pysigline{\bfcode{--add}\code{}}
Adds partitions till there are at least TIMESPEC --interval sized future buckets.

The adding of partitions is not done blindly. This will only add new partitions
if there are fewer than TIMESPEC future partitions. For example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Given: --interval d, today is: 2011-01-15, TIMESPEC is: +1w,
       last partition \PYG{o}{(}p5\PYG{o}{)} is \PYG{k}{for }2011-01-16;

Result:
  Parted will add 6 partitions to make the last partition 2011-01-22 \PYG{o}{(}p11\PYG{o}{)}.

Before:
 \textbar{}---+\textbar{}
p0  p5

After:
 \textbar{}---+-----\textbar{}
p0  p5    p11
\end{Verbatim}

You can think of \code{-{-}add} as specifying a required minimum safety zone.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-parted-fat command line option!--drop}\index{--drop!mariadb-parted-fat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-parted-fat:cmdoption-mariadb-parted-fat--drop}\pysigline{\bfcode{--drop}\code{}}
Drops partitions strictly older than TIMESPEC.
The partitions are not renumbered to start with p0 again.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Given: today is: 2011-01-15, TIMESPEC is: -1w,
       first partition \PYG{o}{(}p0\PYG{o}{)} is \PYG{k}{for }2011-01-06

Result: 2 partitions will be dropped.

Before: \textbar{}-----+--\textbar{}
        0     6  9
After : \textbar{}---+--\textbar{}
        2   6  9
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}
