\section{\textbf{mariadb-query-digest}}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:mariadb-query-digest}\label{mariadb-query-digest::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:name}
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} - Analyze MariaDB queries from logs, processlist, and tcpdump.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{query}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{digest} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{FILES}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{DSN}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} analyzes MariaDB queries from slow, general, and binary log
files.  It can also analyze queries from \code{SHOW PROCESSLIST} and MariaDB
protocol data from tcpdump.  By default, queries are grouped by fingerprint
and reported in descending order of query time (i.e. the slowest queries
first).  If no \code{FILES} are given, the tool reads \code{STDIN}.  The optional
\code{DSN} is used for certain options like {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--since]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}since}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--until]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}until}}}}.

Report the slowest queries from \code{slow.log}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-query-digest slow.log
\end{Verbatim}

Report the slowest queries from the processlist on host1:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-query-digest --processlist \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}host1
\end{Verbatim}

Capture MariaDB protocol data with tcppdump, then report the slowest queries:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
tcpdump -s 65535 -x -nn -q -tttt -i any -c 1000 port 3306 \textgreater{} mariadb.tcp.txt

mariadb-query-digest --type tcpdump mariadb.tcp.txt
\end{Verbatim}

Save query data from \code{slow.log} to host2 for later review and trend analysis:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-query-digest --review \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}host2 --no-report slow.log
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:risks}
MariaDB Tools is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:description}
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} is a sophisticated but easy to use tool for analyzing
MariaDB queries.  It can analyze queries from MariaDB slow, general, and binary
logs. (Binary logs must first be converted to text, see {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}type}}}}).
It can also use \code{SHOW PROCESSLIST} and MariaDB protocol data from tcpdump.
By default, the tool reports which queries are the slowest, and therefore
the most important to optimize.  More complex and custom-tailored reports
can be created by using options like {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}filter}}}}, and
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--embedded-attributes]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}embedded-attributes}}}}.

Query analysis is a best-practice that should be done frequently.  To
make this easier, \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} has two features: query review
({\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}}) and query history ({\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}}).  When the {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}}
option is used, all unique queries are saved to a database.  When the
tool is ran again with {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}}, queries marked as reviewed in
the database are not printed in the report.  This highlights new queries
that need to be reviewed.  When the {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}} option is used,
query metrics (query time, lock time, etc.) for each unique query are
saved to database.  Each time the tool is ran with {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}}, the
more historical data is saved which can be used to trend and analyze
query performance over time.


\subsection{ATTRIBUTES}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:attributes}
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} works on events, which are a collection of key-value pairs
called attributes.  You'll recognize most of the attributes right away:
\code{Query\_time}, \code{Lock\_time}, and so on.  You can just look at a slow log
and see them.  However, there are some that don't exist in the slow log,
and slow logs may actually include different kinds of attributes depending
upon the MariaDB Server version.

See ``ATTRIBUTES REFERENCE'' near the end of this documentation for a list
of common and {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}type}}}} specific attributes.  A familiarity with these
attributes is necessary for working with {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}filter}}}},
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--ignore-attributes]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}ignore-attributes}}}}, and other attribute-related options.

With creative use of {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}filter}}}}, you can create new attributes derived
from existing attributes.  For example, to create an attribute called
\code{Row\_ratio} for examining the ratio of \code{Rows\_sent} to \code{Rows\_examined},
specify a filter like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--filter \PYG{l+s+s1}{'(\PYGZdl{}event-\textgreater{}\PYGZob{}Row\PYGZus{}ratio\PYGZcb{} = \PYGZdl{}event-\textgreater{}\PYGZob{}Rows\PYGZus{}sent\PYGZcb{} / (\PYGZdl{}event-\textgreater{}\PYGZob{}Rows\PYGZus{}examined\PYGZcb{})) \&\& 1'}
\end{Verbatim}

The \code{\&\& 1} trick is needed to create a valid one-line syntax that is always
true, even if the assignment happens to evaluate false.  The new attribute will
automatically appears in the output:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Row ratio        1.00    0.00      1    0.50      1    0.71    0.50}
\end{Verbatim}

Attributes created this way can be specified for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}} or any
option that requires an attribute.


\subsection{OUTPUT}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:output}
The default {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--output]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}output}}}} is a query analysis report.  The \emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}report}}
option controls whether or not this report is printed.  Sometimes you may
want to parse all the queries but suppress the report, for example when using
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}} or {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}}.

There is one paragraph for each class of query analyzed.  A ``class'' of queries
all have the same value for the {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} attribute which is
\code{fingerprint} by default.  (See ``ATTRIBUTES''.)  A fingerprint is an
abstracted version of the query text with literals removed, whitespace
collapsed, and so forth.  The report is formatted so it's easy to paste into
emails without wrapping, and all non-query lines begin with a comment, so you
can save it to a .sql file and open it in your favorite syntax-highlighting
text editor.  There is a response-time profile at the beginning.

The output described here is controlled by {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-format]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}report-format}}}}.
That option allows you to specify what to print and in what order.
The default output in the default order is described here.

The report, by default, begins with a paragraph about the entire analysis run
The information is very similar to what you'll see for each class of queries in
the log, but it doesn't have some information that would be too expensive to
keep globally for the analysis.  It also has some statistics about the code's
execution itself, such as the CPU and memory usage, the local date and time
of the run, and a list of input file read/parsed.

Following this is the response-time profile over the events.  This is a
highly summarized view of the unique events in the detailed query report
that follows.  It contains the following columns:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Column        \PYG{n+nv}{Meaning}
\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}  \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}
Rank          The query\PYG{l+s+s1}{'s rank within the entire set of queries analyzed}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{Query ID      The query'}s fingerprint
Response \PYG{n+nb}{time }The total response \PYG{n+nb}{time}, and percentage of overall total
Calls         The number of \PYG{n+nb}{times }this query was executed
R/Call        The mean response \PYG{n+nb}{time }per execution
V/M           The Variance-to-mean ratio of response \PYG{n+nb}{time}
Item          The distilled query
\end{Verbatim}

A final line whose rank is shown as MISC contains aggregate statistics on the
queries that were not included in the report, due to options such as
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--outliers]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}outliers}}}}.  For details on the variance-to-mean ratio,
please see \href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index\_of\_dispersion}{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Index\_of\_dispersion}.

Next, the detailed query report is printed.  Each query appears in a paragraph.
Here is a sample, slightly reformatted so `perldoc' will not wrap lines in a
terminal.  The following will all be one paragraph, but we'll break it up for
commentary.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Query 2: 0.01 QPS, 0.02x conc, ID 0xFDEA8D2993C9CAF3 at byte 160665}
\end{Verbatim}

This line identifies the sequential number of the query in the sort order
specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}}.  Then there's the queries per second, and the
approximate concurrency for this query (calculated as a function of the timespan
and total Query\_time).  Next there's a query ID.  This ID is a hex version of
the query's checksum in the database, if you're using {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}}.  You can
select the reviewed query's details from the database with a query like \code{SELECT
.... WHERE checksum=0xFDEA8D2993C9CAF3}.

If you are investigating the report and want to print out every sample of a
particular query, then the following {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}filter}}}} may be helpful:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-query-digest slow.log           \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
   --no-report                     \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
   --output slowlog                \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
   --filter \PYG{l+s+s1}{'\PYGZdl{}event-\textgreater{}\PYGZob{}fingerprint\PYGZcb{} \PYGZbs{}}
\PYG{l+s+s1}{        \&\& make\PYGZus{}checksum(\PYGZdl{}event-\textgreater{}\PYGZob{}fingerprint\PYGZcb{}) eq "FDEA8D2993C9CAF3"'}
\end{Verbatim}

Notice that you must remove the \code{0x} prefix from the checksum.

Finally, in case you want to find a sample of the query in the log file, there's
the byte offset where you can look.  (This is not always accurate, due to some
anomalies in the slow log format, but it's usually right.)  The position
refers to the worst sample, which we'll see more about below.

Next is the table of metrics about this class of queries.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}           pct   total    min    max     avg     95\PYGZpc{}  stddev  median}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Count       0       2}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Exec time  13   1105s   552s   554s    553s    554s      2s    553s}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Lock time   0   216us   99us  117us   108us   117us    12us   108us}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Rows sent  20   6.26M  3.13M  3.13M   3.13M   3.13M   12.73   3.13M}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Rows exam   0   6.26M  3.13M  3.13M   3.13M   3.13M   12.73   3.13M}
\end{Verbatim}

The first line is column headers for the table.  The percentage is the percent
of the total for the whole analysis run, and the total is the actual value of
the specified metric.  For example, in this case we can see that the query
executed 2 times, which is 13\% of the total number of queries in the file.  The
min, max and avg columns are self-explanatory.  The 95\% column shows the 95th
percentile; 95\% of the values are less than or equal to this value.  The
standard deviation shows you how tightly grouped the values are.  The standard
deviation and median are both calculated from the 95th percentile, discarding
the extremely large values.

The stddev, median and 95th percentile statistics are approximate.  Exact
statistics require keeping every value seen, sorting, and doing some
calculations on them.  This uses a lot of memory.  To avoid this, we keep 1000
buckets, each of them 5\% bigger than the one before, ranging from .000001 up to
a very big number.  When we see a value we increment the bucket into which it
falls.  Thus we have fixed memory per class of queries.  The drawback is the
imprecision, which typically falls in the 5 percent range.

Next we have statistics on the users, databases and time range for the query.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Users       1   user1}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Databases   2     db1(1), db2(1)}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Time range 2008-11-26 04:55:18 to 2008-11-27 00:15:15}
\end{Verbatim}

The users and databases are shown as a count of distinct values, followed by the
values.  If there's only one, it's shown alone; if there are many, we show each
of the most frequent ones, followed by the number of times it appears.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Query\PYGZus{}time distribution}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}   1us}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}  10us}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 100us}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}   1ms}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}  10ms  \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 100ms  \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}    1s  \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}  10s+}
\end{Verbatim}

The execution times show a logarithmic chart of time clustering.  Each query
goes into one of the ``buckets'' and is counted up.  The buckets are powers of
ten.  The first bucket is all values in the ``single microsecond range'' -- that
is, less than 10us.  The second is ``tens of microseconds,'' which is from 10us
up to (but not including) 100us; and so on.  The charted attribute can be
changed by specifying {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-histogram]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}report-histogram}}}} but is limited to time-based
attributes.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Tables}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}    SHOW TABLE STATUS LIKE 'table1'\PYGZbs{}G}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}    SHOW CREATE TABLE {}`table1{}`\PYGZbs{}G}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} EXPLAIN}
SELECT * FROM table1\PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}G}
\end{Verbatim}

This section is a convenience: if you're trying to optimize the queries you see
in the slow log, you probably want to examine the table structure and size.
These are copy-and-paste-ready commands to do that.

Finally, we see a sample of the queries in this class of query.  This is not a
random sample.  It is the query that performed the worst, according to the sort
order given by {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}}.  You will normally see a commented \code{\# EXPLAIN}
line just before it, so you can copy-paste the query to examine its EXPLAIN
plan. But for non-SELECT queries that isn't possible to do, so the tool tries to
transform the query into a roughly equivalent SELECT query, and adds that below.

If you want to find this sample event in the log, use the offset mentioned
above, and something like the following:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
tail -c +\textless{}offset\textgreater{} /path/to/file \textbar{} head
\end{Verbatim}

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-format]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}report-format}}}}.


\subsection{QUERY REVIEW}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:query-review}
A query {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}} is the process of storing all the query fingerprints
analyzed.  This has several benefits:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
You can add metadata to classes of queries, such as marking them for follow-up,
adding notes to queries, or marking them with an issue ID for your issue
tracking system.

\item {} 
You can refer to the stored values on subsequent runs so you'll know whether
you've seen a query before.  This can help you cut down on duplicated work.

\item {} 
You can store historical data such as the row count, query times, and generally
anything you can see in the report.

\end{itemize}

To use this feature, you run \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} with the {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}} option.  It
will store the fingerprints and other information into the table you specify.
Next time you run it with the same option, it will do the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
It won't show you queries you've already reviewed.  A query is considered to be
already reviewed if you've set a value for the \code{reviewed\_by} column.  (If you
want to see queries you've already reviewed, use the {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-all]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}report-all}}}} option.)

\item {} 
Queries that you've reviewed, and don't appear in the output, will cause gaps in
the query number sequence in the first line of each paragraph.  And the value
you've specified for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} will still be honored.  So if you've reviewed all
queries in the top 10 and you ask for the top 10, you won't see anything in the
output.

\item {} 
If you want to see the queries you've already reviewed, you can specify
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-all]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}report-all}}}}.  Then you'll see the normal analysis output, but you'll
also see the information from the review table, just below the execution time
graph.  For example,

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Review information}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}      comments: really bad IN() subquery, fix soon!}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}    first\PYGZus{}seen: 2008-12-01 11:48:57}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}   jira\PYGZus{}ticket: 1933}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}     last\PYGZus{}seen: 2008-12-18 11:49:07}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}      priority: high}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}   reviewed\PYGZus{}by: xaprb}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}   reviewed\PYGZus{}on: 2008-12-18 15:03:11}
\end{Verbatim}

This metadata is useful because, as you analyze your queries, you get
your comments integrated right into the report.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{FINGERPRINTS}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:fingerprints}
A query fingerprint is the abstracted form of a query, which makes it possible
to group similar queries together.  Abstracting a query removes literal values,
normalizes whitespace, and so on.  For example, consider these two queries:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT name, password FROM user WHERE \PYG{n+nv}{id}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'12823'};
\PYG{k}{select }name,   password from user
   where \PYG{n+nv}{id}\PYG{o}{=}5;
\end{Verbatim}

Both of those queries will fingerprint to

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{select }name, password from user where \PYG{n+nv}{id}\PYG{o}{=}?
\end{Verbatim}

Once the query's fingerprint is known, we can then talk about a query as though
it represents all similar queries.

What \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} does is analogous to a GROUP BY statement in SQL.  (But
note that ``multiple columns'' doesn't define a multi-column grouping; it defines
multiple reports!) If your command-line looks like this,

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-query-digest               \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    --group-by fingerprint    \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    --order-by Query\PYGZus{}time:sum \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    --limit 10                \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    slow.log
\end{Verbatim}

The corresponding pseudo-SQL looks like this:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT WORST\PYG{o}{(}query BY Query\PYGZus{}time\PYG{o}{)}, SUM\PYG{o}{(}Query\PYGZus{}time\PYG{o}{)}, ...
FROM /path/to/slow.log
GROUP BY FINGERPRINT\PYG{o}{(}query\PYG{o}{)}
ORDER BY SUM\PYG{o}{(}Query\PYGZus{}time\PYG{o}{)} DESC
LIMIT 10
\end{Verbatim}

You can also use the value \code{distill}, which is a kind of super-fingerprint.
See {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} for more.

Query fingerprinting accommodates many special cases, which have proven
necessary in the real world.  For example, an \code{IN} list with 5 literals
is really equivalent to one with 4 literals, so lists of literals are
collapsed to a single one.  If you find something that is not fingerprinted
properly, please submit a bug report with a reproducible test case.

Here is a list of transformations during fingerprinting, which might not
be exhaustive:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Group all SELECT queries from mariadb-dump together, even if they are against
different tables.  The same applies to all queries from pt-table-checksum.

\item {} 
Shorten multi-value INSERT statements to a single VALUES() list.

\item {} 
Strip comments.

\item {} 
Abstract the databases in USE statements, so all USE statements are grouped
together.

\item {} 
Replace all literals, such as quoted strings.  For efficiency, the code that
replaces literal numbers is somewhat non-selective, and might replace some
things as numbers when they really are not.  Hexadecimal literals are also
replaced.  NULL is treated as a literal.  Numbers embedded in identifiers are
also replaced, so tables named similarly will be fingerprinted to the same
values (e.g. users\_2009 and users\_2010 will fingerprint identically).

\item {} 
Collapse all whitespace into a single space.

\item {} 
Lowercase the entire query.

\item {} 
Replace all literals inside of IN() and VALUES() lists with a single
placeholder, regardless of cardinality.

\item {} 
Collapse multiple identical UNION queries into a single one.

\end{itemize}


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:options}
This tool accepts additional command-line arguments.  Refer to the
``SYNOPSIS'' and usage information for details.
\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--ask-pass}\index{--ask-pass!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--ask-pass}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ask-pass}\code{}}
Prompt for a password when connecting to MariaDB.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--attribute-aliases}\index{--attribute-aliases!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--attribute-aliases}\pysigline{\bfcode{--attribute-aliases}\code{}}
type: array; default: db\textbar{}Schema

List of attribute\textbar{}alias,etc.

Certain attributes have multiple names, like db and Schema.  If an event does
not have the primary attribute, \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} looks for an alias attribute.
If it finds an alias, it creates the primary attribute with the alias
attribute's value and removes the alias attribute.

If the event has the primary attribute, all alias attributes are deleted.

This helps simplify event attributes so that, for example, there will not
be report lines for both db and Schema.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--attribute-value-limit}\index{--attribute-value-limit!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--attribute-value-limit}\pysigline{\bfcode{--attribute-value-limit}\code{}}
type: int; default: 0

A sanity limit for attribute values.

This option deals with bugs in slow logging functionality that causes large
values for attributes.  If the attribute's value is bigger than this, the
last-seen value for that class of query is used instead.
Disabled by default.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--charset}\index{--charset!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--charset}\pysigline{\bfcode{--charset}\code{}}
short form: -A; type: string

Default character set.  If the value is utf8, sets Perl's binmode on
STDOUT to utf8, passes the mysql\_enable\_utf8 option to DBD::mysql, and
runs SET NAMES UTF8 after connecting to MariaDB.  Any other value sets
binmode on STDOUT without the utf8 layer, and runs SET NAMES after
connecting to MariaDB.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--config}\index{--config!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--config}\pysigline{\bfcode{--config}\code{}}
type: Array

Read this comma-separated list of config files; if specified, this must be the
first option on the command line.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--{[}no{]}continue-on-error}\index{--{[}no{]}continue-on-error!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}continue-on-error}}
default: yes

Continue parsing even if there is an error.  The tool will not continue
forever: it stops once any process causes 100 errors, in which case there
is probably a bug in the tool or the input is invalid.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--{[}no{]}create-history-table}\index{--{[}no{]}create-history-table!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}create-history-table}}
default: yes

Create the {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}} table if it does not exist.

This option causes the table specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}} to be created
with the default structure shown in the documentation for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--{[}no{]}create-review-table}\index{--{[}no{]}create-review-table!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}create-review-table}}
default: yes

Create the {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}} table if it does not exist.

This option causes the table specified by {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}} to be created
with the default structure shown in the documentation for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{fulllineitems}

short form: -D; type: string

Connect to this database.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--defaults-file}\index{--defaults-file!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--defaults-file}\pysigline{\bfcode{--defaults-file}\code{}}
short form: -F; type: string

Only read mariadb options from the given file.  You must give an absolute pathname.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--embedded-attributes}\index{--embedded-attributes!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--embedded-attributes}\pysigline{\bfcode{--embedded-attributes}\code{}}
type: array

Two Perl regex patterns to capture pseudo-attributes embedded in queries.

Embedded attributes might be special attribute-value pairs that you've hidden
in comments.  The first regex should match the entire set of attributes (in
case there are multiple).  The second regex should match and capture
attribute-value pairs from the first regex.

For example, suppose your query looks like the following:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT * from users -- file: /login.php, line: 493;
\end{Verbatim}

You might run \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} with the following option:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
:program:\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}mariadb-query-digest\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`} --embedded-attributes \PYG{l+s+s1}{' -- .*'},\PYG{l+s+s1}{'(\PYGZbs{}w+): ([\PYGZca{}\PYGZbs{},]+)'}
\end{Verbatim}

The first regular expression captures the whole comment:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{l+s+s2}{" -- file: /login.php, line: 493;"}
\end{Verbatim}

The second one splits it into attribute-value pairs and adds them to the event:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
ATTRIBUTE  \PYG{n+nv}{VALUE}
\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}  \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}
file       /login.php
line       493
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{NOTE}: All commas in the regex patterns must be escaped with otherwise
the pattern will break.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--expected-range}\index{--expected-range!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--expected-range}\pysigline{\bfcode{--expected-range}\code{}}
type: array; default: 5,10

Explain items when there are more or fewer than expected.

Defines the number of items expected to be seen in the report given by
\emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}report}}, as controlled by {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--outliers]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}outliers}}}}.  If
there  are more or fewer items in the report, each one will explain why it was
included.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--explain}\index{--explain!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--explain}\pysigline{\bfcode{--explain}\code{}}
type: DSN

Run EXPLAIN for the sample query with this DSN and print results.

This works only when {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} includes fingerprint.  It causes
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} to run EXPLAIN and include the output into the report.  For
safety, queries that appear to have a subquery that EXPLAIN will execute won't
be EXPLAINed.  Those are typically ``derived table'' queries of the form

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{select} ... from \PYG{o}{(} \PYG{k}{select} .... \PYG{o}{)} der;
\end{Verbatim}

The EXPLAIN results are printed as a full vertical format in the event report,
which appears at the end of each event report in vertical style
(\code{\textbackslash{}G}) just like MariaDB prints it.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--filter}\index{--filter!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter}\pysigline{\bfcode{--filter}\code{}}
type: string

Discard events for which this Perl code doesn't return true.

This option is a string of Perl code or a file containing Perl code that gets
compiled into a subroutine with one argument: \$event.  This is a hashref.
If the given value is a readable file, then \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} reads the entire
file and uses its contents as the code.  The file should not contain
a shebang (\#!/usr/bin/perl) line.

If the code returns true, the chain of callbacks continues; otherwise it ends.
The code is the last statement in the subroutine other than \code{return \$event}.
The subroutine template is:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sub \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{shift}; filter \PYG{o}{\&\&} \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event}; \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

Filters given on the command line are wrapped inside parentheses like like
\code{( filter )}.  For complex, multi-line filters, you must put the code inside
a file so it will not be wrapped inside parentheses.  Either way, the filter
must produce syntactically valid code given the template.  For example, an
if-else branch given on the command line would not be valid:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--filter \PYG{l+s+s1}{'if () \PYGZob{} \PYGZcb{} else \PYGZob{} \PYGZcb{}'}  \PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} WRONG}
\end{Verbatim}

Since it's given on the command line, the if-else branch would be wrapped inside
parentheses which is not syntactically valid.  So to accomplish something more
complex like this would require putting the code in a file, for example
filter.txt:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
my \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}; \PYG{k}{if} \PYG{o}{(}...\PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}\PYG{o}{=}1; \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{k}{else} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}\PYG{o}{=}0; \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event\PYGZus{}ok}
\end{Verbatim}

Then specify \code{-{-}filter filter.txt} to read the code from filter.txt.

If the filter code won't compile, \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} will die with an error.
If the filter code does compile, an error may still occur at runtime if the
code tries to do something wrong (like pattern match an undefined value).
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} does not provide any safeguards so code carefully!

An example filter that discards everything but SELECT statements:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--filter \PYG{l+s+s1}{'\PYGZdl{}event-\textgreater{}\PYGZob{}arg\PYGZcb{} =\PYGZti{} m/\PYGZca{}select/i'}
\end{Verbatim}

This is compiled into a subroutine like the following:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
sub \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{n+nb}{shift}; \PYG{o}{(} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event}-\textgreater{}\PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}arg\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}} \PYG{o}{=}\PYGZti{} m/\PYGZca{}select/i \PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{\&\&} \PYG{k}{return} \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}event}; \PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

It is permissible for the code to have side effects (to alter \code{\$event}).

See ``ATTRIBUTES REFERENCE'' for a list of common and {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}type}}}} specific
attributes.

Here are more examples of filter code:

Host/IP matches domain.com
\begin{quote}

--filter `(\$event-\textgreater{}\{host\} \textbar{}\textbar{} \$event-\textgreater{}\{ip\} \textbar{}\textbar{} ``'') =\textasciitilde{} m/domain.com/'

Sometimes MariaDB logs the host where the IP is expected.  Therefore, we
check both.
\end{quote}

User matches john
\begin{quote}

--filter `(\$event-\textgreater{}\{user\} \textbar{}\textbar{} ``'') =\textasciitilde{} m/john/'
\end{quote}

More than 1 warning
\begin{quote}

--filter `(\$event-\textgreater{}\{Warning\_count\} \textbar{}\textbar{} 0) \textgreater{} 1'
\end{quote}

Query does full table scan or full join
\begin{quote}

--filter `((\$event-\textgreater{}\{Full\_scan\} \textbar{}\textbar{} ``'') eq ``Yes'') \textbar{}\textbar{} ((\$event-\textgreater{}\{Full\_join\} \textbar{}\textbar{} ``'') eq ``Yes'')'
\end{quote}

Query was not served from query cache
\begin{quote}

--filter `(\$event-\textgreater{}\{QC\_Hit\} \textbar{}\textbar{} ``'') eq ``No'''
\end{quote}

Query is 1 MB or larger
\begin{quote}

--filter `\$event-\textgreater{}\{bytes\} \textgreater{}= 1\_048\_576'
\end{quote}

Since {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}filter}}}} allows you to alter \code{\$event}, you can use it to do other
things, like create new attributes.  See ``ATTRIBUTES'' for an example.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--group-by}\index{--group-by!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by}\pysigline{\bfcode{--group-by}\code{}}
type: Array; default: fingerprint

Which attribute of the events to group by.

In general, you can group queries into classes based on any attribute of the
query, such as \code{user} or \code{db}, which will by default show you which users
and which databases get the most \code{Query\_time}.  The default attribute,
\code{fingerprint}, groups similar, abstracted queries into classes; see below
and see also ``FINGERPRINTS''.

A report is printed for each {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} value (unless \code{-{-}no-report} is
given).  Therefore, \code{-{-}group-by user,db} means ``report on queries with the
same user and report on queries with the same db''; it does not mean ``report
on queries with the same user and db.''  See also ``OUTPUT''.

Every value must have a corresponding value in the same position in
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}}.  However, adding values to {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} will automatically
add values to {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}}, for your convenience.

There are several magical values that cause some extra data mining to happen
before the grouping takes place:

fingerprint
\begin{quote}

This causes events to be fingerprinted to abstract queries into
a canonical form, which is then used to group events together into a class.
See ``FINGERPRINTS'' for more about fingerprinting.
\end{quote}

tables
\begin{quote}

This causes events to be inspected for what appear to be tables, and
then aggregated by that.  Note that a query that contains two or more tables
will be counted as many times as there are tables; so a join against two tables
will count the Query\_time against both tables.
\end{quote}

distill
\begin{quote}

This is a sort of super-fingerprint that collapses queries down
into a suggestion of what they do, such as \code{INSERT SELECT table1 table2}.
\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--help}\pysigline{\bfcode{--help}\code{}}
Show help and exit.

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--history}\index{--history!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history}\pysigline{\bfcode{--history}\code{}}
type: DSN

Save metrics for each query class in the given table.  \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} saves
query metrics (query time, lock time, etc.) to this table so you can see how
query classes change over time.

The default table is \code{mariadb\_tools.query\_history}.  Specify database
(D) and table (t) DSN options to override the default.  The database and
table are automatically created unless \code{-{-}no-create-history-table}
is specified (see \emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}create-history-table}}).

\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} inspects the columns in the table.  The table must have at
least the following columns:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{CREATE} \PYG{k}{TABLE} \PYG{n}{query\PYGZus{}review\PYGZus{}history} \PYG{p}{(}
  \PYG{n}{checksum}     \PYG{n+nb}{CHAR}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{32}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{sample}       \PYG{n}{LONGTEXT} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL}
\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

Any columns not mentioned above are inspected to see if they follow a certain
naming convention.  The column is special if the name ends with an underscore
followed by any of these values:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
pct\textbar{}avg\textbar{}cnt\textbar{}sum\textbar{}min\textbar{}max\textbar{}pct\PYGZus{}95\textbar{}stddev\textbar{}median\textbar{}rank
\end{Verbatim}

If the column ends with one of those values, then the prefix is interpreted as
the event attribute to store in that column, and the suffix is interpreted as
the metric to be stored.  For example, a column named \code{Query\_time\_min} will be
used to store the minimum \code{Query\_time} for the class of events.

The table should also have a primary key, but that is up to you, depending on
how you want to store the historical data.  We suggest adding ts\_min and ts\_max
columns and making them part of the primary key along with the checksum.  But
you could also just add a ts\_min column and make it a DATE type, so you'd get
one row per class of queries per day.

The following table definition is used for \emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}create-history-table}}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{CREATE} \PYG{k}{TABLE} \PYG{n}{IF} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{EXISTS} \PYG{n}{query\PYGZus{}history} \PYG{p}{(}
  \PYG{n}{checksum}             \PYG{n+nb}{CHAR}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{32}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{sample}               \PYG{n}{LONGTEXT} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{ts\PYGZus{}min}               \PYG{n}{DATETIME}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{ts\PYGZus{}max}               \PYG{n}{DATETIME}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{ts\PYGZus{}cnt}               \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Query\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}sum}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Query\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}min}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Query\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}max}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Query\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}pct\PYGZus{}95}    \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Query\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}stddev}    \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Query\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}median}    \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Lock\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}sum}        \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Lock\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}min}        \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Lock\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}max}        \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Lock\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}pct\PYGZus{}95}     \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Lock\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}stddev}     \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Lock\PYGZus{}time\PYGZus{}median}     \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Rows\PYGZus{}sent\PYGZus{}sum}        \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}

  \PYG{n}{Rows\PYGZus{}sent\PYGZus{}max}        \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Rows\PYGZus{}sent\PYGZus{}pct\PYGZus{}95}     \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Rows\PYGZus{}sent\PYGZus{}stddev}     \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
