  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}IO\PYGZus{}r\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}pct\PYGZus{}95}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}IO\PYGZus{}r\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}stddev}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}IO\PYGZus{}r\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}median}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}rec\PYGZus{}lock\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}min}      \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}rec\PYGZus{}lock\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}max}      \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}rec\PYGZus{}lock\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}pct\PYGZus{}95}   \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}rec\PYGZus{}lock\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}stddev}   \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}rec\PYGZus{}lock\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}median}   \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}queue\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}min}         \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}queue\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}max}         \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}queue\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}pct\PYGZus{}95}      \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}queue\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}stddev}      \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}queue\PYGZus{}wait\PYGZus{}median}      \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}pages\PYGZus{}distinct\PYGZus{}min}     \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}pages\PYGZus{}distinct\PYGZus{}max}     \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}pages\PYGZus{}distinct\PYGZus{}pct\PYGZus{}95}  \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}pages\PYGZus{}distinct\PYGZus{}stddev}  \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{InnoDB\PYGZus{}pages\PYGZus{}distinct\PYGZus{}median}  \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{c+c1}{-- Boolean (Yes/No) attributes.  Only the cnt and sum are needed}
  \PYG{c+c1}{-- for these.  cnt is how many times is attribute was recorded,}
  \PYG{c+c1}{-- and sum is how many of those times the value was Yes.  So}
  \PYG{c+c1}{-- sum/cnt * 100 equals the percentage of recorded times that}
  \PYG{c+c1}{-- the value was Yes.}
  \PYG{n}{QC\PYGZus{}Hit\PYGZus{}cnt}          \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{QC\PYGZus{}Hit\PYGZus{}sum}          \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Full\PYGZus{}scan\PYGZus{}cnt}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Full\PYGZus{}scan\PYGZus{}sum}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Full\PYGZus{}join\PYGZus{}cnt}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Full\PYGZus{}join\PYGZus{}sum}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Tmp\PYGZus{}table\PYGZus{}cnt}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Tmp\PYGZus{}table\PYGZus{}sum}       \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Tmp\PYGZus{}table\PYGZus{}on\PYGZus{}disk\PYGZus{}cnt} \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Tmp\PYGZus{}table\PYGZus{}on\PYGZus{}disk\PYGZus{}sum} \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Filesort\PYGZus{}cnt}          \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Filesort\PYGZus{}sum}          \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Filesort\PYGZus{}on\PYGZus{}disk\PYGZus{}cnt}  \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{n}{Filesort\PYGZus{}on\PYGZus{}disk\PYGZus{}sum}  \PYG{n+nb}{FLOAT}\PYG{p}{,}
  \PYG{k}{PRIMARY} \PYG{k}{KEY}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{n}{checksum}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ts\PYGZus{}min}\PYG{p}{,} \PYG{n}{ts\PYGZus{}max}\PYG{p}{)}
\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{;}
\end{Verbatim}

Note that we store the count (cnt) for the ts attribute only; it will be
redundant to store this for other attributes.

Starting from MariaDB Toolkit 3.0.11, the checksum function has been updated to use 32 chars in the MD5 sum.
This causes the checksum field in the history table will have a different value than in the previous versions of the tool.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--host}\index{--host!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--host}\pysigline{\bfcode{--host}\code{}}
short form: -h; type: string

Connect to host.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--ignore-attributes}\index{--ignore-attributes!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--ignore-attributes}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ignore-attributes}\code{}}
type: array; default: arg, cmd, insert\_id, ip, port, Thread\_id, timestamp, exptime, flags, key, res, val, server\_id, offset, end\_log\_pos, Xid

Do not aggregate these attributes.  Some attributes are not query metrics
but metadata which doesn't need to be (or can't be) aggregated.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--inherit-attributes}\index{--inherit-attributes!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--inherit-attributes}\pysigline{\bfcode{--inherit-attributes}\code{}}
type: array; default: db,ts

If missing, inherit these attributes from the last event that had them.

This option sets which attributes are inherited or carried forward to events
which do not have them.  For example, if one event has the db attribute equal
to ``foo'', but the next event doesn't have the db attribute, then it inherits
``foo'' for its db attribute.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--interval}\index{--interval!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--interval}\pysigline{\bfcode{--interval}\code{}}
type: float; default: .1

How frequently to poll the processlist, in seconds.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--iterations}\index{--iterations!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations}\pysigline{\bfcode{--iterations}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

How many times to iterate through the collect-and-report cycle.  If 0, iterate
to infinity.  Each iteration runs for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} amount of time.  An
iteration is usually determined by an amount of time and a report is printed
when that amount of time elapses.  With {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time-mode]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time-mode}}}} \code{interval},
an interval is instead determined by the interval time you specify with
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}}.  See {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time-mode]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time-mode}}}} for more
information.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--limit}\index{--limit!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--limit}\pysigline{\bfcode{--limit}\code{}}
type: Array; default: 95\%:20

Limit output to the given percentage or count.

If the argument is an integer, report only the top N worst queries.  If the
argument is an integer followed by the \code{\%} sign, report that percentage of the
worst queries.  If the percentage is followed by a colon and another integer,
report the top percentage or the number specified by that integer, whichever
comes first.

The value is actually a comma-separated array of values, one for each item in
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}}.  If you don't specify a value for any of those items, the
default is the top 95\%.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--outliers]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}outliers}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--log}\index{--log!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--log}\pysigline{\bfcode{--log}\code{}}
type: string

Print all output to this file when daemonized.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--max-hostname-length}\index{--max-hostname-length!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--max-hostname-length}\pysigline{\bfcode{--max-hostname-length}\code{}}
type: int; default: 10

Trim host names in reports to this length. 0=Do not trim host names.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--max-line-length}\index{--max-line-length!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--max-line-length}\pysigline{\bfcode{--max-line-length}\code{}}
type: int; default: 74

Trim lines to this length. 0=Do not trim lines.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--order-by}\index{--order-by!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by}\pysigline{\bfcode{--order-by}\code{}}
type: Array; default: Query\_time:sum

Sort events by this attribute and aggregate function.

This is a comma-separated list of order-by expressions, one for each
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} attribute.  The default \code{Query\_time:sum} is used for
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} attributes without explicitly given {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}} attributes
(that is, if you specify more {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} attributes than corresponding
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}} attributes).  The syntax is \code{attribute:aggregate}.  See
``ATTRIBUTES'' for valid attributes.  Valid aggregates are:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
Aggregate \PYG{n+nv}{Meaning}
\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}
sum       Sum/total attribute value
min       Minimum attribute value
max       Maximum attribute value
cnt       Frequency/count of the query
\end{Verbatim}

For example, the default \code{Query\_time:sum} means that queries in the
query analysis report will be ordered (sorted) by their total query execution
time (``Exec time'').  \code{Query\_time:max} orders the queries by their
maximum query execution time, so the query with the single largest
\code{Query\_time} will be list first.  \code{cnt} refers more to the frequency
of the query as a whole, how often it appears; ``Count'' is its corresponding
line in the query analysis report.  So any attribute and \code{cnt} should yield
the same report wherein queries are sorted by the number of times they
appear.

When parsing general logs ({\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}type}}}} \code{genlog}), the default {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}}
becomes \code{Query\_time:cnt}.  General logs do not report query times so only
the \code{cnt} aggregate makes sense because all query times are zero.

If you specify an attribute that doesn't exist in the events, then
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} falls back to the default \code{Query\_time:sum} and prints a notice
at the beginning of the report for each query class.  You can create attributes
with {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}filter}}}} and order by them; see ``ATTRIBUTES'' for an example.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--outliers}\index{--outliers!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--outliers}\pysigline{\bfcode{--outliers}\code{}}
type: array; default: Query\_time:1:10

Report outliers by attribute:percentile:count.

The syntax of this option is a comma-separated list of colon-delimited strings.
The first field is the attribute by which an outlier is defined.  The second is
a number that is compared to the attribute's 95th percentile.  The third is
optional, and is compared to the attribute's cnt aggregate.  Queries that pass
this specification are added to the report, regardless of any limits you
specified in {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--limit]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}limit}}}}.

For example, to report queries whose 95th percentile Query\_time is at least 60
seconds and which are seen at least 5 times, use the following argument:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--outliers Query\PYGZus{}time:60:5
\end{Verbatim}

You can specify an --outliers option for each value in {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--output}\index{--output!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--output}\pysigline{\bfcode{--output}\code{}}
type: string; default: report

How to format and print the query analysis results.  Accepted values are:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
VALUE          \PYG{n+nv}{FORMAT}
\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}        \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}
report         Standard query analysis report
slowlog        MariaDB slow log
json           JSON, on array per query class
json-anon      JSON without example queries
secure-slowlog JSON without example queries
\end{Verbatim}

The entire \code{report} output can be disabled by specifying \code{-{-}no-report}
(see \emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}report}}), and its sections can be disabled or rearranged
by specifying {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-format]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}report-format}}}}.

\code{json} output was introduced in 2.2.1 and is still in development,
so the data structure may change in future versions.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--password}\index{--password!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--password}\pysigline{\bfcode{--password}\code{}}
short form: -p; type: string

Password to use when connecting.
If password contains commas they must be escaped with a backslash: ``exam,ple''

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--pid}\index{--pid!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--pid}\pysigline{\bfcode{--pid}\code{}}
type: string

Create the given PID file.  The tool won't start if the PID file already
exists and the PID it contains is different than the current PID.  However,
if the PID file exists and the PID it contains is no longer running, the
tool will overwrite the PID file with the current PID.  The PID file is
removed automatically when the tool exits.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--port}\index{--port!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--port}\pysigline{\bfcode{--port}\code{}}
short form: -P; type: int

Port number to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--preserve-embedded-numbers}\index{--preserve-embedded-numbers!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--preserve-embedded-numbers}\pysigline{\bfcode{--preserve-embedded-numbers}\code{}}
Preserve numbers in database/table names when fingerprinting queries.
The standar fingeprint method replaces numbers in db/tables names, making
a query like `SELECT * FROM db1.table2' to be figerprinted as `SELECT * FROM db?.table?'.
This option changes that behaviour and the fingerprint will become
`SELECT * FROM db1.table2'.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--processlist}\index{--processlist!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--processlist}\pysigline{\bfcode{--processlist}\code{}}
type: DSN

Poll this DSN's processlist for queries, with {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}} sleep between.

If the connection fails, \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} tries to reopen it once per second.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--progress}\index{--progress!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--progress}\pysigline{\bfcode{--progress}\code{}}
type: array; default: time,30

Print progress reports to STDERR.  The value is a comma-separated list with two
parts.  The first part can be percentage, time, or iterations; the second part
specifies how often an update should be printed, in percentage, seconds, or
number of iterations.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--read-timeout}\index{--read-timeout!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--read-timeout}\pysigline{\bfcode{--read-timeout}\code{}}
type: time; default: 0

Wait this long for an event from the input; 0 to wait forever.

This option sets the maximum time to wait for an event from the input.  It
applies to all types of input except {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--processlist]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}processlist}}}}.  If an
event is not received after the specified time, the script stops reading the
input and prints its reports.  If {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}} is 0 or greater than
1, the next iteration will begin, else the script will exit.

This option requires the Perl POSIX module.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--{[}no{]}report}\index{--{[}no{]}report!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}report}}
default: yes

Print query analysis reports for each {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}} attribute.  This is
the standard slow log analysis functionality.  See ``OUTPUT'' for the
description of what this does and what the results look like.

If you don't need a report (for example, when using {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}} or
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}}), it is best to specify \code{-{-}no-report} because this allows
the tool to skip some expensive operations.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--report-all}\index{--report-all!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-all}\pysigline{\bfcode{--report-all}\code{}}
Report all queries, even ones that have been reviewed.  This only affects
the \code{report} {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--output]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}output}}}} when using {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}}.  Otherwise, all
queries are always printed.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--report-format}\index{--report-format!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-format}\pysigline{\bfcode{--report-format}\code{}}
type: Array; default: rusage,date,hostname,files,header,profile,query\_report,prepared

Print these sections of the query analysis report.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SECTION      \PYG{n+nv}{PRINTS}
\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}
rusage       CPU \PYG{n+nb}{times }and memory usage reported by ps
date         Current \PYG{n+nb}{local }date and \PYG{n+nb}{time}
hostname     Hostname of machine on which :program:\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}mariadb-query-digest\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`} was run
files        Input files \PYG{n+nb}{read}/parse
header       Summary of the entire analysis run
profile      Compact table of queries \PYG{k}{for }an overview of the report
query\PYGZus{}report Detailed information about each unique query
prepared     Prepared statements
\end{Verbatim}

The sections are printed in the order specified.  The rusage, date, files and
header sections are grouped together if specified together; other sections are
separated by blank lines.

See ``OUTPUT'' for more information on the various parts of the query report.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--report-histogram}\index{--report-histogram!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-histogram}\pysigline{\bfcode{--report-histogram}\code{}}
type: string; default: Query\_time

Chart the distribution of this attribute's values.

The distribution chart is limited to time-based attributes, so charting
\code{Rows\_examined}, for example, will produce a useless chart.  Charts look
like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} Query\PYGZus{}time distribution}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}   1us}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}  10us}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 100us}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}   1ms}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}  10ms  \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 100ms  \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}    1s  \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{}  10s+}
\end{Verbatim}

See ``OUTPUT'' for more information.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--resume}\index{--resume!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--resume}\pysigline{\bfcode{--resume}\code{}}
type: string

If specified, the tool writes the last file offset, if there is one,
to the given filename. When ran again with the same value for this option,
the tool reads the last file offset from the file, seeks to that position
in the log, and resumes parsing events from that point onward.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--review}\index{--review!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review}\pysigline{\bfcode{--review}\code{}}
type: DSN

Save query classes for later review, and don't report already reviewed classes.

The default table is \code{mariadb\_tools.query\_review}.  Specify database
(D) and table (t) DSN options to override the default.  The database and
table are automatically created unless \code{-{-}no-create-review-table}
is specified (see \emph{\texttt{-{-}{[}no{]}create-review-table}}).

If the table was created manually, it must have at least the following columns.
You can add more columns for your own special purposes, but they won't be used
by \textbf{mariadb-query-digest}.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{CREATE} \PYG{k}{TABLE} \PYG{n}{IF} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{EXISTS} \PYG{n}{query\PYGZus{}review} \PYG{p}{(}
   \PYG{n}{checksum}     \PYG{n+nb}{CHAR}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{32}\PYG{p}{)} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL} \PYG{k}{PRIMARY} \PYG{k}{KEY}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{fingerprint}  \PYG{n+nb}{TEXT} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{sample}       \PYG{n+nb}{TEXT} \PYG{k}{NOT} \PYG{k}{NULL}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{first\PYGZus{}seen}   \PYG{n}{DATETIME}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{last\PYGZus{}seen}    \PYG{n}{DATETIME}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{reviewed\PYGZus{}by}  \PYG{n+nb}{VARCHAR}\PYG{p}{(}\PYG{l+m+mi}{20}\PYG{p}{)}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{reviewed\PYGZus{}on}  \PYG{n}{DATETIME}\PYG{p}{,}
   \PYG{n}{comments}     \PYG{n+nb}{TEXT}
\PYG{p}{)}
\end{Verbatim}

The columns are:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
COLUMN       \PYG{n+nv}{MEANING}
\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}  \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}
checksum     A 64-bit checksum of the query fingerprint
fingerprint  The abstracted version of the query; its primary key
sample       The query text of a sample of the class of queries
first\PYGZus{}seen   The smallest timestamp of this class of queries
last\PYGZus{}seen    The largest timestamp of this class of queries
reviewed\PYGZus{}by  Initially NULL; \PYG{k}{if }\PYG{n+nb}{set}, query is skipped thereafter
reviewed\PYGZus{}on  Initially NULL; not assigned any special meaning
comments     Initially NULL; not assigned any special meaning
\end{Verbatim}

Note that the \code{fingerprint} column is the true primary key for a class of
queries.  The \code{checksum} is just a cryptographic hash of this value, which
provides a shorter value that is very likely to also be unique.

After parsing and aggregating events, your table should contain a row for each
fingerprint.  This option depends on \code{-{-}group-by fingerprint} (which is the
default).  It will not work otherwise.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--run-time}\index{--run-time!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--run-time}\code{}}
type: time

How long to run for each {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}}.  The default is to run forever
(you can interrupt with CTRL-C).  Because {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}} defaults to 1,
if you only specify {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}}, \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} runs for that amount of
time and then exits.  The two options are specified together to do
collect-and-report cycles.  For example, specifying {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}} \code{4}
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} \code{15m} with a continuous input (like STDIN or
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--processlist]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}processlist}}}}) will cause \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} to run for 1 hour
(15 minutes x 4), reporting four times, once at each 15 minute interval.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--run-time-mode}\index{--run-time-mode!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time-mode}\pysigline{\bfcode{--run-time-mode}\code{}}
type: string; default: clock

Set what the value of {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} operates on.  Following are the possible
values for this option:

clock
\begin{quote}

{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} specifies an amount of real clock time during which the tool
should run for each {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}}.
\end{quote}

event
\begin{quote}

{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} specifies an amount of log time.  Log time is determined by
timestamps in the log.  The first timestamp seen is remembered, and each
timestamp after that is compared to the first to determine how much log time
has passed.  For example, if the first timestamp seen is \code{12:00:00} and the
next is \code{12:01:30}, that is 1 minute and 30 seconds of log time.  The tool
will read events until the log time is greater than or equal to the specified
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} value.

Since timestamps in logs are not always printed, or not always printed
frequently, this mode varies in accuracy.
\end{quote}

interval
\begin{quote}

{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} specifies interval boundaries of log time into which events
are divided and reports are generated.  This mode is different from the
others because it doesn't specify how long to run.  The value of
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} must be an interval that divides evenly into minutes, hours
or days.  For example, \code{5m} divides evenly into hours (60/5=12, so 12
5 minutes intervals per hour) but \code{7m} does not (60/7=8.6).

Specifying \code{-{-}run-time-mode interval -{-}run-time 30m -{-}iterations 0} is
similar to specifying \code{-{-}run-time-mode clock -{-}run-time 30m -{-}iterations 0}.
In the latter case, \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} will run forever, producing reports every
30 minutes, but this only works effectively with  continuous inputs like
STDIN and the processlist.  For fixed inputs, like log files, the former
example produces multiple reports by dividing the log into 30 minutes
intervals based on timestamps.

Intervals are calculated from the zeroth second/minute/hour in which a
timestamp occurs, not from whatever time it specifies.  For example,
with 30 minute intervals and a timestamp of \code{12:10:30}, the interval
is \emph{not} \code{12:10:30} to \code{12:40:30}, it is \code{12:00:00} to \code{12:29:59}.
Or, with 1 hour intervals, it is \code{12:00:00} to \code{12:59:59}.
When a new timestamp exceeds the interval, a report is printed, and the
next interval is recalculated based on the new timestamp.

Since {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}} is 1 by default, you probably want to specify
a new value else \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} will only get and report on the first
interval from the log since 1 interval = 1 iteration.  If you want to
get and report every interval in a log, specify {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}} \code{0}.
\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--sample}\index{--sample!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--sample}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sample}\code{}}
type: int

Filter out all but the first N occurrences of each query.  The queries are
filtered on the first value in {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}}, so by default, this will filter
by query fingerprint.  For example, \code{-{-}sample 2} will permit two sample queries
for each fingerprint.  Useful in conjunction with \code{-{-}output slowlog} to print
the queries.  You probably want to set \code{-{-}no-report} to avoid the overhead of
aggregating and reporting if you're just using this to print out samples of
queries.  A complete example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
:program:\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}mariadb-query-digest\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`} --sample 2 --no-report --output slowlog slow.log
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--slave-user}\index{--slave-user!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--slave-user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--slave-user}\code{}}
type: string

Sets the user to be used to connect to the slaves.
This parameter allows you to have a different user with less privileges on the
slaves but that user must exist on all slaves.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--slave-password}\index{--slave-password!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--slave-password}\pysigline{\bfcode{--slave-password}\code{}}
type: string

Sets the password to be used to connect to the slaves.
It can be used with --slave-user and the password for the user must be the same
on all slaves.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--set-vars}\index{--set-vars!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--set-vars}\pysigline{\bfcode{--set-vars}\code{}}
type: Array

Set the MariaDB variables in this comma-separated list of \code{variable=value} pairs.

By default, the tool sets:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{wait\PYGZus{}timeout}\PYG{o}{=}10000
\end{Verbatim}

Variables specified on the command line override these defaults.  For
example, specifying \code{-{-}set-vars wait\_timeout=500} overrides the defaultvalue of \code{10000}.

The tool prints a warning and continues if a variable cannot be set.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--show-all}\index{--show-all!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--show-all}\pysigline{\bfcode{--show-all}\code{}}
type: Hash

Show all values for these attributes.

By default \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} only shows as many of an attribute's value that
fit on a single line.  This option allows you to specify attributes for which
all values will be shown (line width is ignored).  This only works for
attributes with string values like user, host, db, etc.  Multiple attributes
can be specified, comma-separated.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--since}\index{--since!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--since}\pysigline{\bfcode{--since}\code{}}
type: string

Parse only queries newer than this value (parse queries since this date).

This option allows you to ignore queries older than a certain value and parse
only those queries which are more recent than the value.  The value can be
several types:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
* Simple \PYG{n+nb}{time }value N with optional suffix: N\PYG{o}{[}shmd\PYG{o}{]}, where
  \PYG{n+nv}{s}\PYG{o}{=}seconds, \PYG{n+nv}{h}\PYG{o}{=}hours, \PYG{n+nv}{m}\PYG{o}{=}minutes, \PYG{n+nv}{d}\PYG{o}{=}days \PYG{o}{(}default s \PYG{k}{if }no suffix
  given\PYG{o}{)}; this is like saying \PYG{l+s+s2}{"since N[shmd] ago"}
* Full date with optional hours:minutes:seconds:
  YYYY-MM-DD \PYG{o}{[}HH:MM:SS\PYG{o}{]}
* Short, MariaDB-style date:
  YYMMDD \PYG{o}{[}HH:MM:SS\PYG{o}{]}
* Any \PYG{n+nb}{time }expression evaluated by MariaDB:
  CURRENT\PYGZus{}DATE - INTERVAL 7 DAY
\end{Verbatim}

If you give a MariaDB time expression, and you have not also specified a DSN
for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--explain]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}explain}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--processlist]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}processlist}}}}, or {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}}, then you must specify
a DSN on the command line so that \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} can connect to MariaDB to
evaluate the expression.

The MariaDB time expression is wrapped inside a query like
``SELECT UNIX\_TIMESTAMP(\textless{}expression\textgreater{})'', so be sure that the expression is
valid inside this query.  For example, do not use UNIX\_TIMESTAMP() because
UNIX\_TIMESTAMP(UNIX\_TIMESTAMP()) returns 0.

Events are assumed to be in chronological: older events at the beginning of
the log and newer events at the end of the log.  {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--since]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}since}}}} is strict: it
ignores all queries until one is found that is new enough.  Therefore, if
the query events are not consistently timestamped, some may be ignored which
are actually new enough.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--until]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}until}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--socket}\index{--socket!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--socket}\pysigline{\bfcode{--socket}\code{}}
short form: -S; type: string

Socket file to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--timeline}\index{--timeline!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--timeline}\pysigline{\bfcode{--timeline}\code{}}
Show a timeline of events.

This option makes \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} print another kind of report: a timeline of
the events.  Each query is still grouped and aggregate into classes according to
{\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--group-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}group-by}}}}, but then they are printed in chronological order.  The timeline
report prints out the timestamp, interval, count and value of each classes.

If all you want is the timeline report, then specify \code{-{-}no-report} to
suppress the default query analysis report.  Otherwise, the timeline report
will be printed at the end before the response-time profile
(see {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--report-format]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}report-format}}}} and ``OUTPUT'').

For example, this:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
:program:\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}mariadb-query-digest\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`} /path/to/log --group-by distill --timeline
\end{Verbatim}

will print something like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} distill report}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} \PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}\PYGZsh{}}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 2009-07-25 11:19:27 1+00:00:01   2 SELECT foo}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 2009-07-27 11:19:30      00:01   2 SELECT bar}
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} 2009-07-27 11:30:00 1+06:30:00   2 SELECT foo}
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--type}\index{--type!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type}\pysigline{\bfcode{--type}\code{}}
type: Array; default: slowlog

The type of input to parse.  The permitted types are

binlog
\begin{quote}

Parse a binary log file that has first been converted to text using mariadb-binlog.

For example:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-binlog mariadb-bin.000441 \textgreater{} mariadb-bin.000441.txt

:program:\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}mariadb-query-digest\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`} --type binlog mariadb-bin.000441.txt
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

genlog
\begin{quote}

Parse a MariaDB general log file.  General logs lack a lot of ``ATTRIBUTES'',
notably \code{Query\_time}.  The default {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--order-by]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}order-by}}}} for general logs
changes to \code{Query\_time:cnt}.
\end{quote}

slowlog
\begin{quote}

Parse a log file in any variation of MariaDB slow log format.
\end{quote}

tcpdump
\begin{quote}

Inspect network packets and decode the MariaDB client protocol, extracting queries
and responses from it.

\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} does not actually watch the network (i.e. it does NOT ``sniff
packets'').  Instead, it's just parsing the output of tcpdump.  You are
responsible for generating this output; \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} does not do it for you.
Then you send this to \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} as you would any log file: as files on the
command line or to STDIN.

The parser expects the input to be formatted with the following options: \code{-x -n
-q -tttt}.  For example, if you want to capture output from your local machine,
you can do something like the following (the port must come last on FreeBSD):

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
tcpdump -s 65535 -x -nn -q -tttt -i any -c 1000 port 3306 \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
  \textgreater{} mariadb.tcp.txt
:program:\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`}mariadb-query-digest\PYG{l+s+sb}{{}`} --type tcpdump mariadb.tcp.txt
\end{Verbatim}

The other tcpdump parameters, such as -s, -c, and -i, are up to you.  Just make
sure the output looks like this (there is a line break in the first line to
avoid man-page problems):

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
2009-04-12 09:50:16.804849 IP 127.0.0.1.42167
       \textgreater{} 127.0.0.1.3306: tcp 37
    0x0000:  4508 0059 6eb2 4000 4006 cde2 7f00 0001
    0x0010:  ....
\end{Verbatim}

Remember tcpdump has a handy -c option to stop after it captures some number of
packets!  That's very useful for testing your tcpdump command.  Note that
tcpdump can't capture traffic on a Unix socket.  Read
\href{http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=31577}{http://bugs.mysql.com/bug.php?id=31577} if you're confused about this.

Devananda Van Der Veen explained on the MySQL Performance Blog how to capture
traffic without dropping packets on busy servers.  Dropped packets cause
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} to miss the response to a request, then see the response to a
later request and assign the wrong execution time to the query.  You can change
the filter to something like the following to help capture a subset of the
queries.  (See \href{http://www.mysqlperformanceblog.com/?p=6092}{http://www.mysqlperformanceblog.com/?p=6092} for details.)

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
tcpdump -i any -s 65535 -x -n -q -tttt \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
   \PYG{l+s+s1}{'port 3306 and tcp[1] \& 7 == 2 and tcp[3] \& 7 == 2'}
\end{Verbatim}

All MariaDB servers running on port 3306 are automatically detected in the
tcpdump output.  Therefore, if the tcpdump out contains packets from
multiple servers on port 3306 (for example, 10.0.0.1:3306, 10.0.0.2:3306,
etc.), all packets/queries from all these servers will be analyzed
together as if they were one server.

If you're analyzing traffic for a MariaDB server that is not running on port
3306, see {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--watch-server]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}watch-server}}}}.

Also note that \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} may fail to report the database for queries
when parsing tcpdump output.  The database is discovered only in the initial
connect events for a new client or when \textless{}USE db\textgreater{} is executed.  If the tcpdump
output contains neither of these, then \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} cannot discover the
database.

Server-side prepared statements are supported.  SSL-encrypted traffic cannot be
inspected and decoded.
\end{quote}

rawlog
\begin{quote}

Raw logs are not MariaDB logs but simple text files with one SQL statement
per line, like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
SELECT c FROM t WHERE \PYG{n+nv}{id}\PYG{o}{=}1
/* Hello, world! */ SELECT * FROM t2 LIMIT 1
INSERT INTO t \PYG{o}{(}a, b\PYG{o}{)} VALUES \PYG{o}{(}\PYG{l+s+s1}{'foo'}, \PYG{l+s+s1}{'bar'}\PYG{o}{)}
INSERT INTO t SELECT * FROM monkeys
\end{Verbatim}

Since raw logs do not have any metrics, many options and features of
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} do not work with them.

One use case for raw logs is ranking queries by count when the only
information available is a list of queries, from polling \code{SHOW PROCESSLIST}
for example.
\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--until}\index{--until!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--until}\pysigline{\bfcode{--until}\code{}}
type: string

Parse only queries older than this value (parse queries until this date).

This option allows you to ignore queries newer than a certain value and parse
only those queries which are older than the value.  The value can be one of
the same types listed for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--since]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}since}}}}.

Unlike {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--since]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}since}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--until]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}until}}}} is not strict: all queries are parsed until
one has a timestamp that is equal to or greater than {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--until]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}until}}}}.  Then
all subsequent queries are ignored.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--user}\index{--user!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--user}\code{}}
short form: -u; type: string

User for login if not current user.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--variations}\index{--variations!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--variations}\pysigline{\bfcode{--variations}\code{}}
type: Array

Report the number of variations in these attributes' values.

Variations show how many distinct values an attribute had within a class.
The usual value for this option is \code{arg} which shows how many distinct queries
were in the class.  This can be useful to determine a query's cacheability.

Distinct values are determined by CRC32 checksums of the attributes' values.
These checksums are reported in the query report for attributes specified by
this option, like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{c}{\PYGZsh{} arg crc      109 (1/25\PYGZpc{}), 144 (1/25\PYGZpc{})... 2 more}
\end{Verbatim}

In that class there were 4 distinct queries.  The checksums of the first two
variations are shown, and each one occurred once (or, 25\% of the time).

The counts of distinct variations is approximate because only 1,000 variations
are saved.  The mod (\%) 1000 of the full CRC32 checksum is saved, so some
distinct checksums are treated as equal.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--version}\index{--version!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--version}\pysigline{\bfcode{--version}\code{}}
Show version and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--{[}no{]}vertical-format}\index{--{[}no{]}vertical-format!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--}\pysigline{\bfcode{--}\code{{[}no{]}vertical-format}}
default: yes

Output a trailing ``G'' in the reported SQL queries.

This makes the mariadb client display the result using vertical format.
Non-native MariaDB clients like phpMyAdmin do not support this.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-query-digest command line option!--watch-server}\index{--watch-server!mariadb-query-digest command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--watch-server}\pysigline{\bfcode{--watch-server}\code{}}
type: string

This option tells \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} which server IP address and port (like
``10.0.0.1:3306'') to watch when parsing tcpdump (for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}type}}}} tcpdump);
all other servers are ignored.  If you don't specify it,
\textbf{mariadb-query-digest} watches all servers by looking for any IP address using port
3306 or ``mariadb''.  If you're watching a server with a non-standard port, this
won't work, so you must specify the IP address and port to watch.

If you want to watch a mix of servers, some running on standard port 3306
and some running on non-standard ports, you need to create separate
tcpdump outputs for the non-standard port servers and then specify this
option for each.  At present \textbf{mariadb-query-digest} cannot auto-detect servers on
port 3306 and also be told to watch a server on a non-standard port.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{DSN OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:dsn-options}
These DSN options are used to create a DSN.  Each option is given like
\code{option=value}.  The options are case-sensitive, so P and p are not the
same option.  There cannot be whitespace before or after the \code{=} and
if the value contains whitespace it must be quoted.  DSN options are
comma-separated.  See the mariadb-tools manpage for full details.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
A

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: charset; copy: yes

Default character set.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
D

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: database; copy: yes

Default database to use when connecting to MariaDB.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
F

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: mysql\_read\_default\_file; copy: yes

Only read default options from the given file.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
h

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: host; copy: yes

Connect to host.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
p

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: password; copy: yes

Password to use when connecting.
If password contains commas they must be escaped with a backslash: ``exam,ple''
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
P

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: port; copy: yes

Port number to use for connection.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
S

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: mysql\_socket; copy: yes

Socket file to use for connection.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
t

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

The {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--review]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}review}}}} or {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--history]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}history}}}} table.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
u

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

dsn: user; copy: yes

User for login if not current user.
\end{quote}


\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:environment}
The environment variable \code{PTDEBUG} enables verbose debugging output to STDERR.
To enable debugging and capture all output to a file, run the tool like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{PTDEBUG}\PYG{o}{=}1 mariadb-query-digest ... \textgreater{} FILE 2\textgreater{}\&1
\end{Verbatim}

Be careful: debugging output is voluminous and can generate several megabytes
of output.


\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:system-requirements}
You need Perl, DBI, DBD::mysql, and some core packages that ought to be
installed in any reasonably new version of Perl.


\subsection{ATTRIBUTES REFERENCE}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:attributes-reference}
Events may have the following attributes.  If writing a {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--filter]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}filter}}}},
be sure to check that an attribute is defined in each event before
using it, else the filter code may crash the tool with a
``use of uninitialized value'' error.

You can dump event attributes for any input like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{} }mariadb-query-digest                  \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    slow.log                       \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    --filter \PYG{l+s+s1}{'print Dumper \PYGZdl{}event'} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    --no-report                    \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
    --sample 1
\end{Verbatim}

That will produce a lot of output with ``attribute =\textgreater{} value'' pairs like:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}VAR1} \PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
  \PYG{n+nv}{Query\PYGZus{}time} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'0.033384'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{Rows\PYGZus{}examined} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'0'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{Rows\PYGZus{}sent} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'0'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{Thread\PYGZus{}id} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'10'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{Tmp\PYGZus{}table} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'No'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{Tmp\PYGZus{}table\PYGZus{}on\PYGZus{}disk} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'No'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{arg} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'SELECT col FROM tbl WHERE id=5'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{bytes} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} 103,
  \PYG{n+nv}{cmd} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'Query'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{db} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'db1'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{fingerprint} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'select col from tbl where id=?'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{host} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{''},
  \PYG{n+nv}{pos\PYGZus{}in\PYGZus{}log} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} 1334,
  \PYG{n+nv}{ts} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'071218 11:48:27'},
  \PYG{n+nv}{user} \PYG{o}{=}\textgreater{} \PYG{l+s+s1}{'[SQL\PYGZus{}SLAVE]'}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}};
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{COMMON}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:common}
These attribute are common to all input {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}type}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--processlist]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}processlist}}}},
except where noted.

arg
\begin{quote}

The query text, or the command for admin commands like \code{Ping}.
\end{quote}

bytes
\begin{quote}

The byte length of the \code{arg}.
\end{quote}

cmd
\begin{quote}

``Query'' or ``Admin''.
\end{quote}

db
\begin{quote}

The current database.  The value comes from USE database statements.
By default, \code{Schema} is an alias which is automatically
changed to \code{db}; see {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--attribute-aliases]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}attribute-aliases}}}}.
\end{quote}

fingerprint
\begin{quote}

An abstracted form of the query.  See ``FINGERPRINTS''.
\end{quote}

host
\begin{quote}

Client host which executed the query.
\end{quote}

pos\_in\_log
\begin{quote}

The byte offset of the event in the log or tcpdump,
except for {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--processlist]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}processlist}}}}.
\end{quote}

Query\_time
\begin{quote}

The total time the query took, including lock time.
\end{quote}

ts
\begin{quote}

The timestamp of when the query ended.
\end{quote}


\subsection{SLOW, GENERAL, AND BINARY LOGS}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:slow-general-and-binary-logs}
Events have all available attributes from the log file.  Therefore, you only
need to look at the log file to see which events are available, but remember:
not all events have the same attributes.


\subsection{TCPDUMP}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:tcpdump}
These attributes are available when parsing {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--type]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}type}}}} tcpdump.

Error\_no
\begin{quote}

The MariaDB error number if the query caused an error.
\end{quote}

ip
\begin{quote}

The client's IP address.  Certain log files may also contain this attribute.
\end{quote}

No\_good\_index\_used
\begin{quote}

Yes or No if no good index existed for the query (flag set by server).
\end{quote}

No\_index\_used
\begin{quote}

Yes or No if the query did not use any index (flag set by server).
\end{quote}

port
\begin{quote}

The client's port number.
\end{quote}

Warning\_count
\begin{quote}

The number of warnings, as otherwise shown by \code{SHOW WARNINGS}.
\end{quote}


\subsection{PROCESSLIST}
\label{mariadb-query-digest:processlist}
If using {\hyperref[mariadb-query-digest:cmdoption-mariadb-query-digest--processlist]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}processlist}}}}, an \code{id} attribute is available for
the process ID, in addition to the common attributes.
