\section{\textbf{mariadb-stacktrace}}
\label{mariadb-stacktrace:mariadb-stacktrace}\label{mariadb-stacktrace::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-stacktrace:name}
\textbf{mariadb-stacktrace} - Aggregate GDB stack traces for a selected program.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-stacktrace:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-stacktrace:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{stacktrace} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{FILES}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-stacktrace} is a poor man's profiler, inspired by \href{http://poormansprofiler.org}{http://poormansprofiler.org}.
It can create and summarize full stack traces of processes on Linux.
Summaries of stack traces can be an invaluable tool for diagnosing what
a process is waiting for.


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-stacktrace:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-stacktrace} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-stacktrace:description}
\textbf{mariadb-stacktrace} performs two tasks: it gets a stack trace, and it summarizes the stack
trace.  If a file is given on the command line, the tool skips the first step
and just aggregates the file.

To summarize the stack trace, the tool extracts the function name (symbol)
from each level of the stack, and combines them with commas.  It does this
for each thread in the output.  Afterwards, it sorts similar threads together
and counts how many of each one there are, then sorts them most-frequent first.

\textbf{mariadb-stacktrace} is a read-only tool.  However, collecting GDB stacktraces is achieved by
attaching GDB to the program and printing stack traces from all threads. This
will freeze the program for some period of time, ranging from a second or so to
much longer on very busy systems with a lot of memory and many threads in the
program.  In the tool's default usage as a MariaDB profiling tool, this means that
MariaDB will be unresponsive while the tool runs, although if you are using the
tool to diagnose an unresponsive server, there is really no reason not to do
this.  In addition to freezing the server, there is also some risk of the server
crashing or performing badly after GDB detaches from it.

\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}
\label{mariadb-stacktrace:system-requirements}

then gdb is also required to create backtraces for the process specified
on the command line.

\section{\textbf{mariadb-stat}}
\label{mariadb-stat::doc}\label{mariadb-stat:mariadb-stat}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-stat:name}
\textbf{mariadb-stat} - Collect forensic data about MariaDB when problems occur.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-stat:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-stat:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{stat} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-stat} waits for a trigger condition to occur, then collects data
to help diagnose problems.  The tool is designed to run as a daemon with root
privileges, so that you can diagnose intermittent problems that you cannot
observe directly.  You can also use it to execute a custom command, or to
collect data on demand without waiting for the trigger to occur.


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-stat:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-stat} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-stat:description}
Sometimes a problem happens infrequently and for a short time, giving you no
chance to see the system when it happens. How do you solve intermittent MariaDB
problems when you can't observe them? That's why \textbf{mariadb-stat} exists. In addition to
using it when there's a known problem on your servers, it is a good idea to run
\textbf{mariadb-stat} all the time, even when you think nothing is wrong.  You will
appreciate the data it collects when a problem occurs, because problems such as
MariaDB lockups or spikes in activity typically leave no evidence to use in root
cause analysis.

\textbf{mariadb-stat} does two things: it watches a MariaDB server and waits for a trigger
condition to occur, and it collects diagnostic data when that trigger occurs.
To avoid false-positives caused by short-lived problems, the trigger condition
must be true at least {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--cycles]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}cycles}}}} times before a {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} is triggered.

To use \textbf{mariadb-stat} effectively, you need to define a good trigger.  A good trigger
is sensitive enough to fire reliably when a problem occurs, so that you don't
miss a chance to solve problems.  On the other hand, a good trigger isn't
prone to false positives, so you don't gather information when the server
is functioning normally.

The most reliable triggers for MariaDB tend to be the number of connections to the
server, and the number of queries running concurrently. These are available in
the SHOW GLOBAL STATUS command as Threads\_connected and Threads\_running.
Sometimes Threads\_connected is not a reliable indicator of trouble, but
Threads\_running usually is.  Your job, as the tool's user, is to define an
appropriate trigger condition for the tool.  Choose carefully, because the
quality of your results will depend on the trigger you choose.

You define the trigger with the {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--function]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}function}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}},
{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}threshold}}}}, and {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--cycles]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}cycles}}}} options.  The default values
for these options define a reasonable trigger, but you should adjust
or change them to suite your particular system and needs.

By default, \textbf{mariadb-stat} tool watches MariaDB forever until the trigger occurs,
then it collects diagnostic data for a while, and sleeps afterwards to avoid
repeatedly collecting data if the trigger remains true.  The general order of
operations is:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{k}{while }\PYG{n+nb}{true}; \PYG{k}{do}
\PYG{k}{   }\PYG{k}{if} --variable from --function \textgreater{} --threshold; \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{      }cycles\PYGZus{}true++
      \PYG{k}{if }cycles\PYGZus{}true \textgreater{}\PYG{o}{=} --cycles; \PYG{k}{then}
         --notify-by-email
         \PYG{k}{if} --collect; \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{            }\PYG{k}{if} --disk-bytes-free and --disk-pct-free ok; \PYG{k}{then}
               \PYG{o}{(}--collect \PYG{k}{for} --run-time seconds\PYG{o}{)} \&
            \PYG{k}{fi}
\PYG{k}{            }rm files in --dest older than --retention-time
         \PYG{k}{fi}
\PYG{k}{         }iter++
         \PYG{n+nv}{cycles\PYGZus{}true}\PYG{o}{=}0
      \PYG{k}{fi}
\PYG{k}{      }\PYG{k}{if }iter \textless{} --iterations; \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{         }sleep --sleep seconds
      \PYG{k}{else}
\PYG{k}{         }\PYG{n+nb}{break}
\PYG{n+nb}{      }\PYG{k}{fi}
\PYG{k}{   }\PYG{k}{else}
\PYG{k}{      }\PYG{k}{if }iter \textless{} --iterations; \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{         }sleep --interval seconds
      \PYG{k}{else}
\PYG{k}{         }\PYG{n+nb}{break}
\PYG{n+nb}{      }\PYG{k}{fi}
\PYG{k}{   }\PYG{k}{fi}
\PYG{k}{done}
rm old --dest files older than --retention-time
\PYG{k}{if} --collect process are still running; \PYG{k}{then}
\PYG{k}{   }\PYG{n+nb}{wait }up to --run-time * 3 seconds
   \PYG{n+nb}{kill }any remaining --collect processes
\PYG{k}{fi}
\end{Verbatim}

The diagnostic data is written to files whose names begin with a timestamp, so
you can distinguish samples from each other in case the tool collects data
multiple times.  The pt-sift tool is designed to help you browse and analyze
the resulting data samples.

Although this sounds simple enough, in practice there are a number of
subtleties, such as detecting when the disk is beginning to fill up so that the
tool doesn't cause the server to run out of disk space.  This tool handles these
types of potential problems, so it's a good idea to use this tool instead of
writing something from scratch and possibly experiencing some of the hazards
this tool is designed to avoid.


\subsection{CONFIGURING}
\label{mariadb-stat:configuring}
You can use standard MariaDB tool configuration files to set command line
options.

You will probably want to run the tool as a daemon and customize at least the
{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}threshold}}}}.  Here's a sample configuration file for triggering when
there are more than 20 queries running at once:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
daemonize
\PYG{n+nv}{threshold}\PYG{o}{=}20
\end{Verbatim}

If you don't run the tool as root, then you will need specify several options,
such as {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--pid]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}pid}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--log]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}log}}}}, and {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}, else the tool will probably
fail to start.


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-stat:options}\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--ask-pass}\index{--ask-pass!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--ask-pass}\pysigline{\bfcode{--ask-pass}\code{}}
Prompt for a password when connecting to MariaDB.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--collect}\index{--collect!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect}\pysigline{\bfcode{--collect}\code{}}
default: yes; negatable: yes

Collect diagnostic data when the trigger occurs.  Specify \code{-{-}no-collect}
to make the tool watch the system but not collect data.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--stalk]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}stalk}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--collect-gdb}\index{--collect-gdb!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-gdb}\pysigline{\bfcode{--collect-gdb}\code{}}
Collect GDB stacktraces.  This is achieved by attaching to MariaDB and printing
stack traces from all threads. This will freeze the server for some period of
time, ranging from a second or so to much longer on very busy systems with a lot
of memory and many threads in the server.  For this reason, it is disabled by
default. However, if you are trying to diagnose a server stall or lockup,
freezing the server causes no additional harm, and the stack traces can be vital
for diagnosis.

In addition to freezing the server, there is also some risk of the server
crashing or performing badly after GDB detaches from it.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--collect-oprofile}\index{--collect-oprofile!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-oprofile}\pysigline{\bfcode{--collect-oprofile}\code{}}
Collect oprofile data.  This is achieved by starting an oprofile session,
letting it run for the collection time, and then stopping and saving the
resulting profile data in the system's default location.  Please read your
system's oprofile documentation to learn more about this.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--collect-strace}\index{--collect-strace!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-strace}\pysigline{\bfcode{--collect-strace}\code{}}
Collect strace data. This is achieved by attaching strace to the server, which
will make it run very slowly until strace detaches.  The same cautions apply as
those listed in --collect-gdb.  You should not enable this option together with
--collect-gdb, because GDB and strace can't attach to the server process
simultaneously.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--collect-tcpdump}\index{--collect-tcpdump!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-tcpdump}\pysigline{\bfcode{--collect-tcpdump}\code{}}
Collect tcpdump data. This option causes tcpdump to capture all traffic on all
interfaces for the port on which MariaDB is listening.  You can later use
pt-query-digest to decode the MariaDB protocol and extract a log of query traffic
from it.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--config}\index{--config!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--config}\pysigline{\bfcode{--config}\code{}}
type: string

Read this comma-separated list of config files.  If specified, this must be the
first option on the command line.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--cycles}\index{--cycles!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--cycles}\pysigline{\bfcode{--cycles}\code{}}
type: int; default: 5

How many times {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}} must be greater than {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}threshold}}}} before triggering {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}}.  This helps prevent false positives, and makes
the trigger condition less likely to fire when the problem recovers quickly.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--daemonize}\index{--daemonize!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--daemonize}\pysigline{\bfcode{--daemonize}\code{}}
Daemonize the tool.  This causes the tool to fork into the background and log
its output as specified in --log.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--defaults-file}\index{--defaults-file!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--defaults-file}\pysigline{\bfcode{--defaults-file}\code{}}
short form: -F; type: string

Only read mariadb options from the given file.  You must give an absolute
pathname.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--dest}\index{--dest!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--dest}\pysigline{\bfcode{--dest}\code{}}
type: string; default: /var/lib/mariadb-stat

Where to save diagnostic data from {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}}.  Each time the tool
collects data, it writes to a new set of files, which are named with the
current system timestamp.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--disk-bytes-free}\index{--disk-bytes-free!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--disk-bytes-free}\pysigline{\bfcode{--disk-bytes-free}\code{}}
type: size; default: 100M

Do not {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} if the disk has less than this much free space.
This prevents the tool from filling up the disk with diagnostic data.

If the {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}} directory contains a previously captured sample of data,
the tool will measure its size and use that as an estimate of how much data is
likely to be gathered this time, too.  It will then be even more pessimistic,
and will refuse to collect data unless the disk has enough free space to hold
the sample and still have the desired amount of free space.  For example, if
you'd like 100MB of free space and the previous diagnostic sample consumed
100MB, the tool won't collect any data unless the disk has 200MB free.

Valid size value suffixes are k, M, G, and T.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--disk-pct-free}\index{--disk-pct-free!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--disk-pct-free}\pysigline{\bfcode{--disk-pct-free}\code{}}
type: int; default: 5

Do not {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} if the disk has less than this percent free space.
This prevents the tool from filling up the disk with diagnostic data.

This option works similarly to {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--disk-bytes-free]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}disk-bytes-free}}}} but specifies a
percentage margin of safety instead of a bytes margin of safety.
The tool honors both options, and will not collect any data unless both
margins are satisfied.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--function}\index{--function!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--function}\pysigline{\bfcode{--function}\code{}}
type: string; default: status

What to watch for the trigger.  The default value watches
\code{SHOW GLOBAL STATUS}, but you can also watch \code{SHOW PROCESSLIST} and specify
a file with your own custom code.  This function supplies the value of
{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}}, which is then compared against {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}threshold}}}} to see if the
the trigger condition is met.  Additional options may be required as
well; see below. Possible values are:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
status

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Watch \code{SHOW GLOBAL STATUS} for the trigger.  The value of
{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}} then defines which status counter is the trigger.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
processlist

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Watch \code{SHOW FULL PROCESSLIST} for the trigger.  The trigger
value is the count of processes whose {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}} column matches the
{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--match]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}match}}}} option.  For example, to trigger {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} when more than
10 processes are in the ``statistics'' state, specify:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--function processlist \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
--variable State       \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
--match statistics     \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
--threshold 10
\end{Verbatim}
\end{quote}

In addition, you can specify a file that contains your custom trigger
function, written in Unix shell script.  This can be a wrapper that executes
anything you wish.  If the argument to {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--function]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}function}}}} is a file, then it
takes precedence over built-in functions, so if there is a file in the working
directory named ``status'' or ``processlist'' then the tool will use that file
even though are valid built-in values.

The file works by providing a function called \code{trg\_plugin}, and the tool
simply sources the file and executes the function.  For example, the file
might contain:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
trg\PYGZus{}plugin\PYG{o}{(}\PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
   mysql \PYG{n+nv}{\PYGZdl{}EXT\PYGZus{}ARGV} -e \PYG{l+s+s2}{"SHOW ENGINE INNODB STATUS"} \PYG{l+s+se}{\PYGZbs{}}
     \textbar{} grep -c \PYG{l+s+s2}{"has waited at"}
\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

This snippet will count the number of mutex waits inside InnoDB.  It
illustrates the general principle: the function must output a number, which is
then compared to {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}threshold}}}} as usual.  The \code{\$EXT\_ARGV} variable
contains the MariaDB options mentioned in the ``SYNOPSIS'' above.

The file should not alter the tool's existing global variables.  Prefix any
file-specific global variables with {}`{}`PLUGIN\_{}`{}` or make them local.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--help}\index{--help!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--help}\pysigline{\bfcode{--help}\code{}}
Print help and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--host}\index{--host!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--host}\pysigline{\bfcode{--host}\code{}}
short form: -h; type: string

Host to connect to.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--interval}\index{--interval!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--interval}\pysigline{\bfcode{--interval}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

How often to check the if trigger is true, in seconds.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--iterations}\index{--iterations!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--iterations}\pysigline{\bfcode{--iterations}\code{}}
type: int

How many times to {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} diagnostic data.  By default, the tool
runs forever and collects data every time the trigger occurs.
Specify {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}} to collect data a limited number of times.
This option is also useful with \code{-{-}no-stalk} to collect data once and
exit, for example.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--log}\index{--log!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--log}\pysigline{\bfcode{--log}\code{}}
type: string; default: /var/log/mariadb-stat.log

Print all output to this file when daemonized.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--match}\index{--match!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--match}\pysigline{\bfcode{--match}\code{}}
type: string

The pattern to use when watching SHOW PROCESSLIST.  See {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--function]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}function}}}}
for details.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--notify-by-email}\index{--notify-by-email!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--notify-by-email}\pysigline{\bfcode{--notify-by-email}\code{}}
type: string

Send an email to these addresses for every {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--password}\index{--password!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--password}\pysigline{\bfcode{--password}\code{}}
short form: -p; type: string

Password to use when connecting.
If password contains commas they must be escaped with a backslash: ``exam,ple''

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--pid}\index{--pid!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--pid}\pysigline{\bfcode{--pid}\code{}}
type: string; default: /var/run/mariadb-stat.pid

Create the given PID file.  The tool won't start if the PID file already
exists and the PID it contains is different than the current PID.  However,
if the PID file exists and the PID it contains is no longer running, the
tool will overwrite the PID file with the current PID.  The PID file is
removed automatically when the tool exits.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--plugin}\index{--plugin!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--plugin}\pysigline{\bfcode{--plugin}\code{}}
type: string

Load a plugin to hook into the tool and extend is functionality.
The specified file does not need to be executable, nor does its first line
need to be shebang line.  It only needs to define one or more of these
Bash functions:

before\_stalk
\begin{quote}

Called before stalking.
\end{quote}

before\_collect
\begin{quote}

Called when the trigger occurs, before running a {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}}
subprocesses in the background.
\end{quote}

after\_collect
\begin{quote}

Called after running a collector process.  The PID of the collector process
is passed as the first argument.  This hook is called before
\code{after\_collect\_sleep}.
\end{quote}

after\_collect\_sleep
\begin{quote}

Called after sleeping {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--sleep]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sleep}}}} seconds for the collector process to finish.
This hook is called after \code{after\_collect}.
\end{quote}

after\_interval\_sleep
\begin{quote}

Called after sleeping {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}} seconds after each trigger check.
\end{quote}

after\_stalk
\begin{quote}

Called after stalking.  Since \textbf{mariadb-stat} stalks forever by default,
this hook is only called if {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}} is specified.
\end{quote}

For example, a very simple plugin that touches a file when {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}}
is triggered:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
before\PYGZus{}collect\PYG{o}{(}\PYG{o}{)} \PYG{o}{\PYGZob{}}
   touch /tmp/foo
\PYG{o}{\PYGZcb{}}
\end{Verbatim}

Since the plugin is completely sourced (imported) into the tool's namespace,
be careful not to define other functions or global variables that already
exist in the tool.  You should prefix all plugin-specific functions and
global variables with \code{plugin\_} or \code{PLUGIN\_}.

Plugins have access to all command line options but they should not modify
them.  Each option is a global variable like \code{\$OPT\_DEST} which corresponds
to {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--dest]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}dest}}}}.  Therefore, the global variable for each command line option
is \code{OPT\_} plus the option name in all caps with hyphens replaced by
underscores.

Plugins can stop the tool by setting the global variable \code{OKTORUN}
to \code{1}.  In this case, the global variable \code{EXIT\_REASON} should also
be set to indicate why the tool was stopped.

Plugin writers should keep in mind that the file destination prefix currently
in use should be accessed through the \code{\$prefix} variable, rather than
\code{\$OPT\_PREFIX}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--mariadb-only}\index{--mariadb-only!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--mariadb-only}\pysigline{\bfcode{--mariadb-only}\code{}}
Trigger only MariaDB related captures, ignoring all others. The only not MariaDB related
value being collected is the disk space, because it is needed to calculate the
available free disk space to write the result files.
This option is useful for RDS instances.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--port}\index{--port!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--port}\pysigline{\bfcode{--port}\code{}}
short form: -P; type: int

Port number to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--prefix}\index{--prefix!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--prefix}\pysigline{\bfcode{--prefix}\code{}}
type: string

The filename prefix for diagnostic samples.  By default, all files created
by the same {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} instance have a timestamp prefix based on the current
local time, like \code{2011\_12\_06\_14\_02\_02}, which is December 6, 2011 at 14:02:02.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--retention-count}\index{--retention-count!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--retention-count}\pysigline{\bfcode{--retention-count}\code{}}
type: int; default: 0

Keep the data for the last N runs. If N \textgreater{} 0, the program will keep the data for the last
N runs and will delete the older data.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--retention-size}\index{--retention-size!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--retention-size}\pysigline{\bfcode{--retention-size}\code{}}
type: int; default: 0

Keep up to --retention-size MB of data. It will keep at least 1 run even if the size is bigger
than the specified in this parameter

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--retention-time}\index{--retention-time!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--retention-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--retention-time}\code{}}
type: int; default: 30

Number of days to retain collected samples.  Any samples that are older will be
purged.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--run-time}\index{--run-time!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--run-time}\pysigline{\bfcode{--run-time}\code{}}
type: int; default: 30

How long to {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} diagnostic data when the trigger occurs.
The value is in seconds and should not be longer than {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--sleep]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sleep}}}}.  It is
usually not necessary to change this; if the default 30 seconds doesn't
collect enough data, running longer is not likely to help because the system
or MariaDB server is probably too busy to respond.  In fact, in many cases a
shorter collection period is appropriate.

This value is used two other times.  After collecting, the collect subprocess
will wait another {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}} seconds for its commands to finish.  Some
commands can take awhile if the system is running very slowly (which can
likely be the case given that a collection was triggered).  Since empty files
are deleted, the extra wait gives commands time to finish and write their
data.  The value is potentially used again just before the tool exits to wait
again for any collect subprocesses to finish.  In most cases this won't
happen because of the aforementioned extra wait.  If it happens, the tool
will log ``Waiting up to N seconds for subprocesses to finish...'' where N is
three times {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--run-time]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}run-time}}}}.  In both cases, after waiting, the tool kills
all of its subprocesses.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--sleep}\index{--sleep!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--sleep}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sleep}\code{}}
type: int; default: 300

How long to sleep after {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}}.  This prevents the tool
from triggering continuously, which might be a problem if the collection process is intrusive.
It also prevents filling up the disk or gathering too much data to analyze
reasonably.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--sleep-collect}\index{--sleep-collect!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--sleep-collect}\pysigline{\bfcode{--sleep-collect}\code{}}
type: int; default: 1

How long to sleep between collection loop cycles.  This is useful with
\code{-{-}no-stalk} to do long collections.  For example, to collect data every
minute for an hour, specify: \code{-{-}no-stalk -{-}run-time 3600 -{-}sleep-collect 60}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--socket}\index{--socket!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--socket}\pysigline{\bfcode{--socket}\code{}}
short form: -S; type: string

Socket file to use for connection.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--stalk}\index{--stalk!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--stalk}\pysigline{\bfcode{--stalk}\code{}}
default: yes; negatable: yes

Watch the server and wait for the trigger to occur.  Specify \code{-{-}no-stalk}
to collect diagnostic data immediately, that is, without waiting for the
trigger to occur.  You probably also want to specify values for
{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--interval]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}interval}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--iterations]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}iterations}}}}, and {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--sleep]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}sleep}}}}.  For example, to
immediately collect data for 1 minute then exit, specify:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
--no-stalk --run-time 60 --iterations 1
\end{Verbatim}

{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--cycles]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}cycles}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--daemonize]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}daemonize}}}}, {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--log]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}log}}}} and {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--pid]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}pid}}}} have no effect
with \code{-{-}no-stalk}.  Safeguard options, like {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--disk-bytes-free]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}disk-bytes-free}}}} and
{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--disk-pct-free]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}disk-pct-free}}}}, are still respected.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--threshold}\index{--threshold!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold}\pysigline{\bfcode{--threshold}\code{}}
type: int; default: 25

The maximum acceptable value for {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}}.  {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect}}}} is
triggered when the value of {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}} is greater than {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}threshold}}}}
for {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--cycles]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}cycles}}}} many times.  Currently, there is no way to define a lower
threshold to check for a {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}variable}}}} value that is too low.

See also {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--function]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}function}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--user}\index{--user!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--user}\pysigline{\bfcode{--user}\code{}}
short form: -u; type: string

User for login if not current user.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--variable}\index{--variable!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--variable}\pysigline{\bfcode{--variable}\code{}}
type: string; default: Threads\_running

The variable to compare against {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--threshold]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}threshold}}}}.  See also {\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--function]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}function}}}}.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--verbose}\index{--verbose!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--verbose}\pysigline{\bfcode{--verbose}\code{}}
type: int; default: 2

Print more or less information while running.  Since the tool is designed
to be a long-running daemon, the default verbosity level only prints the
most important information.  If you run the tool interactively, you may
want to use a higher verbosity level.

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
LEVEL \PYG{n+nv}{PRINTS}
\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=} \PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{o}{=}
0     Errors
1     Warnings
2     Matching triggers and collection info
3     Non-matching triggers
\end{Verbatim}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mariadb-stat command line option!--version}\index{--version!mariadb-stat command line option}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--version}\pysigline{\bfcode{--version}\code{}}
Print tool's version and exit.

\end{fulllineitems}



\subsection{ENVIRONMENT}
\label{mariadb-stat:environment}
This tool does not require any environment variables for configuration,
although it can be influenced to work differently by through several
variables.  Keep in mind that these are expert settings, and should not
be used in most cases.

Specifically, the variables that can be set are:

CMD\_GDB

CMD\_IOSTAT

CMD\_MPSTAT

CMD\_MYSQL

CMD\_MYSQLADMIN

CMD\_OPCONTROL

CMD\_OPREPORT

CMD\_PMAP

CMD\_STRACE

CMD\_SYSCTL

CMD\_TCPDUMP

CMD\_VMSTAT

For example, during collection iostat is called with a -dx argument, but
because you have an NFS partition, you also need the -n flag there.  Instead
of editing the source, you can call \textbf{mariadb-stat} as

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n+nv}{CMD\PYGZus{}IOSTAT}\PYG{o}{=}\PYG{l+s+s2}{"iostat -n"} mariadb-stat ...
\end{Verbatim}

which will do exactly what you need.  Combined with the plugin hooks, this
gives you a fine-grained control of what the tool does.

It is possible to enable \code{debug} mode in mysqladmin specifying:

\code{CMD\_MYSQLADMIN='mysqladmin debug' :program:{}`mariadb-stat{}` params ...}


\subsection{SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS}
\label{mariadb-stat:system-requirements}
This tool requires Bash v3 or newer.  Certain options require other programs:

{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-gdb]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect-gdb}}}} requires \code{gdb}

{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-oprofile]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect-oprofile}}}} requires \code{opcontrol} and \code{opreport}

{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-strace]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect-strace}}}} requires \code{strace}

{\hyperref[mariadb-stat:cmdoption-mariadb-stat--collect-tcpdump]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}collect-tcpdump}}}} requires \code{tcpdump}

\section{\textbf{mariadb-stat-browser}}
\label{mariadb-stat-browser:mariadb-stat-browser}\label{mariadb-stat-browser::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-stat-browser:name}
\textbf{mariadb-stat-browser} - Browses files created by mariadb-stat.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-stat-browser:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-stat-browser:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-stat-browser FILE\textbar{}PREFIX\textbar{}DIRECTORY
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-stat-browser} browses files created by mariadb-stat.  If no options are given,
the tool browses all mariadb-stat files in \code{/var/lib/mariadb-stat} if that directory
exists, else the current working directory is used.  If a FILE is given,
the tool browses files with the same prefix in the given file's directory.
If a PREFIX is given, the tool browses files in \code{/var/lib/mariadb-stat}
(or the current working directory) with the same prefix.  If a DIRECTORY
is given, the tool browses all mariadb-stat files in it.


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-stat-browser:risks}
Percona Toolkit is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-stat-browser:description}
\textbf{mariadb-stat-browser} downloads other tools that it might need, such as mariadb-iostat,
and then makes a list of the unique timestamp prefixes of all the files in
the directory, as written by the mariadb-stat tool.  If the user specified
a timestamp on the command line, then it begins with that sample of data;
otherwise it begins by showing a list of the timestamps and prompting for
a selection.  Thereafter, it displays a summary of the selected sample, and
the user can navigate and inspect with keystrokes.  The keystroke commands
you can use are as follows:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
d

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Sets the action to start the mariadb-iostat tool on the sample's disk
performance statistics.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
i

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Sets the action to view the first INNODB STATUS sample in less.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
m

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Displays the first 4 samples of SHOW STATUS counters side by side with the
mariadb-status-diff tool.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
n

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Summarizes the first sample of netstat data in two ways: by originating host,
and by connection state.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
j

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Select the next timestamp as the active sample.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
k

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Select the previous timestamp as the active sample.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
q

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Quit the program.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
1

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Sets the action for each sample to the default, which is to view a summary
of the sample.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
0

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Sets the action to just list the files in the sample.
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} \begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\end{itemize}

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}

Sets the action to view all of the sample's files in the less program.
\end{quote}


\subsection{OPTIONS}
\label{mariadb-stat-browser:options}\index{mariadb-stat-browser command line option!--help}\index{--help!mariadb-stat-browser command line option}

\section{\textbf{mariadb-status-diff}}
\label{mariadb-status-diff::doc}\label{mariadb-status-diff:mariadb-status-diff}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-status-diff:name}
\textbf{mariadb-status-diff} - Look at many samples of MariaDB \code{SHOW GLOBAL STATUS} side-by-side.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-status-diff:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-status-diff:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{status}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{diff} \PYG{p}{[}\PYG{n}{OPTIONS}\PYG{p}{]} \PYG{o}{-}\PYG{o}{-} \PYG{n}{COMMAND}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-status-diff} columnizes repeated output from a program like mariadb-admin extended.

Get output from \code{mariadb-admin}:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-status-diff -r -- mariadb-admin ext -i10 -c3
\end{Verbatim}

Get output from a file:

\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
mariadb-status-diff -r -- cat mariadb-admin-output.txt
\end{Verbatim}


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-status-diff:risks}
pt-mext is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Review the tool's known ``BUGS''

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-status-diff:description}
\textbf{mariadb-status-diff} executes the \code{COMMAND} you specify, and reads through the result one
line at a time.  It places each line into a temporary file.  When it finds a
blank line, it assumes that a new sample of SHOW GLOBAL STATUS is starting,
and it creates a new temporary file.  At the end of this process, it has a
number of temporary files.  It joins the temporary files together side-by-side
and prints the result.  If {\hyperref[mariadb-status-diff:cmdoption-mariadb-status-diff--relative]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}relative}}}} option is given, it first subtracts
each sample from the one after it before printing results.


\subsection{OPTIONS}

\section{\textbf{mariadb-summary}}
\label{mariadb-summary:mariadb-summary}\label{mariadb-summary::doc}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-summary:name}
\textbf{mariadb-summary} - Summarize system information nicely.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-summary:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-summary:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{summary}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-summary} conveniently summarizes the status and configuration of
a database and its underlying server. It is not a tuning tool or diagnosis tool.
It produces a report that is easy to diff and can be pasted into emails without
losing the formatting. This tool works well on many types of Unix systems.


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-summary:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-summary} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-summary:description}
\textbf{mariadb-summary} runs mariadb-system-summary and mariadb-database-summary together.

These tools run a large variety of commands to inspect system and MariaDB
status and configuration.

It works best when executed as a privileged user, but will also work without
privileges, although some output might not be possible to generate without root.


\subsection{OUTPUT}
\label{mariadb-summary:output}
See mariadb-system-summary and mariadb-database-summary documentation for output
details.

\section{\textbf{mariadb-system-summary}}
\label{mariadb-system-summary::doc}\label{mariadb-system-summary:mariadb-system-summary}

\subsection{NAME}
\label{mariadb-system-summary:name}
\textbf{mariadb-system-summary} - Summarize system information nicely.


\subsection{SYNOPSIS}
\label{mariadb-system-summary:synopsis}

\subsubsection{Usage}
\label{mariadb-system-summary:usage}
\begin{Verbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{mariadb}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{system}\PYG{o}{-}\PYG{n}{summary}
\end{Verbatim}

\textbf{mariadb-system-summary} conveniently summarizes the status and configuration of
a server. It is not a tuning tool or diagnosis tool.  It produces a report that
is easy to diff and can be pasted into emails without losing the formatting.
This tool works well on many types of Unix systems.


\subsection{RISKS}
\label{mariadb-system-summary:risks}
\textbf{mariadb-system-summary} is mature, proven in the real world, and well tested,
but all database tools can pose a risk to the system and the database
server.  Before using this tool, please:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Read the tool's documentation

\item {} 
Test the tool on a non-production server

\item {} 
Backup your production server and verify the backups

\end{itemize}


\subsection{DESCRIPTION}
\label{mariadb-system-summary:description}
\textbf{mariadb-system-summary} runs a large variety of commands to inspect system status and
configuration, saves the output into files in a temporary directory, and
then runs Unix commands on these results to format them nicely.  It works
best when executed as a privileged user, but will also work without privileges,
although some output might not be possible to generate without root.


\subsection{OUTPUT}
\label{mariadb-system-summary:output}
Many of the outputs from this tool are deliberately rounded to show their
magnitude but not the exact detail. This is called fuzzy-rounding. The idea is
that it doesn't matter whether a particular counter is 918 or 921; such a small
variation is insignificant, and only makes the output hard to compare to other
servers. Fuzzy-rounding rounds in larger increments as the input grows. It
begins by rounding to the nearest 5, then the nearest 10, nearest 25, and then
repeats by a factor of 10 larger (50, 100, 250), and so on, as the input grows.

The following is a simple report generated from a CentOS virtual machine,
broken into sections with commentary following each section. Some long lines
are reformatted for clarity when reading this documentation as a manual page in
a terminal.

Information about memory is gathered from \code{free}. The Used statistic is the
total of the rss sizes displayed by \code{ps}. The Dirty statistic for the cached
value comes from \emph{/proc/meminfo}. On Linux, the swappiness settings are
gathered from \code{sysctl}. The final portion of this section is a table of the
DIMMs, which comes from \code{dmidecode}. In this example there is no output.

The tool can detect a variety of RAID controllers by examining \code{lspci} and
\code{dmesg} information. If the controller software is installed on the system, in
many cases it is able to execute status commands and show a summary of the RAID
controller's status and configuration. If your system is not supported, please
file a bug report.

columns are received and transmitted bytes, packets, and errors.  You can skip
this section by disabling the {\hyperref[mariadb-system-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-system-summary--summarize-network]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}summarize-network}}}} option.

This section shows a summary of network connections, retrieved from \code{netstat}
and ``fuzzy-rounded'' to make them easier to compare when the numbers grow large.
There are two sub-sections showing how many connections there are per origin
and destination IP address, and a sub-section showing the count of ports in
use.  The section ends with the count of the network connections' states.  You
can skip this section by disabling the {\hyperref[mariadb-system-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-system-summary--summarize-network]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}summarize-network}}}} option.

This section shows the first few lines of \code{top} so that you can see what
processes are actively using CPU time.  The notable processes include the SSH
daemon and any process whose out-of-memory-killer priority is set to 17. You
can skip this section by disabling the {\hyperref[mariadb-system-summary:cmdoption-mariadb-system-summary--summarize-processes]{\emph{\texttt{-{-}summarize-processes}}}} option.
